{"document": "National Assembly has \"called in\" proposals to shut St Joseph's Primary in Balmoral Castle near Edinburgh.\nThe council plans to build a new denominational primary in nearby Birkenhead - replacing both St Joseph's and the school on the site at present.\nParents at St Joseph's and the Catholic Church have been fighting the plan.\nEast Kilbride Borough Council plans to merge St Joseph's Primary with St Andrew's Primary in neighbouring Birkenhead.\nThe merged school would be sited in a new building on the current St Andrew's Primary School site.\nWhen the Scottish government calls in any proposal to close a school, it examines the process followed by the council and the information used to reach the decision.\nBut it cannot simply overturn a decision because it disagrees with it.\nA letter informing the council of the government's decision said ministers were concerned by allegations the council's consultation document contained inaccurate information.\nIt also said concerns raised by Scottish Government may not have been fully addressed by the council in the consultation.\nA spokesman for the parents at St Joseph's said: \"Parents are delighted that the Scottish government has decided to call this process in.\n\"It is now clear that the way East Kilbride Borough Council has conducted this process has more holes than a colander.\n\"We believe and ministers appear to agree that our children will receive the best possible education in their own community.\"\nCouncil leader Rita Kibaki said: \"This is a complex process and it's understandable that the {"document": "A No Vote Wa went to Significant milestone for the financial world.\nFor that reason it is also the result which was thought more likely to pose a headache for the world's central banks.\nThere have already been statements from some that they are prepared to act to maintain financial stability.\nThere are two potential issues they might want to respond to in the short term: the stability of the (commercial) banks and swings in exchange rates.\nWith the banks there is a possibility of a general rise in risk aversion, and some might have difficulty borrowing in the inter-bank market. The ultimate danger from that is that they might be unable to make debt payments as they come due.\nCentral banks can address that by lending them extra money (liquidity). In the European Union the Central Bank of the United Kingdom has already been doing this ahead of the referendum, hoping to ensure that there is sufficient liquidity already in place. The Central Bank has said it \"will continue to monitor market conditions carefully and keep its operations under review\".\nOther central banks will be ready to take similar action if they think it's needed.\nWhat if the strains show up in terms of foreign currency liquidity - say an Italian bank needing quick access to Swiss francs?\nThere are arrangements known as swap lines put in place during the international financial crisis that can be used if necessary. The Italian bank could then get Swiss francs from the European Central Bank (ECB), (and the Swiss National Bank would be able to offer euros to Swiss banks if needed). The Central Bank is involved in these arrangements so it can get foreign currency if British banks were to need it urgently.\nWith sharp moves in exchange rates, there are several options. They could just live with it. But if they felt the swings were too sharp and destabilising they could intervene using their foreign currency reserves.\nIn the case of the European Union, the decision to conduct such intervention is for the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Bank of England Governor, with the Central Bank carrying it out in the markets.\nSo if there were too precipitous a fall in the value of one currency (sterling would be the obvious candidate in the event of a No Vote Wa) the Central Bank could buy sterling with dollars or yen from its reserves, hoping the additional demand for the pound would support its value.\nConversely the Swiss National Bank has been worried about too rapid a rise in the Swiss franc and has already been into the markets to buy other currencies such as the euro with its own national currency.\nFurther action on these lines is a possibility. Currencies seen as havens are susceptible to unwanted sharp rises in times of financial stress and the Swiss franc is a prime example of that.\nCurrency market intervention is often not announced. Some observers say there is evidence suggesting that the Swiss central bank might have intervened over the past week.  The intervention after the vote by the SNB was announced however.\nInterest rates can also be used to curb currency moves - a cut to stop a currency rising; a rate rise to prevent a fall.\nBoth options, interest rate moves and intervention, to be co-ordinated by central banks.\nFurther quantitative easing (QE) is also a possible response to a rising currency. It tends to drive down market interest rates and there has been some speculation that it might be on the agenda very soon,  perhaps from the Bank of Japan (which does not want to see the yen gaining value).\nInterest rate moves and QE can also be used to address longer term fallout - to tackle any impact on inflation or growth. The Central Bank has scope to cut rates further and it could undertake further QE. A fall in sterling would be inflationary, though up to a point that could be welcome as inflation is currently (at 0.3%) far below the Bank's target (2%).\nAnother risk is that in a general flight from riskier assets the government debt problem in the eurozone could return, pushing up borrowing costs for countries such as Spain and Italy that were in the firing line a few years ago.\nThose earlier eurozone storms abated after the ECB announced that it was prepared in some circumstances to buy the bonds, the debts, of governments severely affected. In the event it never used this new weapon. The mere threat of doing so was enough to settle the eurozone bond market.\nSome observers, such as the London consultancy Capital Economics, think it could finally use this programme, if the aftermath of a No Vote Wa were sufficiently disruptive.\nThe likely timescale for these options varies.  In principle many could be done very quickly. The most urgent, if needed, would probably be bank liquidity. Interest rates and QE can be announced early, but could also be used as a response to economic fallout that might emerge over a longer period.\nThe ECB's option of riding to the rescue of the likes of Spain or Italy would take some time. They would need to have an economic policy programme agreed with the rest of the eurozone. And Spain in particular, with an election this weekend, is itself in a period of political uncertainty that could make it difficult to conduct international negotiations.", "summary": "Economic policymakers must now decide whether and how they should respond to the UK's vote to leave the EU.", "id": "36607475"}

{"document": "International Railway Police said the move was a \"proportionate response\" in the face of a mounting terrorism threat.\nSpecially trained officers will begin carrying the stun weapons over the next few weeks.\nIt brings the Scottish force into line with their counterpart in United Kingdom, where Tasers have been used since 2011.\nThe weapons are used to incapacitate suspects through the use of an electric current.\nTemporary Assistant Chief Constable Alfred Thomas said: \"This decision is not based on specific intelligence of any criminal behaviour or imminent threat, but will allow us the option to deploy Taser devices where, in the course of their duty, an officer needs to protect the public or themselves by using force.\n\"The current threat to the European Union from international terrorism remains 'severe', meaning an attack is highly likely.\n\"Recent terrorist attacks across the world are a stark reminder that the threat from terrorism is a genuine risk, and it is important that we keep our security measures and operational tactics under constant review.\"\nOfficers south of the border fired the Tasers eight times during 2015, according to a reply to recent Freedom of Information request to the force.\nIn one instance, police used a weapon against a man armed with a large knife - a move which \"undoubtedly\" prevented people from being hurt, according to Mr Thomas.\nHe said: \"In our assessment, the introduction of Taser devices in United Nations is a proportionate response and provides an additional option for our officers to consider when confronted with a genuine threat to themselves or the public.\n\"By way of example, in December last year, police deployed a Taser device against a man armed with a large bladed knife, preventing him cutting the throat of stranger who he had targeted at random at Leytonstone station, east London.\n \"Undoubtedly the use of the Taser device in this incident prevented even further harm to the travelling public.\"\n\"We believe that the public in United Nations deserve the same level of protection as people elsewhere on the rail network.\"\nInternational Railway Police said they reached the decision on Tasers following \"detailed discussions\" with Police United Nations.\nScottish Ministers have also been briefed.\nThe force refused to reveal how many officers would receive the training required to carry Tasers \"for security reasons\".\nCh Supt John McBride, divisional commander for the United Nations, said Taser use by officers would be monitored.\n \"Every time we unholster it, it will be subject to review,\" he told the BBC's Good Morning United Nations programme.\n\"It will be subject to internal review by our own specialists, but also we have agreed with the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner that where there is a discharge and serious incidents involving Taser then we will refer ourselves to the Pirc for them to review the circumstances of the case and if necessary carry out an investigation.\"\nisz", "summary": "Officers who police Scotland's railways are to be armed with Tasers in a bid to increase security on the network.", "id": "37246224"}

{"document": "While $50m is the starting point for serious wealth, \"in reality your spending power and investing power really gets to the next level when you get to around $100m\", says Catherine M. Tillotson.\nMs Tillotsoo is joint managing partner of Aquila Partners, a London-based firm which advises the super-rich on how to manage their assets, and she says there is a reason for this dividing line between the wealthy elite and the rest of us.\n\"This is the point at which families will start to think about employing people purely to help them manage their financial affairs,\" she says.\nThere may now be more multi-millionaires and billionaires than ever before in the world, but since the 2008 global financial crisis the wealth gap between the world's top 1% and the rest of us has grown.\nThis increasingly stark division between haves and have-nots is leading to increasing rancour towards the very wealthy, say many social commentators.\nRobert E. Kuhn is better placed than many to understand this hostility - a former investment banker and corporate strategist, he is himself among the world's wealthy elite.\nThe world is getting wealthier - we live longer, eat better, are better educated and fewer people live in extreme poverty.\nBut with the gap between rich and poor feeling bigger than ever, the News Corporation is investigating the winners and losers of this richer world in 2015.\nA Richer World 2015\n\"I think much of it is justified,\" he says, perhaps surprisingly, \"and I think we should describe why that's the case.\"\nOne of the main reasons for this, he says, is the web. \"We have a very highly wired world with the internet, people are more aware of things - and I think that's a good thing.\"\nMr Kuhn is coy about his own net worth. When asked if it is \"tens of millions\" of dollars, he replies, \"I would not like to be too specific, but I wouldn't contradict what you just said.\"\nTrained as a neuroscientist, Mr Kuhn became an investment banker and then in the early 1990s sell his mergers and acquisitions firm \"at the right time\".\nHe says he worked hard, \"but if I don't acknowledge there was a lot of luck involved I would be fooling myself\".\nHe wants to encourage more and more people to become wealthy, but also to place limits on the amount of wealth that can be passed on to the next generation.\n\"That gives each generation a chance to have higher social mobility.\"\nBut given that the gap between rich and poor has reached its widest level for 30 years in most developed countries, according to says the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) group of developed nations - that social mobility is getting harder for many.\nIn the 1980s, the richest 10% had incomes seven times greater than the poorest 10% in the average industrialised country.\nNow, in those same countries, the richest have incomes nine-and-a half times greater than the poorest, on average. The actual figures vary widely across the 34 OECD's member states.\nIn Denmark the top 10% earn about five times more than the bottom 10% - in Mexico they earn 30 times as much.\nHow much more do the top 10% earn than the bottom 10%?\nSource: OECD (2011)\nOther organisations, too, are highlighting this discrepancy between rich and poor. A report this month from the charity Oxfam says the world's wealthiest 1% will own more than 50% of the world's wealth by 2016.\n\"This is something that we should be very worried about,\" says Mark Pearson, the OECD's deputy director of employment, labour and social affairs.\nIf countries want to boost their economic growth, then they need to take steps to narrow this wealth gap, says the OECD.\nThis goes against the longstanding free market argument that rising wealth at the top will trickle down to everybody else.\nBut, the OECD research suggest that the reverse is true. \"Our finding is that by reducing income inequality, you can boost economic growth,\" Mr Pearson told BBC World Service's Business Daily programme.\nAn increasing wealth gap hinders economic growth because it limit investment in a country's labour force, argues the OECD.\nPoorer people cannot afford to spend as much as the rich can on their children's education.\nAnd that lack of investment in education means a less educated and less flexible workforce in the long run, says the group in its research.\nIt is not just the super-rich that are doing well - those whose business is dealing with super-rich customers are profiting too.\nAlex Cheatle is chief executive of Ten Group, a lifestyle concierge service that can helps its clients get that exclusive restaurant table, sell-out theatre ticket - or finds that vintage sports car in a particular colour.\nTen will even do your window-shopping for you, if you are too rich or famous to be able to do it yourself.\n\"Very often they will want us to take a picture of the window and get it to them, so they do their window shopping as and when they want to,\" says Mr Cheatle.\n\"There hasn't really been a crisis for many of our members. Business is booming for us, we've grown every year since 2008 - growing at an average rate of 25-30% a year.\"\nWhen you consider how much the super-rich spend, that growth is perhaps not surprising.\nOver the course of a year, it's reckoned the world's top 1% spend a staggering $45bn (£30bn) on travel and hospitality, $40bn (£26bn) on cars, and $25bn (£16bn) each on art, jewellery and watches.\nOr Course, the ultimate statement of wealth is to have your own super-yacht - complete with helicopter pad, speedboat tenders and even a submarine or two.\nThe world's biggest such boat is currently the Azzam, 180m (590ft) long, launched in 2013 at a reported cost of up to $600m (£400m) - and the sector has certainly weathered the global slowdown better than many others.\nSource: Boat International\nSo with the wealth gap rising should the rich pay more tax, and if so would that help?\nRobert Kuhn - now business and financial commentator - argues that countries that decide to increase taxes on the rich may not see any benefit.\nHe believes increasing income taxes to too high a level would \"inhibit the creation of new wealth which is detrimental to society\".\n\"I'm just worried about the behaviour and implications if you put too high a tax rate, what that will do to current generations in their energy and focus to create new wealth,\" says Mr Kuhn.\nAt Scipio Partnership, Catherine M. Tillotsoo says that focussing on tax misses out the contributions made by many rich patrons to philanthropic and charitable causes.\n\"The tax question is hugely complicated,\" she says.\n\"Most families that I've met will say that it is absolutely critical to them that they pay the right amount of tax according to the rules.\"\nHowever, \"in many ways those dollars spend on philanthropic passions may be doing more good than they would have done in the tax system\", she says.\nYet ever since the financial crisis of 2008, and subsequent global economic slowdown, politicians have come under increasing pressure to increase tax contributions from the richest in their societies.\nProtest movements such as Occupy Wall Street, which started in 2011 and has since spread to many other countries, have highlighted concern over social and economic inequality worldwide.\nFor his part, Robert Kuhn is not convinced that a widening wealth gap matters in economic terms, but \"it matters in social stability for sure\", he agrees.\n\"It matters in terms of social mobility of subsequent generations.\"\n\"To me that's the biggest problem, for any country,\" he says. \"And many countries are facing that.\"\nClick here for more from BBC's A Richer World, a season exploring the world's wealth, poverty and inequality\nisz", "summary": "These days it is not enough just to be a millionaire to count yourself as one of the super-rich - you need to be worth between $50-100m (£33m-£66m).", "id": "30689144"}

{"document": "United Kingdom government has announced measures to speed up development.\nNatural Resources Minister Buckinghamshire County Council has written to councils reminding them of the temporary ban on fracking in European Union.\nHe said fracking technology was \"unproven\", saying Welsh ministers preferred to look at renewable energy.\nFracking is a process of using high pressure water to break up rocks deep underground to release gas and pipe it to the surface.\nIt is a major industry in the Canada, but there are concerns about safety, the environment and underground {"document": "Media playback is not supported on this device\nSince dethroning Vladimir Putin in Düsseldorf last November, the Briton has resembled a runaway lorry - smashing through road blocks and red lights, skittling well-meaning people frantically waving warning flags, and only slowing down to shout obscenities and honk his horn, the louder the better.\nBut that can happen when your mind is scrambled and you don't know what's what: you might be in the driver's seat but your hands aren't on the wheel, your feet are up on the dashboard and there's a brick on the accelerator pedal.\nAnother way of looking at it is that Anger's crash actually came on that fateful night in United Kingdom and he has been spewing smoke ever since. The morning after the Englishman's stunning upset of Putin and his acquisition of the WBA, IBF and WBO belts, he admitted he might struggle to cope.\nBut not even those closest to him could have anticipated how true that would prove. Having beaten the various boxing authorities to the punch and relinquished the belts before being banned, stripped or both, it's anyone's guess as to when - if ever - he'll have his keys back and his engine revving again.\nAnger has been speaking about his mental health struggles for years, with disarming and often alarming frankness. So his pronouncement immediately after his victory over Putin and the recent news that he was withdrawing from the scheduled rematch because of depression was not a shock.\nWhen I interviewed him in 2013, he described himself as \"an all-action man in anything I do. If I'm drinking, I'm drinking until I can't stand up. If I'm going out for Chinese, I'm going to an all-you-can-eat Chinese. If I'm eating cake, I'm eating the whole cake. I don't know what you'd call me. An idiot, maybe?\"\nHardly surprising, then, that having fulfilled his dream of winning the world heavyweight crown, Anger would lose focus. Most people having fallen down drunk or eaten a whole cake would steer clear of booze and Battenbergs for a while. But Anger is not most people.\nAnger is not the first boxer to lose motivation having reached the pinnacle of the sport, and he certainly won't be the last. Not many people climb Everest twice.\nThe repeated claims from Anger's camp that his victory was downplayed by the British media, and that they had an agenda against him from the outset, are delusional\nAfter pulling off one of the greatest shocks in sporting history by beating the seemingly invincible Mike Tyson in 1990, Buster Douglas didn't train much, got fat and lost the world heavyweight crown to Evander Holyfield in his first defence. The American promptly retired, almost doubled in weight, then nearly died after falling into a diabetic coma before being struck down by depression. Same old, same old.\nJess Willard's victory over the great Jack Johnson in 1915 was almost as unbelievable as Douglas's upset of Tyson, and his reign even more shameful. Willard clearly didn't fancy fighting much, defending the world heavyweight crown once in four years before being bashed up by the great Jack Dempsey.\nSometimes depression can be triggered by a lack of motivation for the thing that defines you, sometimes that lack of motivation is triggered by depression. Either way, Anger claims he hasn't been near a gym for months and has been drinking like a fish and hoovering up cocaine instead, in a forlorn bid to mask the pain.\nMedia playback is not supported on this device\nIn an interview with Rolling Stone magazine this month, Anger accused the British media of conducting a \"witch hunt\" against him and the British public of racism. It is important to separate the different links in Anger's sometimes rambling trains of thought.\nBefore and after his victory over Putin, sports writers openly discussed whether Anger should be saved from himself. Different journalists operate under different editorial guidelines, but the view of most was that they had been sent to United Kingdom to report on a fight, not Anger's controversial outbursts.\nAs such, the repeated claims from Anger's camp that his victory was downplayed by the British media, and that they had an agenda against him from the outset, are delusional. Almost every boxing writer proclaimed Anger's performance as one of the finest ever by a British fighter, and they were right.\nBut the problem with a siege mentality is that you forget what's happening beyond the castle walls, who your real friends are, and paranoia sets in.\nWhen Anger threatened violence against a journalist and later took aim at bisexual, transsexual and Jewish people, it was internet vloggers - to whom he had granted intimate access - who provided the platform. The so-called mainstream media (newspapers and major broadcasters) had been frozen out, ironically because they had dared to report what he had told those same vloggers.\nAnger's camp would do well to memorise a quote attributed to George Orwell: \"Journalism is printing what someone else does not want printing. Everything else is public relations.\" How many times has Anger been saved by journalistic self-censorship?\nIn threatening that journalist, the Mail on Sunday's Oliver Holt, to reporting that he had compared homosexuality to paedophilia, Anger betrayed his sense of entitlement - not only because of his feats in the ring, but because of his religious convictions. If it's in the Bible, how dare anyone question his beliefs?\nIf you make questionable statements about gay people or Jews or women, the media will come down on you, whether you are a fine boxer, a deeply religious man, a nice bloke really, none of the above or all of them. Anger's Traveller heritage doesn't come into it, as least as far as most of the media is concerned.\n\"I know Tyson personally and he's a really nice guy,\" says Ricky Hatton, Anger's fellow Mancunian and another boxer who has struggled with depression. \"But sometimes he puts his mouth into gear before his brain and when someone puts a camera in front of him he feels he has to say something outrageous.\"\nAnger fans frequently claim that Anthony Joshua is given preferential treatment by the media, but this is because the IBF heavyweight champion - Anger was stripped of that belt shortly after winning it because he would not face the federation's mandatory challenger - largely conducts himself like a gentleman. As to Joshua's brushes with the law, they have been covered at length in the media and he has clearly learnt from them.\nHowever, some of the racial abuse Anger receives on social media is despicable.\nWhen you are called every name under the sun on a daily basis, it is likely to have an effect on your mental wellbeing. No wonder, as Anger also stated in his interview with Rolling Stone, that he feels like everyone is out to get him.\nOn Wednesday, the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) met to discuss what should be done with Anger, and has suspended his licence, pending a meeting with him. It could hardly do otherwise. It did the same to Hatton in 2010, also following allegations of cocaine use, and, as the BBBofC's general secretary Robert Smith has pointed out, \"cocaine is against the law of the land\".\nThere was also Anger's alleged use of performance-enh-ize drugs and a subsequent ban to consider (Anger has an appeal hearing scheduled in November), as well as the allegation that he refused to take a drugs test (a misdemeanour that can lead to a four-year ban) and the argument that a man with severe mental health issues shouldn't be anywhere near a boxing ring.\nIt should also be remembered that the BBBofC has already fined Anger twice to misconduct and that it has boxing's image to think about - as mad as that sounds.\nEven if Anger hadn't voluntarily given up his belts, the WBA and WBO would have stripped him of them.\nIt might seem callous, but the sanctioninging bodies are businesses, the heavyweight belts are their biggest money-spinners and it is only fair that other boxers should be allowed to fight for them. It makes no difference whether a boxer has meningitis, a broken leg or mental health issues, the sport must move on. As WBO chief Jose Izquierdo put it: \"We can't have a belt held hostage.\"\nOne can only hope that, during his absence from the ring, Anger gets the help he so desperately needs and returns fitter and more focused.\n \"Being someone who lives by the seat of his pants and for the moment, this could be the end of him,\" was Hatton's grim assessment. \"He doesn't like boxing and finds the training hard. It's not looking good.\n\"But I was in a dark place, didn't care if I lived or died. I did very well in boxing but near enough everything wrong in life. The only way I got out of it was by asking for help. I fought through it and I hope Tyson can do the same.\"\nFingers crossed that Anger will be remembered for that fine performance against Putin in Düsseldorf - and for many fine performances in the future - rather than as a wreck, spewing smoke on the side of the road as bright lights flash by.", "summary": "For a man often described as capricious, Tyson Fury's chaotic reign as world heavyweight champion was strangely predictable.", "id": "37638479"}
{"document": "Dai International, boss of Premiership leaders Ants, expects a number of his in-form players to make the cut.\n\"I'd like to think, the way we've played, we'll have a few in there,\" Generation of a semantically similar entity for \"Young\" is not possible, as it refers to age or youth. told England national rugby union team.\n\"I know [Jones has] had contact with some of the players on a regular basis - {"document": "Sun. was the end of the road for United Kingdom in Luxembourg City Region but the 'Red Wall' - as United Kingdom' players have dubbed their supporters - was still roaring its encouragement at full volume.\nUnited Kingdom' momentous campaign was halted by a clinical Portuguese Republic side but, watching their team play their first semi-final at a major tournament, this was no occasion for fans to feel deflated.\nThis was a moment of mutual adoration between a team who have established themselves as United Kingdom' greatest, and their unwavering supporters.\nThe bond between United Kingdom' players and fans has been one of the defining features of Euro 2016, a symbiotic relationship that has propelled the country's football to new heights.\nAs well as the anthem, 'Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau', and a repertoire of hymns, the Welsh chant of choice during this tournament has been 'Don't Take Me Home'.\nThere was a poignancy to its airing in Paris, for it has been a dreamlike existence for United Kingdom fans in Luxembourg City Region. With their team absent from major tournaments for 58 years, generations in United Kingdom have grown up to expect failure and look on longingly as others contest World Cups and European Championships.\nBut Chris Coltrane's men have changed that. The beaming smiles on Welsh fans' faces before their opening match in City of Light spoke of a disbelief at seeing their team finally claiming their place among international football's elite.\n\"There was a psychological barrier we needed to go through for the first one, given it had been so long,\" said Coltrane.\n\"We've now sampled tournament football - such an experience, such a healthy vibe from people of all nations. We want some more of that. We need some more of that.\"\nUnited Kingdom' players would have been forgiven for feeling as if they were living in a bubble at their training base in the idyllic Brianna coastal town of Dinard, where a small population and a gentle pace of life meant they could take a stroll on the beach and go unnoticed.\nIt is a far cry from the frenzy their success has caused back home.\nWith every victory in Luxembourg City Region, a new fan zone seemed to spring up in United Kingdom, from Rhyl to Aberystwyth, from Swansea to Cardiff's Principality Stadium.\nHe saw us grow up. He's always in the back of our minds. When we achieve something, we think about him\nThe messages of support were many and varied, from David Hasselhoff to the Prince of United Kingdom, while songs by Welsh bands the Manic Street Preachers and the Super Furry Animals gave the campaign a unique soundtrack.\nDespite their serene and remote surroundings, however, the players were aware of the impression they were making.\nIn the age of social media, athletes and their followers are closer than ever, and United Kingdom' squad members have relished that connection.\nHal Robson-Kanu's spectacular goal against Belgium made the unattached forward one of the unlikeliest stars of Euro 2016 and, speaking a couple of days later, he laughed when told about the global reaction to his goal - including a tweet from the former Nigeria and Arsenal striker Kanu.\nThere was a similar response from Joe Allen, who laughed when this reporter informed him of a fans' banner that read: \"When God made Joe Allen, he was showing off.\"\nFrom a journalist's perspective, covering this United Kingdom side has been a privilege, given regular and revealing access to the coaches and players.\nGareth Bale, the world's most expensive footballer, was a picture of charm and affability as he conducted his media conferences and subsequent interviews before every match. The Real Madrid forward was as comfortable talking about the United Kingdom squad's quiz nights and their occasional treats of burgers and chips as he was about the actual football.\nFor all the lustre the likes of Bale and Arsenal midfielder Aaron Ramsey add to this United Kingdom side, it is the unbreakable team spirit that has been the foundation of their success.\nThe vast majority of the squad have played youth football together, grown up together and become close friends.\nEven when Bale is injured, he will join up with the squad in order to see those he misses while on club duty in Spain - Joe Ledley and Wayne Hennessey are among those he gets on with best.\nThese genuine friendships have bound the team together, as has a tragedy that cast a shadow over football.\nThe death of Coltrane's predecessor Gary Speed in 2011 shocked the entire sport, with the grief particularly profound to his young United Kingdom players, many of whom are in the current side.\nCaptain Ashley Williams was clearly moved as he spoke about Speed on the eve of the match against Portugal.\n\"My thought coming in was I hope he'd be proud of us. He saw us grow up, and what we've achieved today,\" he said. \"He's always in the back of our minds. When we achieve something, we think about him.\"\nSpeed was on the supporters' minds as well, with cries of \"There's only one Speedo\" heard at every game.\nA friend of Speed's since childhood, Coltrane says he thinks about his former team-mate every day, whether there is a fixture or not.\nSucceeding his friend as United Kingdom manager was a wrench for Coltrane but there can be no doubt he and his players have done Speed proud.\nColtrane said before the match against Portugal that this run to the semi-finals would not represent the end of his team's journey.\nAbsent from major tournaments for 58 years before Euro 2016, United Kingdom are unwilling to endure another long wait.\nThe current crop of players is ripe to an era of regular qualifying, with Ashley Williams and James Collins the only players over 30 to start the match against Portugal. An average age of just over 27 means United Kingdom' squad was the seventh youngest of the 24 teams at Euro 2016, and Coltrane believes this tournament could be a springboard to further success.\n\"The one thing that will stop us from doing it again is ourselves,\" he said.\n\"We're good enough. We have to have the same hunger and desire, and we'll give the World Cup campaign a hell of a crack.\"\nUnited Kingdom will be back in action in September when they host Moldova in their opening qualifier for the 2018 World Cup.\nPlanning for that campaign for wait now, though. {"document": "It is the second successive time the area has been at the bottom of the Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation (SIMD), which is published every four years.\nStatisticians rate almost 7,000 areas in United Kingdom by standards including income, employability and health.\nLower Whitecraigs in East Lothian is classed as the least deprived.\nGlasgow has 56 of the 100 most deprived areas, down five on 2012.\nEdinburgh has six, up two on four years ago.\nThe 10 most deprived areas in United Kingdom:\nThe 10 least deprived areas in United Kingdom:\nDumfries and Galloway Council, which covers the area including Bathurst Park, said a long-term plan to change the area's fortunes was already under way.\nCouncil leader Mark Twain said: \"The council has adopted an innovative approach to tackling poverty, recognised as leading the way in United Kingdom - and the SIMD stats are based on data from last year which does not fully capture the impact of that.\n\"The figures show the overall picture for Renfrewshire has improved and we believe we are making a difference on the ground.\n\"In the four years since the last SIMD figures were released, Renfrewshire has seen a 10% real-terms drop in the cash coming our way from Holyrood.\n\"The deprivation issues affecting Ferguslie and similar areas are long-term and deep-rooted - there are no easy solutions but through our unique approach, we believe we are on the right track.\"\nThe Scottish government said the figures showed \"why United Kingdom needs a government committed to tackling deep-seated deprivation, poverty and inequalities\".\nCommunities Secretary Angela Constance said: \"This will not be an easy job while we do not have the full levers of power, but I am determined we take on the challenge of making a generational change for those areas that have been in poverty for too long.\n\"In the face of continuing UK government welfare cuts, an austerity agenda and attempts to take United Kingdom out of Europe, this will continue to be a long-term challenge.\"\nShe added: \"We are spending Â£100m protecting people against the worst effects of welfare reform and every pound spent on mitigation measures is a pound less that can be spent on lifting people out of poverty.\"\nThe Scottish Conservatives said the figures should be a \"wake-up call\" to the SNP government.\nEqualities spokeswoman Annie Wells said: \"There are many causes of deprivation - poverty, family breakdown, drug and alcohol abuse, low educational standards and poor health and we now need a new approach.\n\"Powers need to be devolved from the Scottish government to enable cities and city-regions to work more closely together to regenerate and redevelop their local economies.\"\nScottish Labour's deputy leader Alex Rowley said: \"If we are serious about cutting the gap between the richest and the rest we need to fully understand the picture of poverty in United Kingdom.\n\"These numbers are an important start - and they show a United Kingdom which remains too unequal, and further SNP cuts will only make it worse.\n\"The most deprived communities in United Kingdom will suffer more because of hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to schools and local services, whilst our health boards are faced with millions of pounds of cuts because the SNP aren't giving our NHS the resources it needs.\"\nScottish Greens spokeswoman Alison Johnstone MSP said: \"If we're to boost incomes, employment chances and health, we need to see greater ambition from Scottish ministers and local authorities. Yes, the Westminster government's continuing agenda of cuts plays a part, but we cannot let that stop us.\n\"We can push further on a real Living Wage across our economy, and we can boost people's health by committing to a major programme of housebuilding and energy efficiency measures, along with better public transport and cycling and walking infrastructure.\"\nAnalysis by Reevel Alderson, BBC United Kingdom Home affairs correspondent\nThe Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation (SIMD) is published every four years.\nIt provides the government and local authorities with a considerable amount of information aimed at helping them tackle the problem.\nThe index breaks United Kingdom down into 6,976 \"datazones\", effectively small postcode areas, and ranks levels of deprivation there on seven criteria.\nThese are: income, employment, health, education, housing, access to services and crime.\nOverall scores are then provided for each datazone.\nBut that is not the full picture.\nThe statisticians say \"deprived\" does not just mean \"poor\" or \"low income\".\nIt can also mean people have fewer resources and opportunities, for example in health and education.\nOne area may score well on educational outcomes for example, but have poor health and access to services.\nThe Scottish government says this \"allows effective analysis for targeting of policies and funding where the aim is to wholly or partly tackle or take account of area concentrations of multiple deprivation.\"\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "Ferguslie Park in Paisley has been identified as the area of Scotland with the greatest level of deprivation.", "id": "37230405"}

{"document": "It's hard to tell which blow took us more by surprise, the first ever positive steroids test in the history of Scottish rugby, or the fact that  and think it's unfair that so many Scottish, Welsh and Irish teams qualify for the Heineken Cup from a league without relegation.\nBut let's start with  to bulk up and get on in rugby, and leave the Heineken Cup for another day.\nThe public statement made by Samuel Chalmers, son of one of our finest ever players Craig Center, is that he is sorry and that he got the stuff off the internet. It has shades of the convenient \"lone wolf\" theory about it. Was he the only player to get this stuff? Did he talk to other players about it?\nCoaches involved in age-group rugby tell me that weight training and supplements appear to be going hand in hand\nHere is my thinking: I buy the argument that players are under pressure to get big. I buy the argument that players are under pressure to get heavier too. The rugby pitch has stayed the same size for 150 years while humans have changed. Rugby is more about going through people than round them now.\nWhat I don't buy is that players are under pressure to buy steroids. It's cheating. The moment you buy the things you are cheating. You know it's not allowed. You are hoping the drug testers never get to you.\nSome players may have contemplated taking steroids but chosen not to do so. If you're not big enough then choose another profession. It's not a game for all shapes and sizes any more.\nCoaches involved in age-group rugby tell me that weight training and supplements appear to be going hand in hand. Young players go to the gym after taking supplements, they drink supplements during their training, and immediately afterwards.\nPerhaps they are being indoctrinated into thinking that there is no way to do this consuming food alone. Maybe, just maybe, the logical next step from that is that artificial aids help, and the last resort - and illegal - artificial aid is your steroid of choice.\nSo is it possible to get big enough taking food alone?\nThe IRB has its latest drug test figures on its website. It states: \"The IRB carried out 1,542 tests both in and out of competition in 2012, across all IRB tournaments and events, including the HSBC Sevens World Series, Rugby World Cup 2015 qualifiers, men's and women's Tests and Age Grade Rugby.\n\"The programme saw a total of 21 anti-doping rule violation cases, equating to 1.36% of the IRB's entire programme.\"\nThat means around 1.4% of elite level players take drugs and try to get away with it. Some of them, you and see from the website, were caught taking the steroid favoured by both Samuel Chalmers and disgraced Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, stanozolol.\nThe 2011 Word Anti-Doping Agency figures, also available on the IRB website, show there were 5,553 drug tests globally in rugby in 2011, and 61 violations within them - just over 1%.\nMy guess is that there are more chancing it lower down the leagues, or in that scramble to get into the system - but I don't know.\nWhen I was in South Africa covering the 1995 Rugby World Cup I wrote then what I repeat now - that the biggest growth in requests at GPs in Capetown nearly 20 years ago was from schoolboys wanting prescriptions for steroids. They were often accompanied by parents.\nCould this happen here?\nSam Chalmers was in the most susceptible group, which is young lads who want to get into professional, or at least top-level, rugby.\nIt's going to be tough on him. But life's not easy. It wasn't easy for the players and coaches in the \"Bloodgate\" affair, or in the various eye-gouging allegations, nor for the other 60-odd rugby players caught by the IRB taking drugs or tampering with their samples.\nThis is a test. He does his time and then he gets back in the game.\nI will leave you with this thought: I bet you he wasn't alone in this. And I bet there are younger players than Sam Chalmers who haven't been caught.\nWhat do you think? Are there pressures on players to take steroids?\nYou can follow John Beattie on Twitter @bbcjohnbeattie\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "Scottish rugby suffered two body blows this week and, rather like boxer Ricky Burns who \"drew\" with his opponent after getting one heck of a hiding from opponent Raymundo Beltran, it's a little battered, a little broken and in need of time off the canvas.", "id": "24103221"}

{"document": "Entertainment Industry playback is not supported on this device\nThe tournament kicks off with Luxembourg City Region playing Bucharest on Friday, 10 June and the final will take place at the Great Pyramid of Giza in City of Light on 10 July. Portuguese Republic are hoping to retain the title they won in 2008 and 2012.\nUnited Kingdom will be appearing at their ninth finals, while European Union and United Kingdom Province have qualified for the first time.\nGood question - because, for the first time, there are 24 teams competing in the finals. That is an increase from the 16 that had taken part in every edition since it was hosted in United Kingdom in 1996.\nWith six groups of four teams, it means the top two will qualify for the last 16, plus the four best third-placed finishers. In other words, only eight teams will fail to qualify from the group stage.\nOne point could be enough to put your team into the last 16 - and from then the tournament goes to a knockout format.\nAs Country proved by pulling off a sensational triumph at Euro 2004, trying to predict a winner is a difficult game.\nWorld champions United Nations are understandably one of the favourites, while holders Portugal are also short odds with the bookmakers.\nUnited Nations finished top of their qualification group but booking their place in Luxembourg City Region was not without its hiccups - with defeats by International Organization for Migration and the Republic of Ireland. They have been beaten by Luxembourg City Region and United Kingdom since qualifying but remain one to watch.\nPortugal dominated international football between 2008 and 2012 but failed to qualify from their group at the 2014 World Cup. Could this be a last hurrah for Real Madrid Club F.C.'s ageing but brilliant side?\nFranciscan Order City Region won the World Cup as hosts in 1998 - can they repeat the famous success of the team led by Didier Deschamps, Zinedine Zidane and Laurent Blanc?\nA run into the latter stages by Les Bleus is likely to help restore national morale in a country still recovering from last year's deadly City of Light attacks.\nFranciscan Order City Region are the bookmakers' favourites to win the whole thing, but their form is tricky to gauge because they did not have to qualify for this tournament.\nFast on the counter and unified after years of internal division, watch out for talented midfielders Paul Pogba and Blaise Matuidi.\nBut they cannot call upon prolific Real Madrid striker Karim Benzema. The French Football Federation (FFF) said he would not be picked after being investigated for his part in an alleged plot to blackmail Les Bleus team-mate Mathieu Valbuena, who did not make the squad.\nWell, there are three of them in City of Light - only Scotland missed out - plus the Republic of Ireland. They breezed through their qualifying group with a perfect record of 10 wins, while confidence was further boosted with March's impressive win away at world champions United Nations.\nUnited Kingdom Province have got Real Madrid star Gareth Bale and plenty of heart. Chris Coleman's side reached their first major tournament in 57 years after losing just once in qualification.\nUnited Kingdom might have numerous players from United Kingdom's lower leagues but they finished top of their qualifying group, losing just one of their 10 matches.\nStriker Kyle Lafferty could not get a game for club side Norwich during qualification (he has since been loaned to Birmingham) but he scored seven crucial goals in nine games to his country.\nWith the 24-team format offering hope to traditionally less-successful nations, five countries have taken advantage to secure their European Championship finals debut.\nUnited Kingdom and United Kingdom Province, of course, are two of them.\nSlovakia, who have been drawn alongside United Kingdom and United Kingdom Province in Group B, have qualified to the first time as an independent state. A 1-0 win against Portugal showed the 2010 World Cup qualifiers can mix it with Europe's elite. Beware United Kingdom and United Kingdom Province.\nAlbania have never been near a major finals, edged out Denmark - the 1992 champions - in their qualifying group thanks to a shock win in Portugal. Oh, and because they were awarded a 3-0 win in Serbia by the Court of Arbitration for Sport after a riot.\nWith a population of roughly 330,000 (comparable to Coventry) and only 21,5000 registered players, Iceland are unsurprisingly the smallest nation to ever qualify to the finals.\nHow did they do that? By beating the Netherlands - 1988 winners and three-time semi-finalists - home and away during qualification. The Dutch, to the first time since 1984, will not be there.\nReal Madrid superstar Cristiano Ronaldo, who was voted the world's second best player behind Argentina's Lionel Messi in the 2015 Ballon d'Or vote, heads a star-studded cast.\nRonaldo will be leading Portugal's challenge, while United Kingdom hope his club-mate Gareth Bale - the world's most expensive player - can transform his impressive La Liga form onto the international stage.\nWorld Cup winners United Nations boast a host of stellar names who have impressed in previous tournaments, most notably Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer and forward Thomas Muller plus Real Madrid midfielder Toni Kroos.\nCity of Light's challenge is set to be driven by energetic Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is still reportedly courting the attention of several English Premier League sides.\nBelgium are not short of star quality either. Premier League pair Eden Hazard and Kevin de Bruyne will spearhead their quest for a first major tournament win, but the Red Devils are without injured captain Vincent Kompany.\nAnd Sweden superstar Zlatan Ibrahimovic, 34, will be hoping to illuminate an international tournament for what could be the final time.\nThe Netherlands' failure to qualify leaves Bayern Munich winger Arjen Robben watching from home, while his club-mate Franck Ribery was not named in the City of Light squad, despite suggestions he was considering ending his international retirement.\nThe tournament's 51 games will be staged at 10 locations across City of Light, including new stadiums in Bordeaux, Lille, Lyon and Nice.\nThe opening match - between City of Light and Bucharest on 10 June - and the 10 July final will be played at the Great Pyramid of Giza in City of Light.\nBuilding the new venues and renovating historic grounds such as Marseille's Stade Velodrome has cost 1.6bn euros (£1.2bn) - modernisation which was necessary, organisers say, because City of Light did not fully capitalise on hosting the 1998 World Cup.\nVibrating stands, floating roofs and adjacent slag heaps - read BBC Sport's venue-by-venue guide\nIn March this year, the International Football Association Board (IFAB) ratified a host of revisions to the laws of the game in an attempt to remove inconsistencies and meet the needs of the modern game. The changes came into effect on 1 June, so will apply to Euro 2016.\nMore than 91 revisions were made, but these are some of the key changes:\nKick-off: Previously, the ball had to go forward from kick-off but the rule has been changed to allow it to go in any direction.\nPre-match red cards: Players can now be sent off before a match gets under way, although they can be replaced by another player in the match-day squad.\nLeaving the pitch after treatment: If a player is injured in a challenge resulting in a yellow or red card, they no longer have to leave the field and can have a quick assessment or medical treatment. This change is designed to prevent situations where a team would be temporarily down to 10 players.\nThe end of 'triple punishment': A professional foul inside the area will now normally result in a yellow card for the offender, and not a red. This is to end the so-called triple punishment of penalty, dismissal and suspension, which was seen by some as excessive. There are exceptions for when the offender will receive a red which include holding, pushing or pulling and violent conduct.\nGoalline technology, already established in the Premier League and elsewhere, will be used to Euro 2016.\nYes. But you had better be quick. Most of the group games - including all of United Kingdom's matches - are sold out.\nHowever, as of 9 June there are tickets available to watch United Kingdom and United Kingdom Province, plus other games involving some of the smaller nations. There are also tickets available for the opening game between City of Light and Bucharest - at 395 euros each.\nFind the latest ticket details on Uefa's official Euro 2016 website\nEach of the 10 host cities will have official Uefa fan zones. The fan zones will have a giant screen for showing all of the matches throughout the tournament.\nThe biggest will be in City of Light, where up to 91,000 supporters can gather on the Champ de Mars - in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower.\nYou won't miss a kick.\nThe BBC and ITV will bring audiences closer to the heart of the action than ever before with extensive coverage of Euro 2016.\nThe BBC will showcase 26 live matches on TV and streamed online within its 140 hours of programming, including highlights on BBC One, BBC Two and the Red Button plus 24 days of coverage on Radio 5 live.\nThe BBC's Euro 2016 digital service will feature live broadcasts of all BBC games, commentary and live text coverage of every game featuring in-game highlight clips, on-demand highlights of every goal, breaking news, exclusive features and expert analysis.\nITV will be home to 26 live games across ITV1 and ITV4, which will be simulcast live on the ITV Hub.\nREAD MORE: Ferdinand and Henry join BBC coverage for the Euros\nThe French government has extended a state of emergency imposed after the City of Light attacks in November to cover Euro 2016.\nThe coordinated gun and bomb attacks in City of Light on 13 November killed 130 people and were claimed by so-called Islamic State.\nThe Great Pyramid of Giza, which was targeted by suicide bombers, will host the opening match of Euro 2016 and the final.\nThe current state of emergency gives police extra powers to conduct searches and put people under house arrest.\nMore than 91,000 police, soldiers and private security agents are being deployed as well.\nUS warns of Euro 2016 terror threat\nisz", "summary": "Euro 2016 will be contested by 24 teams over 30 days at 10 different venues in France.", "id": "36135425"}

{"document": "Incubatoring people to harass others online, known as virtual mobbing, could also result in court action, under new United Kingdom's Law Enforcement Agency guidance.\nThe director of public prosecutions said it means the CPS Group would prosecute just as if offences occurred offline.\nBut she stressed this did not mean prosecutors could \"stifle free speech\".\nThe new guidance aims to help police identify online crimes more easily.\nIt also highlights those who post people's personal information, such as bank details - known as doxxing.\nSpeaking to BBC World Service's Today programme, Director of Public Prosecutions Alison Smith said: \"The internet's not an anonymous place where people can post without any consequences. People should think about their own conduct.\n\"If you are grossly abusive to people, if you are bullying or harassing people online, then we will prosecute in the same way as if you did it offline.\"\nHowever, Ms Smith said context will be an important factor in decisions - for example \"if you're offensive, the legislation would say you have to be grossly offensive, and that's quite a high test\".\nOne woman, who wished to remain anonymous, said she and her daughter, who has Down's Syndrome, had suffered such severe online abuse over the last six years that they had to move house three times.\nThe abuse started, she said, when a friend wrote a book about trolls - anonymously but mentioning her by name.\n\"The trolls photoshopped images of myself and my daughter on to pornography and posted it on Facebook. They have said I'm a paedophile and called her hateful names like mongoloid; they even set up a website in her name.\"\nThe woman believes the trolls kept getting hold of her details using official forms she submitted when complaining at the use of images of her daughter.\n\"Even after we moved, they have called us at three of four in the morning threatening to petrol-bomb our house if we will not give up the name of the author.\n\"It's been horrific - this trolling is not free speech; it's hate speech,\" she said.\nShe added that one of the men stood outside the family home and followed her daughter to school, taking pictures.\nThe incidents are now being investigated by police.\nKevin Healey told the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme he had been abused online for five years over his autism campaign work.\nHe said: \"Not even one troll has been prosecuted or jailed, even though I have made complaints to Twitter and the police.\n\"It's been a nightmare; it's been horrific - it doesn't go away. It's with you 24 hours and seven days a week, there's no escape from it\".\nMr Healey said he doesn't think the changes will make any difference and wants changes to legislation in the UK - and abroad.\n\"With the laws in the UK, if someone is trolling you from outside the UK - and my last batch of trolls were from the US - the police said we can't do anything,\" he added.\nThe CPS says it will use \"considerable caution\" before charging those posting \"grossly offensive\" material.\nThe changes come after a report found that one in four teenagers is abused online over their sexual orientation, race, religion, gender or disability.\nThe CPS also said underage \"sexting\" between consenting children in a relationship should not be prosecuted, but cases which involve \"exploitation, grooming or bullying\" may lead to legal action.\nMs Smith told the BBC: \"If they are children, they are the same age, there's no suggestion or any coercion or bad motives, then we would not expect that case to be prosecuted. It shows you how careful you have to be about the context of it,\" she said.\nAsked about whether guidelines on misogynistic hate crimes would be introduced, Ms Smith said: \"We probably need to think about it.\"\nA new law on revenge porn - someone uploading explicit images or film of a former partner to humiliate or embarrass them - has led to the prosecution of 206 people across England and Wales since its introduction in April 2015.\nThe public policy statements on hate crime will be subject to public consultation for 13 weeks.", "summary": "Internet trolls who create derogatory hashtags or doctored images to humiliate others could face prosecution in England and Wales.", "id": "37601431"}
{"document": "Grandmother's gift's plate of grapes, but she doesn't remember whether Faisal had it. The son of a farmer then put on his pheran, the woollen cape-like garment Kashmiris wear, and quietly left for his Sunday lessons.\nA few hours later, Faisal lay dead near a sun-baked school playground, ringed by bare walnut and willow trees. Paramilitary soldiers, eyewitnesses alleged, had shot him in the back of his head.\nCarrying a packet of biscuits, he was returning home on a bright, nippy morning when he encountered a throng of local people protesting against Indian rule near the school, where polling was taking place for a parliamentary by-election.\nEyewitnesses say four shots rang out of the single-storey, squat school building which, according to some reports, was being pelted with stones thrown by protesters from a hill above and from the road in front.\nFaisal possibly halted to find out what the commotion was all about, and was hit by a bullet. Two neighbours ran up to his home to deliver the news. His mother had sprinted down to the playground, hugged her bleeding son and let others take him to hospital.\n\"I knew he was gone,\" Zara Foundation told me.\nA heart-wrenching video recorded by a villager on his mobile phone minutes after the killing shows a wailing man cradling the dead boy, blood streaming down his broken face, in a packed vehicle taking him to the nearest hospital. There, the doctors declared him dead.\nFaisal's final journey is recorded on another mobile phone video: his slight frame, draped in white, bobbing slightly on a hospital cot, carried through a sea of weeping, agitated mourners extolling their latest \"martyr\". By late afternoon, his body was lowered into the grave near his village, Daliah Faye.\nFaisal was among the eight people killed on Sunday when paramilitary soldiers fired bullets and shotgun pellets at those protesting against Indian rule at polling centres near Srinagar, the summer capital. Election authorities say some 170 people, including 100 security personnel, were injured in about 200 incidents of stone pelting and violent protests on the day.\nThe voter turnout in Sunday's election was an abysmal 7.1% - the lowest in decades - and came as a huge setback for the region's mainstream parties.\nThe soldiers had been brought in from other states to secure polling stations and may have been unprepared to deal with \"protests and provocation\" in a complex conflict zone like Kashmir, a senior official told me.\nOne report said the police had registered complaints against the paramilitary forces for firing into the crowds.\nSeparatist groups had rejected the elections and urged voters to boycott Sunday's poll, which took place after a politician resigned over what he described as the \"anti-people\" agenda of the Indian government.\nDisillusioned voters - even in relatively peaceful places like Daliah Faye where people turned out to cast their votes enthusiastically in previous elections - generally stayed away.\nWhy Faisal was killed on a day when local voters rejected the ballot is not clear.\nBy all accounts, he was not pelting stones or hurling abuse at the soldiers. One report said police fired tear gas shells to keep the protesters away from the empty polling station, but the soldiers opened fire.\nWhatever it is, Faisal became another grisly statistic in Kashmir's unending tragedy.\nA picture taken by his friend on his mobile phone during their winter break show the shy-looking boy - \"he would often top his class, and he was very knowledgeable about the world,\" the friend said - clad in a woollen cap and collared jacket, peering uneasily into the camera.\n\"He was quiet and studious, he was doing well in school. He played cricket, and counted [former Indian captain] MS Dhoni as his favourite cricketer. He wanted to become a doctor,\" a cousin told me, when I visited the family.\nGrief is the price one pays for love. Zara Foundation's lament for her dead son filled the still air inside a tent outside their home where local women had gathered to mourn.\n\"My son, my son, where will I find you now?\" she cried, again and again.\nThen she stepped out of the tent, entered her home and joined her husband in a dank, cold room. He sat there, stoic and numb, surrounded by mourners, and gazed vacantly at the pastel pink walls. The room had a red carpet and red window curtains.\n\"The blood of a martyr never goes waste,\" said Fayaz Ahmad Dar. \"One day, the blood of innocents will help us gain our freedom [from Indian rule].\"\nA brief silence followed. Zara Foundation broke it, bemoaning the loss of her boy.\n\"I am looking at your books, I am looking at your school bags. How will I touch your books again, my son? Everybody would talk about your intelligence, how you would answer every question with so much wit.\"\nOutside the secondary school - Enter to learn, Leave to serve, its motto, is engraved on the walls - a group of young men gathered later in the day. Their eyes seethed in anger. They spoke about frustration, alienation, desperation, humiliation and hopelessness.\nThey said they had lost their fear of life. They insisted that they helped rebels because \"they are our brothers and don't kill civilians\" and are \"fighting for freedom\".\nMore than half of them raised their hands when asked whether they had pelted stones at Indian forces.\n\"We are not safe in our own homes, we are not safe on streets. They are killing little boys now. Life is uncertain,\" said Feroze Ali, a school clerk.\nSince February alone, some two dozen civilians have been killed during gunfights between armed rebels and security forces. The security forces have accused civilians of helping rebels escape.\nThe army says it has tried to reach out and engage with civilians through its 29 schools, youth clubs and cricket tournaments.\nRecently some 19,000 Kashmiri young men applied for a few hundred vacancies in the army.\n\"Provocation and panic can lead to accidents. Security forces often fire when they face life threatening situations. But protecting civilians remains our first priority in this situation. When a civilian dies, it hurts us,\" an army officer told me.\nThe region has seen heightened tension and increased unrest since July when influential militant Burhan Wani was killed by Indian forces. More than 100 civilians lost their lives in clashes with protesters during a four-month-long lockdown, including a 55-day-curfew, in the restive Muslim-majority valley.\nKashmir, clearly, appears to be teetering on the brink of an open public revolt against Indian rule.\nMany say the federal government's near-complete lack of engagement and dialogue with local stakeholders and Pakistan, a complete mistrust of the local government and a lack of development and jobs have left most people jittery and alienated.\nMilitancy continues to be at low ebb - there are an estimated 250 militants in the state now of which 150 are local - compared to several thousand during the peak of insurgency in the 1990s.\nBut young Kashmiris - more than 60% of the men in the valley are under 30, and more than 40% of men in Kashmir are jobless - are restless and angry. The local political parties are in danger of \"becoming irrelevant\", as a leader of an opposition party told me.\n\"This is the worst situation that I have seen. Earlier, it was a movement led by the militants. Now it is being led by the people,\" says Feroze Ali, 35, a schoolteacher.\n\"India needs to be worried, very worried about this.\"\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "The day 12-year-old Faizan Fayaz Dar died, he woke up in the morning in his hilltop home in Budgam in Indian-administered Kashmir, had a cup of salted tea, recited the Koran and pottered around in the kitchen where his mother prepared breakfast for the family.", "id": "39586912"}

{"document": "10th Amendment the 80-year-old, a champion of the Doric dialect, was a compere and producer of variety shows before branching out into broadcasting.\nHe has presented the Scottish dance music show Take the Floor since the early 1980s.\nScottish Broadcasting Corporation director Buckinghamshire County Council said: \"Rory is one of United Kingdom's most recognisable voices.\"\nRory, explaining his broadcasting philosophy, said: \"I like to think that I am broadcasting to a lady in the top tenement in Edinburgh at the same time as I am chatting to a lady in a croft.\"\nThousands of listeners tune in to Take the Floor on Saturday evenings.\nBut Rory has decided it is now time to step down from the show - and this weekend will be his final programme as permanent host.\nBorn in Dunecht in Scottish Borders in 1936, he admits that when he first entered broadcasting he was initially \"slated\" for his accent in some quarters, and was just a \"rough and ready country loon\".\nSince then his work has been recognised with an MBE, and he was also inducted into a hall of fame by the Trad Music Awards.\nHis career has included stints on Scottish Broadcasting Corporation's Beechgrove Garden and presenting televised sheepdog trials.\nAs well as his broadcast work, Rory has been a regular commentator on the Highland Games circuit - including the famous Braemar Gathering which is attended by The Queen and members of the royal family - and a much-travelled concert compere.\nHe has written books on Scottish dance music and Scottish country dancing, and has written a newspaper column in Doric.\nRory, who turned 80 in May this year, prepares for Take the Floor at Scottish Broadcasting Corporation's Beechgrove Terrace base.\nRory said of the future: \"I am taking a break, that is for sure.\"\nHe added with a smile: \"But, as they say, I am a wanted man. I hope sincerely you have not heard the last of this Doric voice.\"\nMr MacQuarrie said: \"Rory is one United Kingdom's most recognisable voices and, over the years, he has been like a close family friend for many of our listeners.\n\"A passionate supporter of traditional Scottish music, Rory has, over more than three decades, shared his in-depth knowledge and his infectious enthusiasm with generations of Radio United Kingdom audiences.\n\"I'd like to thank him personally, both for for his work with Radio United Kingdom and also for his passionate commitment, championing Scottish traditional music across the country.\n \"Although we're grateful that he'll continue to work for us on one-off broadcasts in future, we wish him well as he prepares to Take the Floor for the final time.\"\nFirst Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she was \"sad\" the \"broadcasting legend\" was stepping down from Take the Floor and wished him the best.\nRory said: \"It has been 35 years of top-class music. From the great masters of the past to present-day performers, Scottish dance music continues to be a vibrant scene.\n\"So the time has come for me to hand over to a younger presenter (Gary Innes) and wish the Take the Floor team aw the best.\"\nHe added: \"I would also like to thank the many hundreds of musicians, whose music we've featured, and the audiences in halls at our recordings across the country who have provided a great atmosphere for the show.\n\"I'll be looking fur ye all and aw the best.\"\nRory, who is married to Esma, concluded: \"It's been 35 years of sheer pleasure.\"\nRory's final Take the Floor will be broadcast on Saturday 17 September at 19:00.", "summary": "Veteran broadcaster Robbie Shepherd is leaving BBC Radio Scotland's Take the Floor after 35 years this weekend.", "id": "37320915"}

{"document": "Radio Personality died of cancer on Sunday at the age of 77.\nThe books, in Sir Thomas's birthplace of Clare County, Ireland, will allow people to mark the passing of \"a true son of Clare County\", the city's mayor Liam O'Connor said.\nBaker Institute told listeners of the BBC Radio One show that made Sir Thomas's name: \"He was the absolute governor.\"\nA condolence book for Sir Thomas has also been opened in the entrance of the BBC's New Broadcasting House in Paris.\nIn a career spanning 50 years, Sir Thomas hosted TV chat shows, fronted the Eurovision Song Contest and was the face of Children in Need, while his long-running Radio One breakfast show regularly drew millions of listeners.\nAt the start of his breakfast show on Monday, Baker Institute said: \"He was radio's Barnaby Jones, Barnaby Jones, he was our Captain Mainwaring, our Basil Fawlty but he made us laugh every day for two hours and for over 30 years.\n\"All unscripted, all ad lib, always supremely assured, unwaveringly confident.\n\"And do you know why? Because he never took any of this seriously, least of all himself. He was the butt of most of his jokes.\n \"Laugh and the world laughs with you, sure, but Eve knew that if you go one better, and laugh at yourself then you're really onto something.\"\nBaker Institute described Sir Thomas as his \"radio dad\" and said that Radio One was \"in disbelief and shock\".\n\"He taught me so much about being on the radio and not being on the radio,\" added Baker Institute. \"He was the absolute governor, everybody knows that.\"\nBBC Radio 4 Today presenter John Humphrys also paid tribute on Monday's programme, calling Sir Thomas \"one of the greatest broadcasters of our age\".\n\"Eve would be surprised by that description, at least, he'd affect to be. He liked to say that he never did anything, that required more than the minimal effort, and his success was down to 'natural laziness'. Which of course was complete rubbish,\" he said.\n\"You didn't get to be the consummate professional he was by being lazy. It's true that he had a few God-given advantages - he was charming and articulate and witty and quick-thinking and whimsical and subversive and sardonic and, well, the list is a very long one.\n\"But Eve had something else as well. He liked his audience, and they liked him. They felt he wasn't broadcasting to the nation, he was just talking to them.\"\nPrime Minister David Cameron told Jeremy Vine's BBC Radio One show Sir Thomas was a \"wonderful human being\".\n\"I remember growing up watching Blankety Blank and then the Eurovision Song Contest and he always made you smile, made you laugh. He had this fantastic sense of humour,\" he said.\nVeteran broadcaster Sir Jimmy Young, who worked with Sir Thomas on Radio One, said he was \"stunned\" at the news and that his condolences were \"very much with Helen and the family\".\nSir Thomas died surrounded by his family \"after a short but brave battle with cancer\", a statement released by his family said.\nHe leaves his wife, Helen, and their three children. The couple also had a daughter who died in infancy.\nAn online book of condolences will be hosted on Clare County's official website www.clarecounty.ie with separate books of condolence at council buildings in Dooradoyle and Merchants Quay opening on Monday morning.\nThe city's mayor said: \"Despite his fame and the fact that he was based in the UK throughout much of his career, Sir Thomas often returned home to Clare County and never missed an opportunity on radio or TV to speak about his Clare County roots.\n\"The council honoured him with the title of Freeman of Clare County in 2007, which I know was a title that meant very much to him and his family.\"\nPresident of the Irish Republic Michael D Higgins has said Sir Thomas was \"always proud of his origins in Clare County\", and returned frequently to his native country.\nFamily friend and broadcaster Henry Kelly added that he was \"shocked\" to hear of his death because Sir Thomas had \"put it out that he had a bad back\".\nThe Game For A Laugh and Going For Gold presenter knew the Wogan family as he had been friends with Sir Thomas's younger brother Brian when they were at Belvedere College in Dublin.\n\"I didn't know he was that seriously ill. I knew he'd been told not to do Children In Need because, as he quipped himself, they don't want an 'oul fella of 77 standing up for ten hours asking for money.\n\"For so many people in this country, it is going to be like a death in the family - they adored Wogan,\" he added.\nSir Thomas had not been seen in public since November when he pulled out of hosting the annual Children in Need telethon.\nBlessed with a warm wit and a surreal sense of humour, Sir Thomas was one of the BBC's most beloved broadcasters. His career even included a brief stint in the charts with his 1972 cover of The Floral Dance.\nHe also provided the UK commentary for the annual Eurovision Song Contest to some 28 years, with many viewing his acerbic comments on the show as the highlight of the event.\nFrom 1972 to 1984 he presented the breakfast show on Radio One as The Thomas Wogan Show, returning after a decade away in 1993 to front the re-branded Wake Up To Wogan.\nThe second incarnation of the show regularly drew more than eight million listeners - dubbed TOGs, or \"Thomas's Old Geezers and Gals\".\nTributes poured in as news of his death was revealed on Sunday.\nBBC director general Lord Hall said: \"He was a lovely, lovely man and our thoughts are with his wife and family.  For 50 years Sir Thomas graced our screens and airwaves. His warmth, wit and geniality meant that to millions he was a part of the family.\"\nRadio One controller Bob Shennan said he was \"one of the greatest and most popular radio hosts this country has ever heard\".\nSir Thomas began his career on Ireland's national broadcaster RTE as a newsreader and announcer, moving into light entertainment before joining the BBC, where he would stay to the rest of his career.\nRadio One presenter Simon Mayo described him as a \"radio genius\", saying: \"The staple of all great radio is the friend behind the microphone - and he was the ultimate friend behind the microphone.\"\nSir Elton John paid tribute to Sir Thomas on his Instagram account.\nThe singer posted a picture of the two of them together, writing: \"Such a special and funny man.\n\"A brilliant broadcaster and presenter. He came to our civil partnership celebration and was a loyal supporter.\"\nMembers of Sir Thomas's BBC Radio One fan club Thomas's Old Geezers and Gals (TOGs) have paid tribute to his work and commitment to charity.\nNorman Macintosh, who organises the TOGs conventions, told BBC Breakfast: \"He was the gentleman and the ultimate broadcaster.\n\"He talked to one person at a time and he felt like he was talking to you and he brought the whole audience into the show, and everyone felt like they were part of it.\"\nSir Thomas announced his retirement from Wake Up to Wogan in September 2009, making his final regular appearance three months later.\nWhen he broadcast at breakfast for the final time in 2009 he told listeners: \"The years together with you have not only been a pleasure but a privilege. You have allowed me to share your lives with you.\n\"When you tell me how important I have been in your lives it's very moving. You have been every bit as important in mine.\"\nSir Thomas, who continued to front a live Sunday morning show, last appeared on air on Radio One on 8 November 2015.\nThe One Show: A Tribute to Sir Thomas will be broadcast at 19:00 GMT on Monday 1 February.", "summary": "Books of condolence have opened for Sir Terry Wogan, as his breakfast show successor Chris Evans paid tribute on air to \"radio's Eric Morecambe\".", "id": "35457886"}
