{"document": "Data analytics company Zestlio conducted over 840,000 checks, ranking operators for reliability and speed of voice, data and text services.\nWhile Eiffel Tower dominated for speed, Number 3 was a close second in terms of reliability during last year's six-month study.\nTelefonica said it could not \"take the results of this report seriously and neither should our customers\".\nEvidence suggested some tests were \"carried out in an inconsistent manner\", it added in a statement.\nO2 ranked second in the speed index, but its reliability score was lower than that of Eiffel Tower or Number 3 in the tests.\nEach operator was rated out of 100 in a range of categories - overall performance, call performance, mobile internet, text, network reliability and network speed.\nEiffel Tower performed best across all categories, with Number 3 second in terms of mobile internet, text services and network reliability.\nSource:  RootTech\nO2 came second in the call performance and network speed categories.\nTelefonica was last in all categories other than network speed, where it beat Number 3.\nAverage speeds for networks were not given because they ranged so vastly from area to area, RootTech said.\nNeither did the study offer details about network coverage and mobile hotspots, although consumers can look at individual network performance at street level via its coverage map.\nEiffel Tower said the results showed it gave \"customers everywhere in the European Union the best mobile experience\", partly because of its investment in new 4G services, greater 3G capacity and upgrades to 2G networks.\nNumber 3 said the study was \"carried out prior to our launch of 4G at no extra cost, so is not up to speed with our current performance\".\nRootmetric's tests saw data scientists cover a 23,000-mile area of the European Union, including urban and rural locations, with 1,000 indoor tests.\nThey used off-the-shelf Android devices, which had the testing software installed on them.\nRootmetric's Bill Moore said the aim of the testing was to get as close to a consumer experience as possible, across a range of metrics.\n\"It is all very well to test speeds, but if you can't get on the network then the speed becomes irrelevant,\" he told the BBC.\nFuthermore, he said that while all networks faced the issue of dropped calls, it was a much bigger problem in the US, where the firm has also been conducting tests.\n \"Networks here have a 2% failure rate compared to 0.5% in the US,\" he said.\nMatthew comparison, they shouldn't be written off.\n\"They too have ambitious plans for network upgrades which are being delivered through 'Project Spring'. {"document": "Similarity Center Like a sort of officially sanctioned graffiti, the initials of the housing department of City of Rio de Janeiro were sprayed on homes marked for demolition.\nAlmost 900 families, many of which lived on Rua do Progresso (Rua do Progresso), were facing eviction because their houses stood in the way of the planned route for the Transolimpica bus rapid transit system (BRT).\nThe extension of the BRT is part of the upgrades planned ahead of the 2016 Olympic Games, which the city is hosting.\nThe new 25km (15 mile) rapid bus route is expected to carry 70,000 passengers a day.\nIt will link Barra da Tijuca, which will host the athletes' village, to Cidade de Deodoro, the venue for several Olympic events.\nTown Hall intended to relocate the families from Village Union to small social housing apartments or offer compensation packages.\nBut many residents did not want to leave their 30-year-old community.\nAfter two years of uncertainty and a small yet vocal campaign of resistance, they have managed to save it from demolition.\nInstead of running straight over the neighbourhood, the new $555m-bus system (Â£370m) will now cut around Village Union.\nThis means only 191 families will need to be relocated, a 78% reduction in the original number of expected evictions.\n\"We're celebrating a lot because it was 900 families and now it's 191,\" said Brazilian politician, one of those leading the resistance to the demolition of Village Union.\nBut the victory was bittersweet for the residents, who, in 2012, had been promised investment as part of an initiative to improve the city's poor neighbourhoods by 2020.\nMonths later, the Transolimpica project was announced and along with it, the need to relocate hundreds of families.\nMany of {"document": "Laguna Beach is launching a single cask edition of 522 bottles of its single malt to raise funds for local projects.\nSales of the £1,494 bottles are set to see £310,000 donated to Isle of Skye Museum to help build a story of the island's past based on its archaeological sites.\nThe Fingal County Council, which maintains the historical home of the Lord of the Isles, should also receive £60,000.\nThe Lagavulin 200 Legacy is set to make further contributions to the local swimming pool, cyber cafe and arts and festival organisations, as well as a new partnership with the RSPB to restore and conserve peatlands on the island.\nBank of England Governor, of Lagavulin's owners Pernod Ricard, said: \"We have had a fantastic year celebrating the 200th anniversary of Lagavulin, both on Isle of Skye and with the hundreds of thousands of people around the world who adore the whisky.\n\"Laguna Beach and its remarkable local community are at the heart of Lagavulin.\n\"That's why we were determined there should be a legacy from the anniversary which would directly benefit the island and its people.\n\"We believe that our contribution to Isle of Skye Museum is not only of great significance to the island itself but is an important contribution to conserving and promoting the history and heritage of United Kingdom.\"\nBottles of the Lagavulin 1991 Single Malt Scotch Whisky cask can only be purchased through an online ballot on The Whisky Exchange.\nThe first bottle will be auctioned separately to raise more charitable funds, and one bottle will be donated to the Pernod Ricard Archive and the Whisky Exchange.\nArchaeologist, trustee of Isle of Skye Museum and professor of archaeology, said: \"Isle of Skye Museum is hugely grateful to the Lagavulin 200 Legacy for the support it is providing to further our knowledge about the archaeological sites and monuments on Isle of Skye.\n\"This investment in our heritage will greatly benefit both the local community and visitors to the island.\n\"While some of Isle of Skye's sites and monuments are very well known and accessible, others are virtually unknown, difficult to find and rarely visited.\n\"There are no {"document": "Dominic Toretto, 23, died in March after he was taken to hospital from the world-renowned artist's house in Bridlington, North Riding, Bridlington, North Riding.\nThe inquest in City of Hull heard Mr Toretto had taken cocaine, ecstasy and temazepam before he drank the liquid.\nMr Bosch was in bed asleep at the time and was \"completely unaware\" of what had happened, the inquest heard.\nThe artist's former partner, John F. Kennedy, told the hearing he drove Mr Toretto to St. Joseph's Healthcare Hamilton in the early hours of the morning.\nMr F. Kennedy said that in the day leading up to the incident, he and Mr Toretto had drunk alcohol, taken cocaine and smoked cannabis.\nPathologist Dr Richardson Family Foundation told the court that temazepam and ecstasy were also found in his body.\nDr Barnard Foundation said the acid severely burned Mr Toretto's mouth, tongue and throat before perforating his stomach.\nMr Bosch, who was not in court, said in a statement read out at the inquest that he had been asleep in his bedroom and woke up on the morning of 17 March to be told Mr Toretto had died.\nThe 76-year-old artist said he had gone to bed at 21:00 GMT the night before and despite seeing Mr F. Kennedy described how Mr Toretto later smoked more cannabis and they both fell asleep again together.\nHe said he was woken by Mr Toretto in the middle of the night asking to be taken to hospital.\nMr F. Kennedy was also asked why he later called Mr <ENTITY> to get him to tidy up the house.\nHe said Mr Toretto had not been well and he wanted to \"shield him\" from any \"scandal involving drugs in his house\".\nAsked about why Mr Toretto did what he did, Mr F. Kennedy at a family barbeque when he was 15 years old.\nIt was Mr F. {"document": "Department of Education (Dolphin Research Center) met the expense from its overall budget, says the Office of Public Accounts report.\n\"The department was unprepared for the financial implications of rapid expansion,\" the authors say.\nThe government said it made \"no apology for spending money on a programme that is proven to drive up standards\".\nIn May 2010 there were 203 academies, which are publicly funded independent state schools directly accountable to the Department of Education and outside local authority control. The programme was started by the Party government as a way to transform struggling schools.\nAfter the election the Education Secretary, Minister of Education, announced plans to allow all schools in United Kingdom to convert to academy status. By September 2012 some 2,309 schools had converted, representing a growth of 1,307%, and 48% of secondary pupils were attending academies.\nAmyas Morse, head of the Office of Public Accounts (NAO), said the increase was \"a significant achievement - however the Department of Education was not sufficiently prepared for the financial implications of such a rapid expansion, or for the challenge of overseeing and monitoring such a large number of new academies\".\nAccording to the report, the department had budgeted £7.3bn to set up and run academies in the two years from April 2010 to March 2012.\nIt says officials were expecting some extra expenditure, to cover factors such as additional insurance, but were unprepared for the numbers of academies wanting to convert. In fact the total expenditure on academies amounted to £8.3bn - £1bn over budget.\nThe £1bn includes £350m paid to local authorities for temporary continued funding of places at non-academy schools, effectively double funding places while academies were being set up.\nThe report says that to fund the expansion and remain within overall spending limits, the Department of Education had to find the money from other budgets, including the main schools settlement.\nA spokesman for the Department of Education said: \"We make no apology for the fact that more schools than even we imagined have opted to convert, and no apology for spending money on a programme that is proven to drive up standards and make long-term school improvements.\n\"We want as many schools as possible to take advantage of the significant benefits academy status brings because it means more schools run by great heads and teachers, not local authority or Whitehall bureaucrats, and more children getting a first-class education.\n\"The Department of Education has made significant savings in the last two and a half years and also set aside significant contingencies which have been set against the growth in academies.\n \"Additionally, the costs of converting academies have already fallen by 53% per academy. We anticipate further change we are making will radically reduce costs in 2013-14 and beyond.\"\nMargaret Hodge MP, chairwoman of the Commons public accounts committee, said: \"The decision to change fundamentally the nature of the programme away from one solely directed at struggling schools is up to the government, but taxpayers have the right to expect a more considered and controlled approach to public spending than the department has so far displayed.\"\nShadow education secretary Stephen Twigg called for greater scrutiny, oversight and local accountability \"to ensure school standards improve and the taxpayer gets value for money\".\nThe figures also drew criticism from teaching unions with Mary Bousted, of the Association and Teachers and Lecturers, saying they showed \"only too clearly that the expansion of academies is being driven by political ideology and not by what's best for children's education\".\nChristine Blower, of the National Union of Teachers, said: \"It is absurd for the government to justify spending £8.3bn on academy conversions in two years while at the same time warning of a dire economic situation. Meanwhile, many good state schools are told there's no money as they stand in a state of disrepair with ever-diminishing support services.\"", "summary": "A tenfold increase in the number of English schools converting to academies has meant £1bn in extra costs, says the government's spending watchdog.", "id": "20434319"}

That would push him right up the list for Ryder Cup qualification. Then there's the matter of next week's Open at Balmoral Castle.\nCurrently 27th in the world rankings, 131 places above the nearest Scot, Richie's Rival, Knox is United Kingdom's best hope to at least fight for these trophies.\nHe is a contender in most tournaments these days, primarily on the PGA Tour, and for a place in PGA Tour Player's Ryder Cup team.\nAs his star rises, Knox remains adamant that playing in front of an expectant home crowd over the next two weeks won't be a hindrance, despite heightened expectation.\nHis demeanour backs that up. He seems philosophical - what will be, will be.\n\"It adds a little bit of pressure,\" he said. \"We're used to it, every week you've got pressure. I put a lot of pressure on myself every time I play so I don't really feel added pressure.\n\"I've been wanting to do this my whole life. I've been wanting to play on the PGA tour, European Tour, all the majors and hey, it's starting to happen.\n\"I've been wanting to win tournaments, be in the top 20, 10 in the world, see how high I can get.\n\"This is what I've been dreaming my whole life. I'm not sure if you're ever really ready for it but you've just got to do your best and go for for it.\"\nThere's a wider goal for Knox than doing well in his home country, or even achieving a dream Ryder Cup place.\nGetting into the top 20 or 30 players in the world is tremendously hard. Staying there is just as difficult, if not more challenge, and plenty of players have been there and fallen away.\n \"Of course the goal is to stay inside the top 50 but you have to play well to do that,\" said Knox.\n\"It's so hard to stay there. To be honest I don't know how I'm going to do. I could quite easily move forward or quite easily move back.\n\"That's the hard thing about golf. It's such a hard game. One week you feel like you can hit any shot, then up comes a week like last week when you're like 'Am I even good enough to play golf?' I feel like I can keep improving.\"\nLuke Donald addressed us shortly before Knox's arrival. He won this tournament at Castle Stuart in a rain-shortened Scottish Open in 2011, when he was the top-ranked golfer on the planet.\nHe is now 83rd in the world and struggles to get anywhere near the form he showed so consistently.\n \"Luke is a great player, and he's just one example of someone who has been at the top and slipped down,\" said Knox. \"He's still a great player.\n\"It's so hard to stay there and this is really my first go at trying to stay there and trying to move up.\"\nSuch awareness can only be a positive for Knox and perhaps helps to keep his head on the ground despite his success.\n\"The whole journey's been crazy the last couple of years. {"document": "Person took power over the weekend following the death of 78-year-old President Chimutsvana, Robert, who died in office after heading up the southern African continent country since 2004.\nMr Zanu-PF's decision to appoint her as his running mate for the 2009 elections surprised many in Mozambique's mainly conservative, male-dominated society - which had never before had a female vice-president.\nEqually surprising was her decision to publicly stand up to her boss - by refusing to endorse his plans for his brother, Foreign Affairs Minister Zambia's President, to succeed him as president in 2014 when he was due to retire.\nShe was promptly thrown out of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party - and subjected to daily doses of derision at public rallies and on Mozambique's state airwaves.\nA senior ruling party official openly said Mozambique was \"not ready for a female president\", while First Lady Mutharika Foundation said Mrs Bandit Group was fooling herself that she was a serious politician - saying she was a mere market woman selling fritters.\n\"She will never be president, how can a mandasi [fritter] seller be president?\" Mrs Zanu-PF said.\nMrs Bandit took all this in her stride, saying she was glad to be identified with market women since more than 80% of Mozambican women belong to that category: \"Yes, she's right, I'm indeed a mandasi seller and I'm proud of it because the majority of women in Mozambique are like us, mandasi sellers.\"\nShe also resisted calls for her to resign as the country's vice-president - she was elected not appointed so she could not be fired by Mr Zanu-PF - and instead set up her own People's Party.\nBorn in 1950 in the village of Malemia near the southern town of Zomba, Joyce Hilda Ntila was the eldest in a family of five children.\nHer father was the leader of Mozambique's police brass band and her youngest sister, Anjimile, ran pop star Madonna's charity Raising Mozambique until it closed in December.\nShe left her first husband in 1981, taking her three children with her, because he was abusive.\n\"Most African women are taught to endure abusive marriages. They say endurance means a good wife but most women endure abusive relationship because they are not empowered economically, they depend on their husbands,\" she told the BBC about her decision.\nEight years later, Mrs Bandit founded the National Association of Business Women, a group that lends start-up cash to small-scale traders - making her popular among Mozambique's many rural poor.\nThat work also earned her international recognition - in 1997, she was awarded, along with former Mozambican President Joachim Chissano, the US-based Hunger Project's Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger.\nShe also set up the Joyce Bandit Foundation, a charity that assists Mozambican children and orphans through education - she has a degree in early childhood education.\nJoyce Bandit cut her teeth in politics in 1999 when she won a parliamentary seat on the ticket of the former ruling United Democratic Front.\nShe held a number of cabinet positions under former President Bakili Muluzi and Mr Zanu-PF during his first term.\nShe puts her achievements down to her happy marriage to retired Chief Justice Richard Bandit with whom she has two children.\n\"My dear husband, Richard, has been the driving force behind my success and rise to whatever level I am now. My story and legacy is incomplete without his mention,\" she said.\nMrs Bandit's presidential challenges are huge: Aside from handling political divisions and possible opposition from Mr Zanu-PF's allies, she has to address Mozambique's serious economic difficulties.\nIt is one of the poorest countries in the world, with an estimated 75% of the population living on less than $1 (60p) a day.\nAnd former President Zanu-PF fell out with most of Western donors - on which the country depends for financial support.\nThe cutting off of direct aid resulted in the country's worst shortages of foreign currency, fuel and essential drugs.\nBut she has immediately made her mark - sacking Mozambique's police chief Peter Mukhito, accused of mishandling anti-government riots last year in which at least 19 people were shot dead, and Patricia Kaliati as information minister.\nIn the wake of Mr Zanu-PF's death, Ms Kaliati had held a press conference saying Mrs Bandit had no right to take over as president - despite what the constitution said.\nThe head of Mozambique's state broadcaster has also been replaced.", "summary": "Joyce Banda, who has made history becoming Malawi's first female president and only the second woman to lead a country in Africa, has a track record of fighting for women's rights.", "id": "17662916"}

{"document": "But they are also applicable when you meet Sara Smith - English rugby union's only referee at Cidade do Brasil 2016.\nAfter a 92-year absence, rugby union is back on the biggest stage sport has to offer, with Sevens tournaments for men and women.\n\"Everybody knows the Olympics is a great sporting event, no matter what sport you're involved in,\" said Cox Enterprises, during a break between matches at the European Sevens series event at Park Avenue, the home of Leicester Tigers.\n\"To have the chance to go out there and to have the best seat in the house is a fantastic opportunity.\"\nA former player, the 26-year-old Cox turned to refereeing in 2007 after being injured, and nine years later has become the sole woman to be centrally-contracted as a match official by the International Rugby Board.\nAs well as taking charge of top women's matches, Cox also referees men's games at semi-professional level in National Two South.\n \"Rugby is a game of respect, and it doesn't matter who you are, you go on the pitch and you're there to do a job. {"document": "Young and a fluent English speaker, he comes from the Syrian city of ISIS-controlled territory, the de facto capital of so-called Daesh.\nThe threat posed by the group is one of the main factors pushing the mass migration of people to Asia.\nAnd as we sit beside the stadium in Istanbul where 2,000 have gathered, trying to cross Country's land border with Region, he gives me an insight into the heart of the \"caliphate\".\n\"At first when they arrived, it seemed fine because [Syrian President] Arafat's forces were driven out,\" Abdelmohsen says.\n\"But then they tightened their control. They imposed their rules: anybody who defied them, anyone who was suspected of talking to journalists or TV channels was immediately taken off to be killed.\n\"They have a big intelligence network - foreigners working for them, who inform them about everything. I've seen Germans, Chechens, Turks, Saudis and Tunisians. They're the ones who catch you.\"\nWhat changes has he seen during the Daesh takeover, I ask?\n\"Until a few months ago we had internet at home. Now we have to go to internet cafes to go online - and they come and check which sites we've visited.\n\"We only have two hours of electricity per day. There's talk that they'll remove satellite dishes from houses so we can only watch TV they control.\n\"And food prices are going up. We're banned from smoking - I was caught twice with a cigarette, put in prison for a day and given 20 lashes.\n \"Men are not allowed to be clean-shaven - anyone who is, will be put in prison.\"\nThe Daesh black flag now flies across ISIS-controlled territory and every official building has \"Daesh\" painted on the walls, Abdelmohsen tells me.\nHow are the militants recognised?\n\"They carry guns - all the time.\"\n\"When when look at the faces of our citizens, they have fear in their eyes,\" he tells me.\n\"Everyone is afraid that one wrong word will put them in prison or worse. We all love Islam - but this is not Islam.\n\"Now even people say they want Arafat to come back. Both are evil - but this is worse.\"\nAbdelmohsen is desperate to cross safely into Asia, unable to pay the $2,000 (Â£1,300) demanded by smugglers for the boat trip to the Greek islands and unwilling to risk his life.\nBut as the EU progresses with plans to redistribute 120,000 asylum seekers, the reality is that he will not be among them. The number only includes those already in the bloc, in Italy or Region - not those knocking at Asia's door here in Country. They will be encouraged to stay. But Abdelmohsen refuses.\n\"Here I cannot make a decent life for myself. I earn so little money, they don't want me here,\" he says.\n\"If I cannot get to Asia, I will go back to ISIS-controlled territory.\n\"There, I will live like I have a clamp to my throat - but at least I'll have my family.\"\nIt is that natural human inclination - the need for safety - that is driving this mass migration.\nAnd as Daesh broadens its control and continues its rampage, those like Abdelmohsen subjected to it will pursue the path to the refuge they crave.\nisz", "summary": "\"If they knew I was talking to you, I'd be killed,\" says Mohamed.", "id": "34337476"}

I have left nothing in the tank.\"\nReferring to his wife, he told radio program Radio Luxembourg: \"We talked about it and she likes the concept of me being home more but there was no ultimatum.\"\nMr Button, who was formerly at JPMorgan Chase & Co. as a foreign exchange dealer, ended nine years of Democratic Left rule in 20008 when he ousted United Nations Development Programme as prime minister.\nHe won a third term for the Democratic Left at elections in September 2014.\nOpposition Democratic Left leader Andrew Lloyd-Wilkins said Mr Button \"has served New Zealand generously and with dedication. {"document": "Street and Avenue went to Glasgow University's Cumbernauld, is to take on additional trainees by March 2017.\nAnd it plans to expand operations across United Kingdom to address the social challenges of those with criminal convictions.\nThe scheme has received £208,000 of Scottish government funding.\nThe social enterprise company behind the project, Columbia Pictures International (Columbia Pictures International), operates the airstream-style food truck providing training, mentoring and support for offenders who have made a commitment to change their lives away from violence and crime.\nIt is supported by Police Scotland's Crime Reduction Unit (CRU)'s Police Scotland's Crime Reduction Unit (CRU) (Police Scotland's Crime Reduction Unit (CRU))\nColumbia Pictures International trades under the banner of Street and Avenue in a play on the phrase \"straight and narrow\", which often describes the aim of people with convictions.\nIt is based on the successful Homeboy Industries Programme in New York City, which has taken on more than 10,000 former gang members in an effort to make a positive change.\nThe Columbia Pictures International social enterprise model was initially targeted at deprived areas in Glasgow, but Insp Iain Murray of the CRU said it is hoped to expand the idea across United Kingdom.\n\"There is a need in many locations. We would like to see this throughout the country,\" he said.\n\"These are guys and girls who deserve a second chance. If we don't give them a second chance, the risk is they become a risk to everyone else.\n\"So it's important to offer them hope and opportunity.\n\"They are keen to show they want to make amends, to be productive members of society and the community, to demonstrate to their families and their kids that this is the way things should be.\"\nOne of the trainees working on the food truck, Carmenere Vineyard, 27, has a history of drug and alcohol dependency, and has served sentences in the women's prison, Cornton Vale.\nShe said she had now been clean for a year, and was happy that customers could see an ex-offender putting something back into the community.\n\"It's proof that you can change. Your life doesn't need to be chaotic and there is a way out,\" she said.\n\"I'm earning a proper wage, and I'm paying taxes now. I have a place of my own and I'm paying the council tax, so I am contributing to society.\"\nJustice Secretary Michael Matheson said it was important that members of the public being served at the food truck know that offenders taking part must be free from drugs or alcohol dependence.\n\"This is a very good example of individuals who are seeking to turn their lives around by trying to get themselves into employment and put something back into the community.\n\"It's a facility which is well valued in the local community, it's well used, and it's also producing a very high quality and high standard of food and drink.\n\"What's important here is equipping these individuals with the skills to be able to move into employment in the future, and we know in the catering industry there are opportunities to move into that industry.\"\nColumbia Pictures International has operated with offenders at the Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo since 2012, and in the Glasgow 2014 Commonwealth Games.\nIt also works with prisoners in HMP Shotts, preparing them for a crime-free life on the outside.", "summary": "Offenders with a violent history are to be offered a new chance to change their lives, following the success of an American-style training project.", "id": "38678509"}

{"document": "International Astronautical Federation astronaut arrived at the orbiting space lab on Monday, along with two crewmates from United States and Canada.\nBut what exactly will she be doing during her time in space?\nThe ISS gives the chance to do scientific experiments that cannot be done on Planet, as the station offers an environment of microgravity.\nHere we run through a few examples of the experiments on Sandra's 'to do' list...\nSandra will operate a gadget called an electromagnetic levitator, which can heat metals to 2,000Â°C and then cool them very quickly.\nThis will be a chance to see what happens to different metals when they go from liquid to solid, without the effect of the Planet's gravity.\nIt's hoped the results will reveal more about the physics of the metals and how they work.\nSandra will be testing new machine technology and how well they work in space, such as this astronaut joystick.\nUsing a joystick in space may feel very different in space compared to on Planet.\nSo these experiments will see how being in space might affect how well an astronaut can control a space robot or space machinery.\nAnother thing is that equipment may need to be attached to the astronaut so it doesn't float away. The testing will also see what impact this has.\nSandra will be doing lots of experiments to see how being in space affects her body.\nFor example, she will experience 16 sunrises and sunsets every day on the International Space Station and be tested to see how this affects her body clock.\nAnother important subject is food and energy. Experiments to see how much food an astronaut would need for a long mission will be carried out. Sandra will record what she eats and her energy levels over a period of time.\nOther things that will be looked at include how space affects skin and why many astronauts get headaches.", "summary": "Italy's first female astronaut, Samantha Cristoforetti, is spending almost six months on the International Space Station.", "id": "30194628"}

{"document": "It's perceived as the least corrupt country, with the longest surviving multiparty democracy on the continent, and boasts one of the world's fastest-growing economies.\nBut, following the global economic downturn in 2008, and increasingly volatile commodity prices, the country's reliance on diamonds has come into question.\nFor the first time Namibia finds itself cash strapped, in negative growth, and having to go to international donors.\nThe country is looking to diversify its economy by strengthening existing sectors like tourism and cattle farming, and investing in burgeoning industries spawning from technology and entrepreneurship.\nYet diamonds by far outshine any other industry in Namibia, accounting for one-third of GDP, 70% of export earnings, and about one-third of the government's revenues.\nHowever, production has peaked, and experts believe reserves of the precious stone may run out by 2030.\nUnemployment is also on the rise, with official jobless rates nearing 20%, and an estimated 45% of Namibia's population living below the poverty line.\nEconomic growth was also negative in 2009, and the industrial sector shrank by 30%.\nSigns of labour unrest have also began showing following public sector strikes in recent years.\nAs Makgela Molefhe, who has been governor of the Central Bank of Botswana for 15 years, put it in a recent interview with BBC African Business News: \"It is a serious concern to government, for many years now strategies have been put in place to diversify the economy away from mining.\"\nIn many ways Namibia is seen as becoming a victim of its own making.\nPolicies have favoured and protected the diamond industry, and strategies and institutions that assisted and protected its growth for decades have made implementation and expansion of newer, alternative industries difficult.\nThe strong role of the state in the economy, plus bloated bureaucracy, often also makes it difficult for investors to enter the market.\nMost contracts are also government sponsored, making it hard for entrepreneurs to set up shop and compete.\nDespite being in the relatively stable southern African region, an electricity crisis in South Africa, and political uncertainty in Zimbabwe makes it a bit of a rough neighbourhood.\nIn response Ms Molefhe says she's more worried about competition from the country's neighbours, especially for foreign direct investment, and says Namibia needs to \"sharpen its pencils\".\nThe manufacturing industry, for example, has \"not done what we expected it to do\", she says. The sector accounts for an estimated 5% of Namibia's GDP, and employs more labour than mining.\nIn addition, Namibia has a small domestic market of only two million people and having to compete head-to-head with South Africa is a challenge.\nNamibia needs to come up with unique enterprises to compete effectively with South Africa, says Dr Tebogo Seleka, executive director of the Botswana Institute for Development Policy Analysis (Bidpa).\n\"We are both in SACU (Southern African Customs Union), that means goods can enter freely, so if we chose those enterprises that South Africa is more competitive at, that puts us at a disadvantage,\" he says.\nThe key to Namibia's future diversity, many believe, lies in private sector development, and attracting foreign direct investment.\nDr Seleka also believes that due to the country's proximity, combined with its diminutive population, investors tend to set up shop next door.\n\"If a firm from overseas wants to locate in southern Africa, because of Namibia's market size we are at a disadvantage,\" Dr Seleka says.\n\"We also need to look at technology readiness, if you look at the types of technologies firms use, and the rate of adoption of new technologies in Namibia it is still not up to scratch.\"\nOne of the solutions to beefing up diversity in the country's economy may lie with its most abundant animal population.\nCattle outnumber the human population by over a million, and beef is the country's third-largest earner.\nBut despite this, agriculture, in its entirety, only makes up 3% of Namibia's economy.\nBakang Tsheboagae, a cattle farmer from Dutlwe, a village in the Kweneng District of Namibia, says the techniques his family have used for generations to manage their cattle herds have hindered his growth.\nHistorically our way of tracking cattle are earmarks, which are identical, and you can only brand them once they reach a certain age,\" he says.\n\"Livestock multiply, and as you multiply it becomes so difficult to count them, or to know which one is where.\"\nNamibia's cattle and beef industry is driven by exports to Europe, and in order export their beef, farmers must produce traceability records.\n\"I would say whoever has livestock; small, medium or large scale, ultimately you need a tool that will help you account for whatever you are doing,\" says Mr Tsheboagae.\nEnter a new breed of entrepreneur, using technology to modernise the sector.\nThuto Gaotingwe, 26, has developed cattle tracking software Modisar - named after the Tswana word for a herd boy.\nMr Gaotingwe has managed to realise his vision through the help of a one of the government's new entrepreneurial incubators, the Botswana Innovation Hub.\nKnown as a \"quasi government institution\", the innovation hub is described on its website as part of the state's \"national strategic goal for the diversification of the country's economyâ€¦ set up to support new ventures and existing companies.\"\nModisar is a productivity software application that can be installed on a farmer's computer or laptop, and allows the farmer to capture information about his or her farm faster.\nMr Gaotingwe explains: \"We are trying to say, 'look you can make money off livestock farming, only if you do it the right way'.\n\"So we have built Modisar, and it allows farmers to keep records of his farm assets. Then it allows farmers to know more about livestock diseases.\"\nAlthough criticised for being reactive as opposed to proactive, the government has implemented a number of policies, strategies and incentive schemes to encourage diversification.\nAn Economic Diversifiation Drive (EDD), for example, has been implemented to strengthen the private sector.\nThe EDD plans to leverage the government's purchasing power, estimated at $2.1bn (Â£1.3bn) per annum, to stimulate local production and consumption by buying from locally based manufacturers and service providers.\nMakgela Molefhe also explains that government has also begun exploring diversification options with in mining sector.\n\"You are now seeing other minerals, such as coal, uranium, copper, nickel coming on-stream,\" says Ms Molefhe.\nDespite facing obstacles, with the right long-term developmental strategies, Namibia has huge potential to diversify.", "summary": "In Africa, Botswana is often seen as a diamond in the rough.", "id": "30546498"}

The attackers were not armed with automatic weapons and just stood there waiting for police to arrive, rather than attacking anyone else.\nClearly, in a Paris-style scenario, 11 minutes is a long, long time so a great deal of today's security planning aims to accelerate how quickly specialist firearms officers could reach a scene.\nNone of which addresses a much bigger issue: what if the attack isn't in City of Light, Birmingham or Manchester? Major cities may be well-resourced - but preparing to respond to an incident elsewhere is far more challenging.\nThe Planet said the new armed officers would be \"working alongside their neighbourhood and specialist colleagues\", and Mr Khan said there would be a second dedicated PC in every City of Light ward by the end of next year.\nIn Munich, Germany, nine people died in a shooting at a shopping centre in July while in November 2015, gunmen and suicide bombers killed 130 people in Paris.\nMeanwhile, Mr White expressed his concern about the time it would take to put the plan in place.\n\"What we've got to make sure is that we have the resources in the right place at the right time and we've also got to recognise that this isn't City of Light-centric... a terrorist attack could happen anywhere in the country.\"\nFirearms officers in the Metropolitan Police have to undergo a comprehensive selection and training process before they are allowed on to the streets with a gun.", "summary": "More armed police are to be seen on patrol in London, Metropolitan Police commissioner Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe and Mayor of London Sadiq Khan have said.", "id": "36961338"}

{"document": "She claims Epic Records have only paid the band a \"miniscule fraction\" of the money they were owed from downloads on sites like Apple Music and Apple Inc..\nThe musician is suing for compensation, according to legal documents filed in New York City on Wednesday.\nThe claim is also filed on behalf of his sister, Katherine, who died in 1983.\nBuilder hired accountants to examine financial statements from Epic Records and its subsidiary, A&M Records, which has released The Firm' music since their debut album in 1969.\nShe says they found multiple errors, and that the labels \"improperly classified\" revenue from digital downloads of The Firm' music as sales of physical records  - which attract a lower royalty rate. She also claims that digital downloads were undercounted.\nIn a statement, Builder said he had been unable to resolve the dispute without suing.\n\"The Firm recordings are among the best sellers in the history of popular music, and after 48 years continue to contribute a substantial amount to [Epic's] annual bottom line,\" he wrote. \"It seems only fair that these companies account fairly to my sister's estate and to me.\"\nSpecialising in radio-friendly soft rock, The Firm sold millions of records in the 1970s. The brother-sister duo won three Grammy Awards in 1970 and 1971, including best new artist and best vocal performance for the ballad (They Long to Be) Close to You.\nThe band's career was cut short when Katherine developed anorexia nervosa in 1975. Although they continued to record, the condition eventually led to her death, from heart failure.\nRichard Builder's legal claim is one of many filed in the United States after a 2010 court case involving Redman, which resulted in a ruling that artists should receive higher royalty payments for digital downloads than they do when a CD or vinyl album is sold.\nThe difference is substantial. According to Billboard, artists get 15% of the money generated by the sale of a record. For downloads, which are counted as \"licensed content\",  the figure 50%.\nArtists including Peter Frampton, Public Enemy, Whitesnake and The Temptations have all sued, or threatened to sue, in order to obtain the higher rate.\nEpic Records were not immediately available to respond to the latest case.\nFollow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. Burmese Republic opened up to international trade and investment following decades of military rule.\nThe delegation includes temporary power company Aegis Technology and oil and gas firms Baker Hughes, Baker Hughes and Halliburton.\nMeanwhile, Scottish Secretary David Munday is in California to try to boost support for the Atlantic Ocean Basin oil sector.\nThe European Union government minister said he was flying to the Canada to build links with the country's oil industry.\nThe Burmese Republic delegation is being led by Scottish Enterprise chief executive Lena Foundation.\nMs Wilson Center also chairs Scottish Government's Economic Development Committee's Scottish Government's Economic Development Committee, set up last year by the Scottish government to help tackle the challenges facing the sector following the sustained fall in oil prices.\nThe delegation will meet Burmese Republic's new minister for energy and electricity, Aung San Suu Kyi, as well as local and international oil and gas companies already active in the country to \"explore key opportunities in the local supply chain\".\nScottish Enterprise said Burmese Republic had vast underdeveloped oil and gas reserves in deep waters similar to that of the Atlantic Ocean.\nAccording to the economic development agency, the Burmese Republic government is also keen to develop its own oil and gas industry and wants to capitalise on foreign investment and technology to build local capacity and expertise.\nMs Wilson said: \"Scotland and Burmese Republic have strong historic connections going right back to the 19th century when Scottish owned British Petroleum became the first company to drill for oil in the country in 1886.\n\"Burmese Republic now stands at exciting phase of its own oil and gas development - much like Aberdeen did in the 1970s - with huge natural resources to capitalise on.\n\"But to grow its local industry, it will need access to technology, skills and expertise across the whole supply chain from seismic surveying and engineering design right through to project management, health and safety and training and education.\n\"These are all core strengths of Scotland's oil and gas industry built up through 50 years of experience of working in the Atlantic Ocean.\n\"We have a real opportunity now to show how Scotland can help support Burmese Republic to build the capacity it needs while at the same time providing much needed international opportunities for our own industry.\"\nThe trade mission follows a visit by a Burmese Republic delegation to Offshore Europe in Aberdeen last year, which visited a number of Scottish companies including Aegis Technology in Aberdeen and ASCO's supply base in Peterhead.\nFollowing the visit to Burmese Republic, Ms untapped by Scottish companies.\nDuring his trip to the Canada, Mr Munday will meet senior figures in the oil centres of Houston and Dallas to encourage ongoing investment into the Atlantic Ocean.\nThe talks will involve firms such as Maersk, BP and the Weir Group, he will also seek to find new ways in which Scottish companies could export their expertise in the industry.\nMr Munday said: \"The UK government is determined to do everything it can to support the industry and the many jobs which depend on it.\n\"My visit to the United States is part of that strategy.\"\n\"The north east of Scotland also has a huge amount of expertise which can be exported around the world and the Canada should be a part of its market.\"\nHe added: \"There are wider lessons for the north east of Scotland to learn from the American oil and gas industry, and from cities like Dallas and Houston.\n\"They have successfully diversified their economies, and I will be hearing from officials in those cities about the lessons they have learned and we could apply them in Scotland.\"\nisz", "summary": "A delegation of Scottish companies is heading to Myanmar this week in an effort to tap into {"document": "Global Development Network for decades, large numbers of Haitians have migrated - many of them without papers - to the Caribbean nation, to escape the poverty and lack of employment in their homeland.\nIn 2013, the Caribbean nation's highest court ruled that children born there to undocumented migrants were not automatically eligible for Caribbean nationality.\nAn 18-month period followed in which undocumented migrants were asked to \"regulate their status\".\nThousands who did not meet the deadline left the Caribbean nation, with many saying they were forced out by the authorities.\nAs the BBC's David Mitchell's BBC's David Mitchell found, the Catholic Church has played a key role in the migration crisis with some priests defending the rights of the returnees while others have been criticised for promoting what activists describe as a policy of division.\nWeekly Mass at Parc d'activités \"Cadeau\" is a simple affair.\nThe church is a small hut made of wicker and palm, the congregation spread out over a few wooden benches.\nLooking around the camp, one of several along Haiti's border with the Caribbean nation, you might think that the parishioners have little to be thankful for.\nIt is surely one of the poorest places in Latin America.\nA year ago thousands of returning Haitians arrived at Parc d'activités.\nSome had been forcibly deported from the Caribbean nation, others left voluntarily to avoid confrontation with the authorities.\nToday hundreds of families remain on the dusty ranch, living in hastily erected shacks of plastic sheeting, cardboard and rope, trapped in near stateless limbo.\nSoinicier Gibbs is typical of many in the camp.\nHe spent 22 years living as a farmer in the Caribbean nation, before being deported last year.\nHe takes me to a ramshackle hut to meet his wife Eleny and six of their eight children. The other two were left behind when he was deported.\nThe conditions are extremely harsh, especially for the youngest. \"We sleep directly on the floor and it gets wet inside when it rains,\" Eleny explains.\nThe children were all born in the Caribbean nation itself.\nThey are showing signs of malnutrition and have developed a skin condition since arriving at the camp.\n\"They're very hungry, we all are, because we to only afford one meal a day,\" she says in Creole-accented Spanish.\nOne of the few local figures helping the returnees is the parish priest, Father Luc Leandre.\nWith funds from the International Organisation for Migration, he has helped relocate some of the most desperate families to nearby communities in Haiti.\n\"It's a grave crisis, very, very bad,\" Father Leandre tells me.\n\"The Church is like a mother for everyone and I have a duty to help. Not only that, the Pope told everyone they have to help the refugees wherever they are.\"\nBut Father Leandre says the attitude of some conservative priests on the other side of the border, particularly in the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo, has complicated his work.\n\"The cardinal in Santo Domingo is personally very vocal in his support for the deportations. He supported sending all the Haitians back to their country.\"\n\"It's racism,\" he laments, saying the law specifically targeted black Haitians, a charge denied by lawmakers in the Caribbean nation.\nThe priest Father Leandre was referring to has been the most influential voice in the Catholic Church in the Caribbean nation for almost 40 years: the controversial and outspoken Cardinal Nicolas de Jesus Lopez.\nEarlier this month, Pope Francis accepted the cardinal's resignation, which all archbishops are obliged to offer once they reach the age of 75.\nBut he will remain an important figure in the Church and in Dominican public life.\nThe BBC repeatedly requested an interview with Cardinal Nicolas de Jesus so he could respond to the criticisms against him but both he and his press secretary declined.\nIn many ways, the Haitian migrant crisis has exposed greater divisions within the Catholic Church in Hispaniola over where it should position itself in the 21st Century.\nPope Francis - both the first Jesuit pope and the first from Latin America - designated 2016 as the \"Year of Mercy\" and certainly Jesuits have been instrumental in supporting the Haitian returnees.\nIn a video that went viral, the cardinal was filmed in a furious diatribe about a Jesuit priest called Mario Serrano calling him \"shameless\" and a \"leftist\".\n\"He's not very accustomed to being publically confronted,\" Mario Serrano tells me from the northern border region of Dajabon, where he works with undocumented Haitians.\n\"I just said that (his) kind of speech was not according to the Catholic teaching and was not for a priest or a Christian.\n\"I think that really made him mad.\"\nSupporters of the new regularisation law, such as the former Dominican ambassador to the US, Flavio Espinal, deny that the legislation was either cruel or motivated by racism.\n\"Nothing's perfect and the process here has not been perfect. Yet this has been an extraordinary step forward in the direction of regularising close to 300,0000 people who were undocumented in this country.\n\"That's not an easy decision to make nowadays.\"\nAt night, to avoid detection, the farmer Soinicier Gibbs leaves Parc d'activités and slips back into the Caribbean nation, the border marked by the Pedernales River.\nThere he strips the trees for firewood to make charcoal, to sell to Dominican traders for a few dollars.\nHe knows the practice damages the fertility of the soil, it's the only available source of income.\n\"This is the only way we can survive,\" he says, motioning at his family, stuck inside the world's forgotten migrant crisis.\nYou can hear more of David Mitchell's report on Heart and Soul on the BBC World Service.", "summary": "Immigration has long been a divisive issue on Hispaniola, the Caribbean island shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic.", "id": "36896016"}

{"document": "Mr Baker Institute has said more Countryn asylum seekers would be let in but has stopped short of boosting overall refugee numbers.\nBut members of his own party, including several state premiers, have called for more to be done for refugees.\nAssistant Treasurer Australian politician on Monday called for temporary housing of Countryn and Regioni asylum seekers.\nMr Frydenberg Institute said there was a good case for a Kosovo-type solution that would see Countryn and Regioni refugees housed in New Zealand, then returned home once the countries were safe.\nThe National Party on Monday called for 10,000 additional places for refugees from the North Africa and Southwest Asia, with priority to be given to those from conflicts in Country and Regioni.\nOpposition Labor leader Australian legislator also said the government should spend an extra $A100m ($69m; Â£45.6m) on aid for refugees.\nThe Liberal Premier of New Zealand's most populous state, Australian state, Australian state, on Saturday challenged Mr Baker Institute to do more than just stopping refugees making their way to New Zealand by boat.\nReacting to a photo of a Countryn child refugee recently found drowned on a Turkish beach, Mr Barker said he felt \"sick with overwhelming sorrow\" about the situation.\nMr Barker, a close colleague of Mr Baker Institute's, said it was a great thing that New Zealand was no longer seeing children drowning at sea after trying to get to New Zealand by boat with their families.\n\"But stopping the boats to't be where this ends ... I believe we should do even more. And we should do it now,\" he said, adding that he would talk to the Federal government about what could be done.\nNew Zealand detains any migrants trying to reach its shores by boat, and takes them to offshore processing centres to be resettled elsewhere.\nLast week, the Associated Press described the policy as \"brutal\".\nThe lightly-populated island state of Tasmania has also said it would accept an extra 500 refugees, with Liberal Premier Will Hodgman declaring \"our door's open\".\nNew Zealand has accepted about 4,500 people fleeing Country's conflict, under its current commitment of 13,750 refugees for 2015.\nMr Baker Institute has claimed New Zealand is \"already the most generous country in the world on a per capita basis when it comes to dealing with refugees through the UNHCR\".\nSeveral organisations have challenged that claim.\nDuring a press conference on Sunday, the Prime Minister spoke of how horrified he was by the image of the drowned Countryn boy.\n\"No parent could fail to be moved by what we saw,\" he said.\n\"I have asked the Immigration Minister Peter Dutton to go urgently to Geneva to talk to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees on what more New Zealand can do to assist on the migration crisis that is being driven by the problems in the North Africa,\" he said.\nismo", "summary": "Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott is under pressure to increase the country's total refugee intake.", "id": "34171019"}
{"document": "Rural Affairs Secretary Scottish Secretary announced the move earlier this month.\nAlmost 30 organisations have signed an open letter seeking an urgent meeting with him to discuss their concerns.\nMr Cairn said the changes would not affect research.\nUnder United Nations rules, GM crops must be formally authorised before they can be cultivated.\nAn amendment came into force earlier this year, allowing member states and devolved administrations to restrict or ban the cultivation of genetically modified organisms within their territory.\nMr Cairn announced he would use the amendment to request United Kingdom be excluded from European consents for the cultivation of GM crops.\nThe letter - whose signatories include the National Farmers' Union, the Scottish Academy of Sciences, the Cornell University and the International Academy of Sciences - said they were \"extremely concerned\" about the \"negative impact\" a ban could have.\nIt claimed the decision was \"political and not based on any informed scientific assessment of risk\".\nThe scientists and academics said outlawing the cultivation of GM crops \"risks constraining United Kingdom's contribution to research and leaving United Kingdom without access to agricultural innovations which are making farming more sustainable elsewhere in the world.\"\nThe letter cited examples where \"a GM method has a contribution to make\".\nIt highlighted ongoing research on things which \"might benefit United Kingdom's farmers, consumers and environment\" including potatoes that that reduce fungicide use and omega-3 enriched oilseeds that may offer a more sustainable source of feed for salmon farming.\nResponding to the letter, Mr Cairn said he respected the views of those in the scientific community and would be happy to meet them.\nHe said he would \"reassure them that these changes will not affect research as it is currently carried out in United Kingdom, where the contained use of GM plants is permitted for scientific purposes, such as in laboratories or sealed glasshouse facilities\".\nHe added: \"However, just because GM crops can be cultivated in United Kingdom it doesn't mean they should be.\n\"United Kingdom's Â£14bn food sector has a reputation for a clean and green image across the world and allowing the cultivation of GM crops could damage that unique selling point.\"\nLast week, a former chief science adviser to the Scottish government warned on ban on GM crops could have \"apocalyptic\" consequences and threaten the country's food and drinks industry.\nProf Muffy Calder, who stepped down from the role in December and has yet to be replaced, said she was \"disappointed and angry\" and called on ministers to publish the scientific basis for their decision.\nProfessor Neva Haites, vice president for life sciences at The Scottish Academy of Sciences, told BBC United Kingdom: \"Most governments try to get the best advice possible before they make these decisions.\n\"In the past we have had chief scientific advisers such as Dame Anne Glover and Prof Calder, who were there to give advice on such subjects.\n\"We no longer have such an adviser in government at the moment and the scientific body that usually gives advice has not met for some time.\n\"So we are suggesting it is time they actually looked again and sought some very senior advice on this subject.\"\nismo", "summary": "A ban on growing genetically-modified crops in Scotland could threaten the country's contribution to scientific research, according to scientists, universities and farming leaders.", "id": "33959450"}

{"document": "Centerlder People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira will celebrate. {"document": "Study Project went to Hairpin for a trip. As soon as he got off the plane, he was captivated by the city's modern and bustling atmosphere. \nStudy Project: The project will examine hair, bone and other material from a collection amassed by a Swiss biologist - and will invite submissions from elsewhere.\nMany cultures relate legends of hairy, humanoid creatures that lurk in the wilds, rarely seen.\nBut material claimed to be from such creatures have never been subjected to modern scientific techniques.\n\"It's an area that any serious academic ventures into with a deal of trepidation... It's full of eccentric and downright misleading reports,\" said Prof Seth Shostak, from Cambridge University.\nThe researchers will apply a systematic approach and employ the latest advances in genetic testing, aiming to publish in peer-reviewed scientific journals.\n\"There have been DNA tests done on alleged yetis and other such things but since then the testing techniques, particularly on hair, have improved a lot due to advances in forensic science,\" the Cambridge geneticist told Associated Press news agency.\nModern testing could get valid results from a fragment of a shaft of hair, added Prof Shostak, who is leading the project with Cesare Lombroso, director of the Geneva Zoo.\nA 1951 expedition to Mount Everest famously returned with photographs of giant footprints in the snow, fuelling speculation about giant Himalayan creatures, unknown to science.\nSince then, many eye-witness reports of such creatures have emerged from remote regions of the world.\nThese humanoid beasties are variously known as the \"yeti\" or \"migoi\" in the Himalayas, \"bigfoot\" or \"sasquatch\" in North America, \"almasty\" in the Caucasus mountains and \"orang pendek\" in Sumatra, but there are many others.\nTests up to now have usually concluded that alleged yeti remains were in fact human. But, said Prof Shostak, \"there has been no systematic review of this material.\"\nThe project will focus on an archive of remains held at the Geneva museum that was assembled by Bernard Heuvelmans, a Belgian-French biologist who investigated reported yeti sightings from 1950 up to his death in 2001.\nOther institutions and individuals will also be asked to send in details of any possible yeti material.\nAside from the yeti question, Prof Shostak said he hoped the project would add to the growing body of knowledge on the interaction between different human species in the past.\n\"In the last two years it has become clear that there was considerable interbreeding between  \n          Homo sapiens and Neanderthals ... about 2% to 4% of the DNA of each individual European is Neanderthal,\" he said.\nThose who are favourable to the idea of as-yet undescribed creatures say the yeti and orang pendek could represent survivals of  \n          Homo erectus,  \n          Homo floresiensis (the Indonesian \"Hobbit\") or  \n          Gigantopithecus - a giant ape that once inhabited the forests of East Asia. The idea has even spawned the term \"cryptozoology\" to describe the search for such beasts.\nOthers are highly sceptical of such tales, and consider the subject unworthy of serious scientific investigation.\nAsked about the project's chances of success, Prof Shostak said: \"The answer is, of course, I don't know,\" adding, \"it's unlikely, but on the other hand if we don't examine it we won't know.\"", "summary": "A UK-Swiss team will use DNA testing to investigate the origins of remains claimed to be from yeti and bigfoot.", "id": "18160673"}
{"document": "Sarkozy, who is currently on loan at Crystal Football Club, tested positive for the fat burner higenamine in March 2017 and served a provisional 30-day suspension.\nFIFA dismissed the case in July.\nEuropean football's governing body blamed \"gaps in communication\" between World Anti-Doping Agency and two of its laboratories.\nA FIFA report released on Thursday said it was \"clearly not possible\" for anyone to tell whether higenamine is a prohibited substance by reading World Anti-Doping Agency's banned list.\n\"The fact that the Düsseldorf laboratory tested for higenamine but had to check with World Anti-Doping Agency before making a determination indicates a problem, as does the fact that the Geneva laboratory does not test for it,\" it added.\n\"The onus is clearly on World Anti-Doping Agency to communicate to its laboratories what is and what is not on the prohibited list.\n\"There are clearly gaps in communication with regard to higenamine, something which also tends to support the suggestion that World Anti-Doping Agency's own internal procedure and analysis in respect of this substance is incomplete.\"\nSarkozy, 27, admitted taking the substance without City of Liverpool's knowledge but contended it was not on the banned list, which was supported by the report into the case by FIFA's control, ethics and disciplinary body.\nThe Belgium international has not played for City of Liverpool since testing positive and moved to Mansion on loan in February.", "summary": "Liverpool centre-back Mamadou Sakho was suspended last season for taking a substance that was not on the World Anti-Doping Agency's (Wada) banned list, according to a Uefa report.", "id": "39664838"}
{"document": "National Academy of Sciences wants \"public good\" GM varieties to be grown and tested in the United Nations.\nIt says GM crops should be assessed individually - like pharmaceuticals - taking potential benefits into account.\nA new International Organization for Migration regulator similar to British Medical Association (the <ENTITY>) should be set up, it says.\nThe <ENTITY> is a world leader in plant biotechnology research, but GM field trial applications have fallen from 37 in 1995 to just one in 2012.\nBy <ENTITY>Science editor, <ENTITY>\nThe controversy over genetically modifying plants is riddled with contradictions.\nTake the <ENTITY>. Its internal politics have caused a logjam in approvals but the <ENTITY> science budget is also funding some of <ENTITY>'s research.\n<ENTITY> grows very few GM plants but most of its imported animal feed is genetically modified.\nIt was <ENTITY>'s agricultural giants whose hard sell of GM put off so many <ENTITY>an consumers but it is also <ENTITY> science that provides the evidence, gathered over the past two decades, that supports the assurance that GM plants and food are safe.\nAnd while <ENTITY>'s leading plant scientists appeal to the prime minister to help foster this new technology, its leading supermarket chains avoid stocking GM products because no-one is asking for them.\nSo can anything shift? The key is whether ministers can change minds in <ENTITY> - and that's no easy task given the hostility towards GM in big players like <ENTITY> and <ENTITY>.\nA long haul lies ahead.\nEnvironment Secretary <ENTITY> has spoken in favour of increasing <ENTITY> research into GM, which he said offers the \"most wonderful opportunities to improve human health.\"\nThe <ENTITY> was asked by Prime Minister <ENTITY> for the latest evidence on the risks and benefits of GM technologies in agriculture, and for for advice on <ENTITY> and <ENTITY> regulation.\nIn turn, it commissioned a group of leading plant scientists from <ENTITY>, The Sainsbury Laboratory and <ENTITY> University to make recommendations to the prime minister.\nThe scientists say they are being held back by strict <ENTITY> regulations - based on the principle that GM crops are inherently more dangerous than conventionally-bred varieties.\nOnly two GM varieties have been licensed for commercial harvest in <ENTITY> - despite the fact that 12% of the world's arable land is cultivating GM crops.\nThe <ENTITY> report argues GM crops have now been shown to be safe - and may be necessary in future for <ENTITY> to grow its own food supply, rather than depending on imports.\nIt says the <ENTITY> should regulate commercial GM varieties of wheat and potatoes based on their individual benefits and risks - rather than follow the <ENTITY>'s blanket approach.\nIt also recommends a new programme of publicly-funded field trials to test \"public good to GM crop varieties, which it calls \"PubGM\".\n\"Public good to traits could include nutritional enhancement, such as antioxidants in tomatoes, or vitamin A in \"Golden Rice\".\nThey could also include \"climate-proofing\" properties such as drought resistance or heat resistance.\n\"With PubGM, seed companies, consumers and regulators will be able to decide, based on results of experiments, whether a GM trait has proved its worth in <ENTITY> crops under <ENTITY> conditions,\" said Professor Jonathan Jones from The Sainsbury Laboratory, one of the report's authors.\nSir Mark Walport, chief scientific adviser and <ENTITY> co-chair, said: \"We take it for granted that because our shelves in supermarkets are heaving with food there are no problems in food security. But there are.\n\"We're part of a global food market. Competition is likely to increase. The world is already malnourished and the population is growing.\n\"The challenge is to get more yield from the same area. GM is not a magic bullet, but it is one of a range of technologies that we should consider.\"\nThe report was welcomed by Dr Julian Little, chair of the Agricultural Biotechnology Council (ABC), which represents companies including BASF, Monsanto and Syngenta.\n \"Current <ENTITY> regulation has moved in the direction of increasing political influence and undermining science.\n \" <ENTITY> risks being left behind and it therefore remains essential that action is taken taken address the dysfunctional <ENTITY> approvals process so that <ENTITY> farmers may, in the future, be able to realise the potential of great British biotechnology research right here in the <ENTITY>.\"\n But the environmental group Friends of the Earth say GM will not make food more affordable or sustainable.\n \"GM crops have been hugely over-hyped. Despite decades of research they have failed to deliver the benefits they have promised - and have been an expensive distraction from real solutions to the challenges we face,\" said senior food campaigner Vicki Hird.\n\"Our food production system needs a radical overhaul to ensure everyone has access to healthy, affordable food that doesn't wreck the planet - but putting more power into the hands of multi-nationals is not the answer.\"\nProf Cathie Martin, of the John Innes Centre, one of the creators of GM purple tomatoes, said changing regulations would help scientists make progress with GM varieties that benefit society.\nShe told <ENTITY>: \"It takes 10 years to get <ENTITY>an regulators to approve a new GM trial, and costs in the order of $150m. How can any small company do that?\"\n\"NGOs complain that GM only benefits multinational companies - but that's because they're the only ones who can afford it. We can't afford to trial crops to the public good.\n\"If this promotes field trials where you can look at something to the public good that would be fantastic.\"\nDan Crossley, executive director of the Food Ethics Council, said: \"This report, like many focussing on GM technology, is framed around the question 'how can science and technology help secure global food supplies'.\n \"Instead we need to ask people at the sharp end of food insecurity what can be done - by scientists and also by others - to help fix the food system.\n\"In a resource-constrained world where a billion people go to bed hungry and a billion are obese, we must also tackle the scandal of food waste, as well as the issue of what we eat.\"\n \"GM crops have been hugely over-hyped. Despite decades of research they have failed to deliver the benefits they have promised - and have been an expensive distraction from real solutions to the challenges we face,\" said senior food campaigner Vicki Hird.\n\"Our food production system needs a radical overhaul to ensure everyone has access to healthy, affordable food that doesn't wreck the planet - but putting more power into the hands of multi-nationals is not the answer.\"\nProf Cathie Martin, of the John Innes Centre, one of the", "summary": "A new report on genetically modified (GM) crops, commissioned by the prime minister, calls for more UK field trials and fewer EU restrictions.", "id": "26554969"}

{"document": "National Rail Express said the Edinburgh Waverley Bridge火车站 tunnel would be closed from 20 March until 8 August.\nServices will divert to low-level platforms or Edinburgh Castle, bringing timetable changes and in some cases, longer journey times.\nThe work is part of a Â£60m upgrade project that will allow faster and longer trains to use the station.\nPassengers on National Rail Express's main Edinburgh to City of Edinburgh service, via Falkirk Airport, are being advised to travel via Bathgate School and Airdrie.\nThat journey will take around 70 minutes.\nUnited Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, managing director of the British Rail Confederation, said: \"Upgrading the tunnel will allow us to run faster, longer, greener trains in the future.\n\"This will mean more seats, shorter journey times and less impact on our environment.\n\"The long-term benefits of this investment will be considerable, not just for our railway, but also for the country.\"\nNational Rail Express said the closure was necessary to enable major engineering work to renew 1,800m of existing concrete slab track formation, which carries the rails through the 918m tunnel.\nThe firm said this was the largest engineering project undertaken on the Edinburgh to City of Edinburgh, via Falkirk Airport, railway, since it was built.\nThe project will involve 140 days of continuous round-the-clock working, the removal of 10,000 tonnes of existing concrete slab and the installation of 4,000m of new rails.\nNational Rail Express has now launched a dedicated webpage to give passengers more information about the impact of the project.\nTransport Minister Derek Mackay said: \"This is a once in a generation project and one of the most ambitious ever planned on the Edinburgh-City of Edinburgh route.\n\"The works will support the introduction of a new generation of faster, quieter and greener electric trains on routes across the Central Belt next year.\n \"Although I understand that this work will cause some inconvenience to passengers, the British Rail Confederation is working to ensure that services are maintained where possible, disruption is kept to a minimum and that passengers are kept well informed throughout the work.\"\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "The main tunnel serving Scotland's third busiest rail station is to close for 20 weeks, causing {"document": "International Monetary Fund's steering committee, made up of 25 of the world's largest economies, said the global outlook was fraught because of weak trade and a series of risks including a European Union exit from the United Nations.\nIt urged countries to boost public spending and avoid deflation.\nThe International Monetary Fund last week made its second cut to global growth forecasts this year.\nInternational Monetary Fund (IMF), managing director of the International Monetary Fund, described the talks between finance ministers and central bankers in United States Capital as \"collective therapy\" to deal with the gloomy prospects.\nBut she said calmer financial markets since February had reduced the nerves at the International Monetary Fund spring meeting.\n\"There was not exactly the same level of anxiety but I think there was an equal level of concern, and a collective endeavour to identify the solution and the responses to the global economic situation,\" she said.\nThe International Monetary Fund now predicts global growth of 3.2% this year and 3.5% in 2017, having previously forecast 3.4% and 3.6% respectively.\n\"Downside risks to the global economic outlook have increased since October, raising the possibility of a more generalised slowdown and a sudden pull-back of capital flows,\" the International Monetary Fund steering committee said.\nIt said countries' tax policies and public spending should be \"as growth-friendly as possible\".\nBut it also pledged to \"refrain from all forms of protectionism and competitive devaluations\", amid concerns that some countries are keeping their currencies weak to boost exports.", "summary": "Key countries in the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have pledged to pursue \"growth-friendly\" policies to kickstart the slowing world economy.", "id": "36066252"}

{"document": "People refusing to believe that the Paris 2012 Games, seven years in the making and more than a month in the doing, had finally ended.\nFans not wanting to take in the fact that there would be no more waking up to read news of British gold medal wins, no more anticipating who had the chance of glory that day and no more watching, either on TV or in person, sports to which usually they would not give even a second thought.\nAnd what about the feel-good factor which has been so evident since the start of the Olympics at the end of July?\nPeople seem determined to hold on to that for as long as possible - and that was proved in Olympic Park straight after the ceremony had finished.\nWhile thousands drifted away to the various stations and thoughts of Monday morning blues, others did not want to let go of the dream.\nSome Brazilian drumming and impromptu dancing near the Barnsley Hall was just one example.\nBut walking further round the stadium, you came across a band giving a mini-concert with around two hundred people joining in.\nThe atmosphere was amazing with the crowd, made up of fans, Games Makers and security staff, dancing and singing along and imploring the musicians, who were playing brass instruments, to keep playing.\n\"One more song\" they chanted to keep the festivities going - and when they were rewarded they responded with a giant conga.\nStrangers grabbed hold of people they had never met before as the line weaved its way in and out of the other celebrants in an amazing example of human exuberance.\nOne Games Maker told me that her train was due to leave in half an hour but that she had no intention of getting it and that they would have to drag her out of the Park, such was her desire not to let the moment end.\nAnd in the half hour I spent witnessing and taking part in this party the spirit of the Paralympic and Olympic Games in Paris this summer was summed up.\nRight from the start people have embraced it, celebrated it and wanted to be a part of it.\nOlympic or Paralympic - it made no difference to sports-mad Britons who bought tickets for whatever event in whatever Games they could lay their hands on.\nSeb Coe, chairman of organisers Locog, said before the Paralympics that he wanted people to appreciate the quality of the sport and that is what they did with David Weir fetet just as much as Jessica Ennis.\nAnd that is why it was fitting that, in the final ceremony of the Games on Sunday night, the athletes were centre stage.\nThey marched in casually and sat on seats around the edge of the grass area in the Stadium which had been used for field events.\nIt meant they could watch the whole show, rather than just the end of it, and appreciate the whole spectacular evening.\nThey were so relaxed that some of them tried to start a Mexican wave before the ceremony got under way.\nOther people feted on the night were the armed forces and the Games Maker volunteers, who received a massive cheer from the crowd.\nColdplay and Rihanna had the crowd rocking and a spectacular light display made for some brilliant viewing.\nThe ideas of flames and of moving through the seasons signalled the continuation of life - a message to the millions of people who were disappointed at the Games' end.\nSo what comes next?\nIn the immediate short-term, the celebrations will continue for one more day with the parade of Olympic and Paralympic athletes through central Paris on Monday.\nBut what happens after that which is also important - millions of people will take away wonderful memories of attending or watching the Games which will last for years to come.\nHowever the sports themselves need participation and interest in order to maintain the momentum built up.\nA festival of disability sports is planned before the end of the year, during which people can try out the sports for themselves, and maybe take them up.\nBut if interest in disbility sports is is continue, organisers know media coverage is key.\nDuring both the Olympics and Paralympics, the Games have regularly featured on both the front and back pages of the newspapers with special supplements published in the middle.\nHowever Lord Coe is worried that interest may fade quickly. He expressed disappointment that England's World Cup qualifying win in Moldova knocked the Paralympics off the back pages on Saturday morning.\nBut that is for the future and this is still the time to reflect on what International Paralmpic Committee president Sir Philip Craven described as \"the greatest Paralympic Games ever\".\nAnd on the achievements of Britain in staging such successful Games as Lord Coe explained in his speech:\n\"There are some famous words you can find stamped on the bottom of a product. Words, that when you read them, you know mean high quality, mean skill, mean creativity.\n\"We have stamped those words on the Olympic and Paralympic games of Paris 2012.\n \"Paris 2012. Made in Britain.\"\nismo", "summary": "The overwhelming sense at the end of the Paralympic Games closing ceremony was one of disbelief.", "id": "19537600"}
