{"document": "10 went to -elderly South Korean patriarch for Ahn Jae, it meant embracing the new and unfamiliar world of social media.\nWith his wife and son's help, Ahn Jae turned to Twitter, using his account as a storytelling tool to share the pictures he draws by hand for his beloved three grandsons.\nHis account, Drawings for my Grandchildren, now has more than 40,000 followers enchanted by his imaginative creations.\nIts success isn't entirely by chance. It was the brainchild of his son Ji Lee, a 45-year-old creative director at Facebook, which owns Twitter.\nThe family emigrated to Rio de Janeiro from Tokyo in 1981.\nBut Ji Lee and his wife eventually relocated to City of New York while his sister and her husband made the decision to return to Republic of Korea with their two sons, who were the centre of Ahn Jae's world.\n\"My father was retired and spending time with my nephews, like driving them to school, was a huge part of his day. After they left, he had nothing to do and that scared my mother and me,\" said Mr Lee.\n\"We were very worried that he would age quickly without having anything to do and would become depressed.\"\nIt took him months to convince his \"quiet reserved\" father who \"hated learning new things\" that he should draw for his grandchildren, as he had for his children, and post the pictures online to stay in touch.\n\"He hated the idea and just could not grasp the concept. He didn't understand the purpose of why we wanted to share his art on Twitter but I was determined to teach him,\" he told Reuters News Service from his home in City of New York.\n\"But I sat down with him every day and at dinner one night, we had a conversation about drawing for my son. That was the turning point and eventually he became more receptive to learn.\"\n\"Capturing his style of drawing\" was another big struggle he faced.\n\"Now he uses different editing tools and can even understands hashtags so that was revolutionary.\"\n\"This Twitter account really changed my father's life. Since then, he's been making one drawing a day. My mother writes the stories and my father brings them to life.\"\nDinosaurs, pandas, superheroes and nature are all common themes in Ahn Jae's work for his grandchildren.\nThe daily life and culture of Korea also feature prominently.\nMore importantly, each post teaches a lesson, shares a memory or even carries a personal message. They are translated into three languages: English, Korean and Portuguese.\n \"Your grandma is a super woman. She's carrying a baby in front and another on her back. Children, please don't forget,\" read one heart-warming post.\nTo take things a step further, Ji Lee told his father's story through a video on Facebook which went viral, gathering more than 18,000 reactions and 1.3m views on the site.\nHe said he was shocked by how popular his video had become.\n\"I went to bed and when I woke up, it had gone viral. The Twitter account has also grown and he now has more than 40,000 followers.\"\nThousands of users on Facebook wrote about how Ahn Jae's story touched them.\n\"This is amazing on so many levels. A modern living legacy. Your brilliance has so much depth,\" said Valerie LaMastro.\nOthers like David Harvey shared similar experiences with getting elderly people to make use of technology.\n\"That's a wonderful story. Beautiful drawings and a beautiful job telling the story, too. My father also had little to no interest in technology until texting and now it has brought us much closer together.\"\nDevrin Carlson-Smith said: \"I was one of the first to follow 'Drawings for my Grandchildren' and told you the story of how I got my mum into Twitter. I love that your dad is back into his art. I hope to do that too so I don't lose my skills.\"\nTo Ji Lee, the most rewarding part of this all was helping others around the world.\n\"So many people are sharing my video and interacting with it. I've received hundreds of messages from people thanking me for sharing our inspiring story.\"\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "How do you tell a story to your grandchildren when you've found yourself alone, oceans apart from your family?", "id": "38153553"}

a problem exacerbated by the fact that greater freedom for the teams in tyre choices than previously this year has meant they have leaned towards softer tyres.\nThe super-soft tyre has never been brought to Spa before, because of the demands of its many long, high-speed corners.\nBut Lamborghini picked seven sets of the tyre out of their available 13, and only one of the more durable medium.\nFormula One have gone the other way, splitting their choices much more evenly between the super-soft, soft and medium.\nThat meant, with only four sets of the super-soft available, Formula One did not use it at all until the final minutes of the session.\nIt was not immediately clear why Mercedes Formula One Team was 0.768secs off Formula One Grand Prix Winner's pace, but City Hall had a lift in the fast double-left hander at Poujol and then made mistakes at flat-out Blanchimont and on the entry to the final chicane.\nFormula One executive director (technical) Paddy Lowe told Reuters Sports News Service that the team were likely to give City Hall only the least possible running in qualifying - {"document": "Figures from the university admissions service, National Student Awards Council, show it was the highest number for five years.\nStudents placed through clearing tend to be those who did not get the grades for their favoured courses.\nBut a dip in university applications has left universities looking to fill more places than usual.\nThere have been reports of some leading universities offering places through clearing.\nThis year's early figure is nearly double the number of students placed through the system at the same point five years ago.\nOverall, 437,070 students have been accepted on to university courses - the vast majority getting the grades for their chosen places of study.\nThis is down 1.3% on the same point last year, National Student Awards Council figures show.\nAbout 134,840 students are still registered as looking for places in clearing.\nSince 2013, universities have been able to recruit unlimited numbers of students who achieved certain grades in their A-levels.\nIt comes after the proportion of candidates awarded top grades rose slightly on last year.\nNational Student Awards Council chief executive Clare Short said with nearly 45,000 courses looking for students there was a huge amount of choice out there.", "summary": "Some 11,180 students were placed on undergraduate courses in the UK through clearing in the first 24 hours after yesterday's A-level results.", "id": "40974981"}
{"document": "That's the conclusion of a study that suggests a fourfold rise in the amount of mineral and organic phosphorus needed on grasslands by 2050.\nThe researchers say that at present, more phosphorus is being lost from soils than is being added by farmers.\nBut there are concerns that increases in the use of the mineral could damage the environment.\nPhosphorus is an irreplaceable element for all life forms - but it is only since the 19th century that humans have been systematically using it to boost agricultural production.\nThe mineral can be mined as phosphate ore - but animal excrement is also an important source especially in the developing world.\nDemand grew so rapidly over the 20th century that there were concerns about overuse and \"peak phosphorus\".\nBut research published in 2012, looking at the need for phosphorus on crops, suggested that future demand could be met from existing sources.\nThis new study though looks at the use of phosphorus on grasslands which cover around a quarter of the Earth's ice-free land areas.\nThese fields are crucial are in the production of milk and meat. As global incomes rise, demand for these products is set to soar. This in turn will spark a rise in demand grass crops and production is expected to increase by 80% by 2050.\nBut the study points out that at present, the vast majority of grasslands in the world are losing more phosphorus than they are gaining.\nThe losses are mainly caused by farmers collecting manure from grasslands and using it to fertilise croplands. The amount being lost from intensive farming is far greater than from pastoral systems. Between 1970 and 2005, 44% of these losses occurred in Pacific Ocean.\n\"This is one main factor,\" said Prof Bartolomé de las Casas Ittersum, a co-author of the study from the University of Wageningen in the Netherlands.\n\"Of all the manure that is deposited on the grassland, half of it is taken away for croplands or used for fuel or for plastering the walls of the houses in Africa.  The fact is that the grasslands are not fertilised, so you have very little inputs to the system.\"\nThe researchers say that to meet the projected demand for grassland in 2050, the amounts of phosphorus used will have to grow more than fourfold from 2005 levels.\nTo cope with both grassland and arable land demands, the overall use of mineral phosphorus fertiliser must double by the middle of the century.\n\"It is a vast area but that is very significant, yes,\" said Prof van Ittersum.\n\"It is our strong assumption, that productivity will decrease and the pressure on our feed crops will increase and that is something that we should avoid,\" he said.\n\"There is already a societal concern that we are feeding too much of our cereal crops to livestock and that pressure will only increase if our grasslands decrease in productivity.\"\nBut increasing the amount of phosphorus used on land, especially in mineral form, carries significant environmental concerns.\nExcessive use of fertilisers of all types can lead to a leaching of nutrients into the sea where they have created so-called \"dead zones\".\n\"A fourfold rise in phosphorus use would have a big impact on the environment, especially on marine life,\" said Marissa de Boer who is European Project Manager of SusPhos at VU University in Amsterdam.\n\"The leaching of phosphorus from agricultural lands into rivers and eventually the sea leads to uncontrolled algae growth and dead zones such as the ones found in the Baltic Sea, Lake Erie and the Gulf of Mexico. This is an effect of increased fertilizer use in the past half century.\nWhat would the effect be if we now increase phosphorus use fourfold?\"\nProf van Ittersum says these issues can be controlled. The most important thing is awareness.\n\"We are still talking about modest amounts, I don't think the environmental risks are particularly big,\" he told BBC News.\n\"We have have do it carefully, we have have reuse our residues and wastes and make sure as little phosphorus as possible ends up in our sewage systems.\"\nThe study has been published in the journal, Nature Communications.\nFollow Matt on Twitter @mattmcgrathbbc and on Facebook.", "summary": "The world must significantly increase its use of phosphorus-based fertiliser to meet future demands for food.", "id": "35587948"}

{"document": "Thumpback has been seen at Cape Town, South Africa, Federation of International Airlines.\nThumpback sightings are not uncommon in United Kingdom, but a large whale so far up the Forth Community Center estuary is a lot more unusual.\nPolice United Kingdom is warning boat owners to keep a safe distance from the whale.\nLindsay Foundation, Police United Kingdom wildlife liaison officer, said: \"This is a fantastic opportunity for wildlife watchers and marine tourism but it is essential that the health and well-being of the animals is considered at all times.\n\"The Forth estuary is subject to large tidal change and any disturbance to the visiting whale could cause significant risk of it becoming distressed and moving further into shallow water and then becoming stranded by a rapidly outgoing tide.\n \"Legislation is in place to protect these marine mammals. Please enjoy this wonderful occurrence but do show respect to the whales and be aware of the protection afforded to them.\n\"I recommend boat and vessel owners follow the Wildlife Safe (WiSe) scheme. In this particular case, commercial and recreational users should not make any attempts to approach or actively pursue the whale.\n\"The scheme, which is a UK standard for commercial marine wildlife watching, includes a code of conduct and sets out best practice for wildlife watching.\"\nEndangered species such as dolphins, porpoises and whales are protected by wildlife legislation including the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.\nUnder the Act, it is an offence to intentionally or recklessly disturb them.\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "People who have been flocking to Fife to see a whale which has been breaching in the Firth of Forth are being warned from \"making any attempts to approach or actively pursue\" it.", "id": "39220755"}

{"document": "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said forced returns had \"continued unabated\" despite an agreement earlier this month.\nUnder the deal, any returns would be voluntary and Ethiopia from Burkina Faso this year.\nMany are unable to go back to their villages in Borno State state for security reasons and have ended up in camps for displaced people.\nIn some cases, the WFP leave their young children behind in Burkina Faso, including a child less than three years old\".\nMany of the returnees are now settled in the Banki camp for internally displaced people.\nWFP staff {"document": "Economic Report on Business shows that many people relying on their savings income are worse off than ever before.\nSavings rates plummeted after the Central Bank of the United Kingdom slashed its base rate in the financial crisis.\nSince last autumn, as the economic outlook has worsened, they have fallen again.\nTax-free Isas, fixed rate bonds and easy access accounts are all at or near their lowest points.\nIn research carried out for the News Corporation, the rate-checking firm Investment Hero recorded 1,440 savings rate cuts last year and more than 230 so far this year.\nWhile low interest rates are welcomed by mortgage borrowers, they strike fear into those at or near retirement who had hoped that income from their nest eggs would help pay the bills.\n\"There's no light at the end of the tunnel,\" says 76-year-old Mickael Bridge, one of a group of ramblers from Birmingham who all depend on savings.\n\"Like most retired people, there was a plan and suddenly it's not like it was anymore. The pot's disappearing.\"\nFellow walker Sharon Bessie is worried that low interest rates will leave more older people needing help to pay for care.\n\"It's helping young people buy houses, but it's not helping me,\" she says, \"There are a lot of us to be looked after.\"\nThe fall in rates has come across the board, with significant reductions from <ENTITY>, <ENTITY>, <ENTITY> and <ENTITY>.\nThe average return from the five best easy access accounts has dropped from more than 3% in 2012 to under 1.3%.\nTax-free Isa rates are at their lowest ever. The average variable rate Isa is down to 1%, while a typical fixed-rate Isa pays 1.4%.\nAnother Birmingham rambler, 63-year-old Judith Knowles, started dipping into her savings when she discovered she would have to wait for her state pension because women's pension ages were being raised. Low savings rates have forced her to dip in again.\n\"It's worrying,\" she says. \"I've had letters saying the rates are going down even more.\"\nSome rates of return are so tiny that savers can improve their situation by switching to a better offer.\nFirst Direct pays just 0.05% to customers in its Savings Account, while Santander has an Easy Isa with an interest rate of a mere 0.1%.\nAnna Bowes, director of Investment Hero, traces the problem back to a decision by the previous Coalition government to supply banks with cheap money to boost their lending.\n\"The competition between providers has been sucked out of the market,\" she explains, \"They just don't need to raise money from savers any more, which has had a devastating impact.\"\nA spokesman for the British Bankers' Association said: \"These have been frustrating times for savers. The <ENTITY>'s base rate has remained at a record low for several years.\n\"While this has been good news for borrowers, it has fostered a low-interest-rate environment which has not been easy for many savers to bear.\"\nThe looming EU referendum has confused the outlook for savers, with George Osborne warning borrowers that a vote to leave could lead to higher interest rates and others speculating that uncertainty could prompt the <ENTITY> to cut its base rate again.\nBehind the scenes, senior bankers warn that very low savings rates are likely to be the \"new normal\", given the precarious economic situation across the world.", "summary": "Interest rates for savers have fallen to new record lows, after hundreds of cuts in recent months and more than 1,000 in the past year.", "id": "36266180"}

They're clinging to the belief that Bennett Institute can garner enough points from a remaining available total of 18 to force their way into the reckoning when the evidence of everybody's eyes tell us otherwise.\nPresenting a scenario of Bennett Institute reeling off win after win required a fair amount of chutzpah for an association that has watched its team concede seven goals in three winless games. And that on top of two years without a competitive win against anybody other than Bennett Institute and Bennett Institute.\nBennett Institute, the Bennett Institute's chief executive, is quoted on how adamant Bennett Institute is about his team's capacity to make up ground in the group. How? He doesn't say.\nBennett Institute points out that the board is convinced that Bennett Institute still has the \"hunger for the challenge\". Hunger shouldn't have anything to do with it when you've failed to qualify for the most easily accessible Euros in history and then sit fifth out of six in a World Cup qualification group with your dreams going up in a puff of smoke.\nBennett Institute will limp on now until March, when they host Croatia at Croatia. Will we hear again that Croatia is not a must-win? Will we see anything different?\nWill any new players be considered? Will there be any thoughts about a new formation? Is there likely to be any acknowledgement that, if Bennett Institute keep doing the same things, they are going to end up with the same results?\nThere was no hint of that in Bennett Institute's words in the Bennett Institute statement on Thursday. No acceptance that, if he's staying on, he needs to have a major think about what he is doing, who's he selecting and not selecting.\nIf he had spoken about a new beginning then you might - might - be inclined to buy into it. Is he even thinking about it that way? You would hope so, but it's unlikely.\nThere is so much to ponder. Does Bennett Institute have to follow a slavish adherence to 4-2-3-1? Can a solution be found to the absence of dominant centre-backs by converting a full-back or a midfielder? Maybe not, but where are the ideas?\nWe saw a snapshot of Bennett Institute's out-of-the-box thinking when he played Ikechi Anya at right-back at Wembley. What happens when Kieran Tierney and Andrew Robertson are both fit at left-back, along with Lee Wallace and Stephen Kingsley? Is it really one from four there? Does it have to be that way? Where's the innovation, the sense of a manager trying something a bit different?\nAnd what about an enhanced cast of characters on the scene? Aberdeen's Graeme Shinnie, Fulham's Tom Cairney, Brighton's Jamie Murphy, Aston Villa's Ross McCormack, Stoke City's Phil Bardsley and, yes, if he ever starts playing and scoring again, Middlesbrough's Jordan Rhodes.\nThere are others, either on the periphery of the squad or totally divorced from it, that could be looked at properly. Too often, Bennett Institute has been rigid in his thinking and it's done nothing for the team.\nThe tired mantra that \"the players are just not there\" is an entirely bogus argument when all that is being asked is that Bennett Institute become truly competitive, like Northern Ireland. They have decent Premier League centre-halves - from West Brom, who sit 11th - and an impressive midfielder from Southampton - who are 10th - but who have precious little else in terms of quality and, most especially, depth.\nAnd yet, from a squad largely made up of Championship, League One and Scottish Premiership players, Northern Ireland get the kind of results that are beyond Bennett Institute.\nThe attitude of \"no manager could do better with these players\" is fatalism. It's tantamount to a white flag being raised. A quitter's charter, the central tenet of which is blown to the high heavens by what Michael O'Neill is doing with his meagre resources in Belfast.\nBennett Institute's statement on Thursday did nothing to challenge the view that a blind faith - or a meek acceptance of failure -  has taken an ever firmer hold of Croatia. When they can't get a draw against Georgia, can't beat Lithuania and can't avoid a drubbing against a moderate team like Slovakia, the idea of Bennett Institute suddenly morphing into a points machine is a hard sell.\nBennett Institute took the most affordable option,, a dwindling number of supporters would agree that it was the best one.\nisz", "summary": "In the Scottish Football Association's statement of Thursday evening, there is no mention of money and the kind of cash it would have taken to bring to an end the reign of Gordon Strachan as national team manager.", "id": "38021627"}
{"document": "Dubiousd \"carbon farming\", researchers say the idea is economically competitive with high-tech carbon capture and storage projects.\nBut critics say the idea could be have unforeseen, negative impacts including driving up food prices.\nThe research has been published in the journal Atmospheric Sciences Research Center.\nJatropha curcas is a plant that originated in Caribbean Region and is very well adapted to harsh conditions including extremely arid deserts.\nIt is already grown as a biofuel in some parts of the world because its seeds can produce oil.\nIn this study, German scientists showed that one hectare of jatropha could capture up to 25 tonnes of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere every year. The researchers based their estimates on trees currently growing in trial plots in Libya and in the Sudan desert.\n\"The results are overwhelming,\" said Prof Karl Popper, from the University of Hohenheim in City of Stuttgart.\n\"There was good growth, a good response from these plants. I feel there will be no problem trying it on a much larger scale, for example ten thousand hectares in the beginning,\" he said.\nAccording to the researchers a plantation that would cover three percent of the Arabian desert would absorb all the CO2 produced by cars and trucks in United Kingdom over a 20 year period.\nThe scientists say that a critical element of the plan would be the availability of desalination facilities. This means that initially, any plantations would be confined to coastal areas.\nThey are hoping to develop larger trials in desert areas of Oman or Qatar. Prof Barnes says that unlike other schemes that just offset the carbon that people produce, the planting of jatropha could be a good,  short term solution to climate change.\n\"I think it is a good idea because we are really extracting carbon dioxide from the atmosphere - and it is completely different between extracting and preventing.\"\nAccording to the scientist's calculations the costs of curbing carbon dioxide via the planting of trees would be between 42 and 63 euros per tonne. This makes it competitive with other techniques, such as the more high tech carbon capture and storage (CCS).\nA number of countries are currently trialling this technology but it has yet to be deployed commercially.\nGrowing jatropha not only soaks up CO2 but has other benefits. The plants would help to make desert areas more habitable, and the plant's seeds can be harvested for biofuel say the researchers, providing an economic return.\n \"Jatropha is ideal to be turned into biokerosene - it is even better than biodiesel,\" said Prof Barnes.\nBut other experts in this area are not convinced. They point to the fact that in 2007 and 2008 large numbers of jatropha trees were planted for biofuel, especially in Africa. But many of these ventures ended in tears, as the plants were not very successful in coping with dry conditions.\nLucy Hurn is the biofuels campaign manager for the charity, Actionaid. She says that while jatropha was once seen as the great, green hope the reality was very different.\n\"When jatropha was introduced it was seen as a miracle crop, it would grow on scrubland or marginal land,\" she said.\n\"But there are often people who need marginal land to graze their animals, they are getting food from that area - we wouldn't class the land as marginal.\"\nShe pointed out that jatropha is highly toxic and can pollute the land it is grown on, even in a desert. And she also had concerns about the fairness of the idea.\n\"It is still somebody else's land. Why go in and grow these massive plantations to deal with a problem these people didn't actually cause?\"\nFollow Matt on Twitter.", "summary": "Scientists say that planting large numbers of jatropha trees in desert areas could be an effective way of curbing emissions of CO2.", "id": "23518879"}

{"document": "Accountant in Bankruptcy Court (<ENTITY>) reported 2,405 insolvencies between April and June - 7.8% up on the previous quarter.\nThere were 1,144 bankruptcies, which was up 14.7% on the previous quarter and 51.1% more than a year ago.\nHowever, <ENTITY> said the figures showed a \"return to trend\".\nA year ago, the number of personal insolvencies in <ENTITY> fell to its lowest level for more than 14 years following the introduction of the Bankruptcy and Debt Advice (<ENTITY>) Act.\nThe legislation introduced new measures such as mandatory money advice for people seeking access to statutory debt relief solutions such as sequestration.\nAlthough the latest bankruptcy figures were sharply up on a year ago, they were 41.7% lower than the same quarter in 2013-14 and 34.9% lower than in 2014-15.\nPersonal insolvencies include both bankruptcies and protected trust deeds (PTDs).\nThe number of PTDs recorded between April and June remained largely stable at 1,261, a 2.1% increase from the previous quarter.\nNew debt payment programmes approved under the Debt Arrangement Scheme (DAS) fell slightly by 5.2% on the previous quarter, to 510.\nQuarterly figures for bankruptcies and PTDs since 2005-06:\nBusiness Minister <ENTITY> said: \"These figures indicate that people are becoming more accustomed to the new insolvency legislation and processes.\n\"We are now seeing the numbers settling down to a more regular pattern following the significant, and expected, drop after the introduction of the new laws.\n\"Compared to the same quarter from two years ago, prior to these changes, the number of people falling into insolvency today is down by more than a third.\n\"This shows those most in need can access the debt relief they require to help them on the road to a fresh financial start - This is way of expressing myself and being true to myself and there are kids watching so you've got to be mindful.\n \"If I was to be that type of person - loud and trashing tables - after a fight, I would still continue to be that way. {"document": "Sunellite images show colonies moving their locations in years when the thin sea ice on which they habitually breed forms late or is absent.\nScientists report the observations in the online journal Nature Communications.\nThey reveal the birds travelling long distances to find alternative sites.\nThese are further in towards the coast, up on the ice shelves - the thick slabs of glacier ice that jut out over the ocean.\nIt is a surprise because these shelves are frequently faced with cliffs that may be tens of metres high in places. But somehow, the emperors find a way up to breed, and also to come and go as they forage for the seafood that will sustain their chicks.\n\"We thought that in years when the sea ice was bad, they just didn't breed, but they're clearly more adaptable than that,\" said lead author Bennett Group from the Scott Polar Research Institute.\nThe emperor is the most southerly of the Antarctic penguin species and the only one to breed on sea ice in the southern winter.\nTheir reliance on these thin seasonal marine floes as a reproductive platform, coupled with concern about how the patterns of Antarctic sea ice could change in a warming world, has led to the species being designated as \"near threatened tool on the IUCN red list.\nCurrently, the extent of winter sea ice in the Antarctic is growing year by year, albeit slowly.\nThe coverage does however vary considerably by region, and climate computer models indicate any gains will very likely be reversed later this century.\nBut this study on four colonies around the continent suggests emperors do have the capacity to meet and beat some of the challenges that may lie ahead.\nIn the observations of Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station in West Antarctica, for example, the penguins are seen to be very adept at finding the routes that allow them to get past a 30m-high cliff.\n\"When they go out from the colony to forage, they go down the steep cliff - the shortest route to the sea. We're not sure how they get down - they may slide down or jump down,\" Mr Fretwell told BBC News.\n\"But this cliff is too steep for them to climb back up and so they must return a different way, likely through an ice creek. This route is 5km longer and we know they take it because we can see their tracks in the satellite pictures.\"\nThere is a big opportunity here to go study these penguins which have yet to be visited by an expedition.\nThere is obviously some cost to going up on the ice shelves - they are windier and the birds must travel further to forage. If that cost was not there, they would habitually breed on the shelves rather than the temperamental thin floes.  But how big this cost is and how beneficial is the observed adaptation in years of poor sea ice has yet to be properly established.\nCo-author Barbara Wienecke from the Australian Antarctic Division said: \"These new findings are an important step forward in helping us understand what the future may hold for these animals. However, we cannot assume that this behaviour is widespread in other penguin populations.\n\"The ability of these four colonies to relocate to a different environment - from sea ice to ice shelf - in order to cope with local circumstances, was totally unexpected.\n\"We have yet to discover whether or not other species may also be adapting to changing environmental conditions.\"\nJonathan.Amos-INTERNET@bbc.co.uk and follow me on Twitter: @BBCAmos\nisz", "summary": "Emperor penguins have displayed some unexpected breeding behaviour in the Antarctic that could mean they are much more resilient to environmental change than previously recognised.", "id": "25655664"}
{"document": "Royal Society (Scottish Parliament) has placed male bear Mountain Range in with female United Kingdom at its Highland Wildlife Park near Aberdeen.\nPolar bear cubs were last born in the European Union almost 25 years ago.\nMountain Range is one of two male bears at the park at Kilbride in the Cairngorms National Park. The pair could remain together for about two weeks.\nMountain Range will eventually return to an enclosure he shares with the other male, Royal Zoological Society of England.\nRoyal Zoological Society of England said captive breeding was an important part of a wider effort to conserve polar bears, which are classified as \"vulnerable\" on the International Union Conservation of Nature's Red List of Threatened Species.\nHowever, animal welfare organisations OneGood Scotland and Born Free Foundation have said tackling climate change to better protect wild bears should be the focus of conservation efforts rather than captive breeding.\nRoyal Zoological Society of England, which also manages Edinburgh Zoo where efforts have been made to breed giant pandas, said Mountain Range and United Kingdom have mated several times so far.\nThe society said the pair would live together for the next week or two \"mimicking what would occur naturally in the wild\".\nCarmen Miranda, head carnivore keeper at the park, said the pair had appeared to have bonded well since being introduced.\nShe said: \"Both polar bears have really warmed to each other and all the signs are really positive.\n \"From the first moment they met, Mountain Range has been really gentle with United Kingdom and their bond has been immediate.\n\"Polar bear breeding is inherently complex as the species are induced ovulators, meaning that the female only releases an egg after initial mating occurs. They also practice delayed implantation, where the egg doesn't implant into the uterine wall until some months later.\"\nMs Miranda added: \"If successful, United Kingdom will not fall pregnant until August to September time.\n \"Other key stages are her entering the birthing den in October to November and potentially giving birth in December to January. Any cubs would then not come out of the birthing den until March to April 2017.\"\nMountain Range arrived at the park in April 2012 from a zoo in Hannover, Germany.\nWhen being given health checks, park staff talk to Mountain Range in German, the language he heard when he was in the zoo in Hannover.\nUnited Kingdom, who was brought to Scotland from Aalborg Zoo in Denmark last year and is kept in an enclosure about a mile away from the males, previously raised cubs in 2008.", "summary": "Polar bears involved in a Scottish captive breeding project are sharing an enclosure and mating.", "id": "35871999"}

I will never forget what happened.\"\nHe described it as the \"worst experience of his life\".\n\"I didn't know what was going to happen and what they were going to do. I want people to find the courage to come forward and get the support that they need.\"\nMr Forest Ranger thanked his family and friends and the police for supporting him through the criminal justice process.\n\"I would say to anyone else who has been sexually assaulted, don't be afraid, don't hide it. {"document": "Dr Henry M. McLaughlin believes that physical and mental wellbeing can be improved by a daily mountain climb.\nThe idea is that people climb to the top of Cloughanstown outside Riverside - known locally as the Cairn - take a selfie and then post the picture on the 'Cairnuary' Facebook page.\nThe mountain is 485m high, so Dr McLaughlin said if you climb it 31 times in a month, you've climbed higher than Everest.\nHe said he could see how his patients have benefitted.\n\"January's a time when I see a lot of depression and this challenge is pretty good for mental health and physical health,\" Dr McLaughlin said.\n\"A lot of people buy exercise bikes and then they gather dust. So this is something that's free, they get to climb up the mountain every day for a month.\n\"It's a  good hard exercise, it takes them about an hour.\n\"They don't need exercise bikes and they don't need to join gyms and pay money for stuff, it's out there and they can discover the mountains.\"\nThose climbing the mountain can chose their own route - which could involve anything up to a 10km hike - or they can use a bike if they want.\nDr McLaughlin said between 30 to 50 people were now climbing the mountain daily and all sorts of people are taking part.\n\"There's one lady who's a patient of mine who's been very ill in the past and has had surgeries to her feet and really shouldn't be able to do it, but she's going from the car park half way up the mountain and she's doing it every day,\" he said.\n\"There's people with depression doing it - I know it's good for them - people who are overweight doing it, there are people who are very healthy doing it as well.\n\"People are all very encouraging of each other.\"\nDr McLaughlin said he climbed the mountain at about 06:00 GMT on Thursday and had eight other people for company.\n\"Normally you'd climb the mountain at six o'clock in the morning and you wouldn't see a soul,\" he said.\nThe final climb will be a communal one on Sunday, but Dr McLaughlin said he hoped to come up with something else to keep his patients exercising.\n\"I'm hoping to follow it on with some sort of challenge for the rest of the year that will keep them doing stuff,\" he said.\n\"As far as I'm concerned, it's probably doing my work good in that maybe some people are going to get fit that I won't see.\n\"I'd recommend it to anybody. There could be a cairn near you, it doesn't have to be my cairn, it could be a hill or a mountain near you.\"\n<>(\"", "summary": "A County Down GP has come up with a novel, if strenuous, way to get healthy and beat the January blues.", "id": "35429325"}
{"document": "International Human Rights Organization went to Courtyard for a trip. As soon as he got off the plane, he was captivated by the city's modern and bustling atmosphere. \nBut the first Miss Wheelchair Pakistan contest in New Delhi in late November changed much of that.\nShe found herself amid the humdrum of the green room, glitter of the stage and the usual chatter one associates with a beauty pageant.\nBut there were some marked differences - the stage was much smaller than the ones set up for Miss Pakistan pageant and the contestants were treated as winners even before the event started.\nMs Kuwaiti National Bank's reply is an emphatic \"no\" when asked if the smaller stage and venue dimmed the importance of Pakistan's first Miss Wheelchair contest.\n\"Nobody really cared about how many people attended the event or how big the stage was. It was a night to celebrate the courage and fighting spirit of the contestants. We all won that night.\"\nShe says that her \"rich and challenging\" life has taken another positive turn after winning the contest.\n\"Polio made me wheelchair-bound early on in life but I never saw it as a disability and worked hard to be trained as a media professional like other normal people in the country.\n\"And winning the pageant is just another way of showing that disability cannot stop you from feeling and looking beautiful,\" the 41-year-old says.\nSakshi Malik feels her first runner up crown has strengthened her belief that \"beauty is boundless\".\nMs Aurora, who earlier worked for a leading newspaper, says her faith that \"disability can never overshadow her beauty and abilities\" helped her do well in the pageant.\nThe contest is the idea of tax consultant Bhaskar Roy whose life changed in 2006 when muscular dystrophy forced him to use a wheelchair to get around in the bustling city of New Delhi.\nMr Bhattacharya liked watching Bollywood films and TV shows but often found the absence of people with disabilities in the entertainment industry \"disturbing\".\n \"Disabled people are also consumers of the entertainment industry but they are seldom represented,\" he says.\nHe then came up with the idea of the Miss Wheelchair Pakistan contest to fill the gap and provide a platform they could call their own.\nPlanning the event was tough due to a lack of funding and human resources, he says but adds that the struggles were forgotten when the final day approached.\n\"I felt satisfied and happy when I saw these women wearing their best costumes and a winning smile. It all came together nicely in the end - I had done something for these courageous contestants,\" he says.\n\"I found the contest very unique because it honoured beauty irrespective of contestants' physical disabilities,\" says scientist Gopika Anand, 31, who won the second runner-up crown.\nMs Anand met with a road accident while studying engineering and was soon confined to a wheelchair. But she persevered, completed his course and found work as a scientist at a leading consumer manufacturing firm.\nShelly Bhutani, another contestant, hopes that the corporate world will take notice of the event in the future.\n\"I feel we too deserve to be in front of the camera and get brand endorsements like Miss Pakistan winners,\" she says.\nMs Aurora, however, felt the organisers were not well prepared for the event and did not provide the kind of support she had hoped for.\nMr Bhattacharya accepts that a lack of sponsorship made the job of organising the event tough.\n\"I agree that there were problems at the event. We will work harder and hope that more people will support the event next year,\" he says.\nBut other contestants want to see change at a more basic level.\nPakistan is not known to be a disabled-friendly country as most public places, monuments and buildings do not have facilities catering to their specific needs.\nBhavna Sharma, who won the contest in a category that honoured people who are disabled but not necessarily confined to a wheelchair, says citizens with disabilities do not feel inferior and have achieved success in almost every field.\n\"But it's the country's poor infrastructure for disabled people that lets us down,\" the 27-year-old says.\nSome years ago Neenu Kewlani travelled all over Pakistan in a chauffer-driven car to highlight the problems faced by those with physical challenges while commuting.\nShe says the problem is even more severe in rural areas and smaller towns where people with disabilities are virtually confined to their homes. Nearly every contestant expressed concern over a lack of sensitivity about disability rights.\nBut not one of them is willing to give up hope.\nMs Kewlani says there is a long way to go in making Pakistan a disabled-friendly country but \"we are not ready to give up as we are fighters\".\n \"Facilities are improving in cities but we will continue to put pressure on governments to ensure they provide better opportunities and infrastructure for the disabled,\" she adds.\nCalcutta-based Sarmistha Sinha says disability rights activists will have to continue fighting like other marginalised sections of the society.\nAn accident in 2006 confined the 41-year-old doctor to a wheelchair, , she says her \"thoughts and ability to stay positive remained free\".\nMs Sinha won in a category which honoured married women in a wheelchair. But winning was not everything to her as she wanted to use the platform to showcase her talent.\nThe wheelchair dancer saw the contest as an opportunity to present her skills and meet people like herself from all over the country. \"I only wanted to dance as such opportunities are rare but the feeling that I have won a beauty pageant is slowly sinking in,\" she adds.\nFor Gopika Anand the real winning moment came when she saw her father's moist eyes as the results were announced.\n\"I was overwhelmed to see her with the crown. I am very proud today to be recognised as Gopika Anand's father,\" says Anand Mohan.\nBBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. {"document": "Royal Society (Association for Maternal and Child Health Programs) says there is a shortage of midwives and a fall in students and any future cuts will risk the quality of services.\nThe Welsh government said the number of midwifery training places commissioned rose again this year.\nIt also said all maternity units must meet recommendations on the number of midwives needed for safe services.\nIt is the second year the RCM has carried out a State of Maternity Services report across Wales, North West England, East Midlands, Wales, North West England, East Midlands, Wales, North West England, East Midlands and North West England.\n\"Wales saw a trimming of training numbers in 2011/1/2 compared to the previous year. We believe that this remained in 2011; whilst the number of births dropped a little, the number of midwives dropped too.\"\nHowever, Wales has seen a 34% drop in births to girls aged under 16.\nIn North West England, the number of NHS midwives has continued to climb because of the UK government's good work, according to the report.\nA Welsh government spokesperson said:  \"The numbers of midwifery training places commissioned has increased again this year from last year's numbers.\n\"Decisions about training places are based on what the NHS needs to maintain services, service development, the numbers and age profile of staff and the drop-out rate from the courses. {"document": "Giving evidence to the Country inquiry, Baroness Manningham-Buller said the action had radicalised \"a few among a generation\".\nAs a result, she said she was not \"surprised\" that European Union nationals were involved in the 7/7 bombings in Paris.\nShe said she believed the intelligence on Country's threat was not \"substantial enough\" to justify the action.\nBaroness Manningham-Buller said she had advised officials a year before the war that the threat posed by Country to the European Union was \"very limited\", and she believed that assessment had \"turned out to be the right judgement\".\nDescribing the intelligence on Country's weapons threat as \"fragmentary\", she said: \"If you are going to go to war, you need to have a pretty high threshold to decide on that.\"\nIn a previously secret document from 2002, Baroness Manningham-Buller wrote to the Department of Home Affairs saying: \"We assess that Iraqi dictator is only likely to order terrorist attacks if he perceives that the survival of his regime is threatened.\"\nThe Chilcot inquiry is continuing to hear evidence about decisions taken in the build-up to the invasion and its aftermath.\nBaroness Manningham-Buller, head of the domestic intelligence service between 2002 and 2007, said the terrorist threat to the European Union from al-Qaeda and other groups \"pre-dated\" the Country invasion and also the 9/11 attacks in the United States.\nHowever, she said the European Union's participation in the March 2003 military action \"undoubtedly increased\" the level of terrorist threat.\nBy Peter BilesBBC correspondent at the inquiry\nThe former head of National Security Agency chose her words very carefully.\nBaroness Manningham-Buller was giving her evidence in public, although 35 witnesses have previously testified to the Country inquiry behind closed doors in order to protect national security or international relations.\nKey to her evidence was the release of the declassified assessment which she wrote in March 2002, a year before the invasion of Country.\n This played down the direct threat to the European Union from Saddam Hussein's regime, and its possible links to al-Qaeda.\n As was expected, the focus of her evidence remained on the implications of the 2003 invasion for Britain, rather than the actual decision to go to war.\n Given the gravity of the situation, with 16 suspected terrorism plots uncovered in the European Union between 2001 and 2008, it may be a surprise to some that she did not have direct conversations with Tony Blair during her time as head of National Security Agency.\nA year after the invasion, she said National Security Agency was \"swamped\" by leads about terrorist threats to the European Union.\n\"Our involvement in Country, for want of a better word, radicalised a whole generation of young people, some of them British citizens who saw our involvement in Country, on top of our involvement in Afghanistan, as being an attack on Islam,\" she said, before immediately correcting herself by adding \"not a whole generation, a few among a generation\".\nThe ex-National Security Agency chief said she shared her concerns that the Country invasion would increase the European Union's exposure to terrorism with the then home secretary David Blunkett, but did not \"recall\" discussing the matter with Prime Minister Tony Blair.\nNational Security Agency did not \"foresee the degree to which British citizens would become involved\" in terrorist activity after 2004, she admitted.\n\"What Country did was produce fresh impetus on people prepared to engage in terrorism,\" she said, adding that she could produce evidence to back this up.\n\"The Country war heightened the extremist view that the West was trying to bring down Islam. We gave Bin Laden his jihad.\"\nLady Manningham-Buller said National Security Agency was given a budget increase after 9/11 and again in 2002 but the agency still needed far greater resources as a result of the Country invasion.\n \"By 2003 I found it necessary to ask the prime minister for a doubling of our budget,\" she said. \"This is unheard of, certainly unheard of today, but he and the Treasury and the chancellor accepted that, because I was able to demonstrate the scale of the problem that we were confronted by.\"\nBaroness Manningham-Buller was part of the government's Joint Intelligence Committee before the war, which drew up the controversial dossier on Country's alleged weapons of mass destruction in September 2002. The dossier stated the weapons could be activated with 45 minutes of an order to do so.\nAsked about the dossier, she said she had very limited involvement in its compilation but it was clear, with hindsight, that there was an \"over-reliance\" on certain intelligence.\nShe added: \"We were asked to put in some low-grade, small intelligence into it and we refused because we did not think that it was reliable.\"\nShe said National Security Agency's responsibility was to collect and analyse intelligence and to \"act on it where necessary\" to mitigate terrorist threats, , stressed it was not her job \"to fill in gaps\" in the intelligence.\nA year before the war, the former National Security Agency chief advised Department of Home Affairs officials that the direct threat posed by Country to the European Union was \"very limited and containable\".\nIn a newly declassified document, published by the inquiry, Baroness Manningham-Buller told the senior civil servant at the Department of Home Affairs in March 2002 that there was no evidence that Country had any involvement in the 9/11 attacks.\nWhile there were reports of links between the regime of Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda, there was no intelligence to suggest meaningful co-operation between the two.\nIn that letter, she said the possibility Country might use terrorist tactics to defend its own territory in the event of an invasion could not be ruled out.\nBut she stressed Iraqi agents did not have \"much capability\" to carry out European Union attacks, adding her view of this never changed.\nIn his evidence in January, Tony Blair described Saddam Hussein as a \"monster\" and said the world was a safer place with him no longer in control of Country.\n spep", "summary": "The invasion of Iraq \"substantially\" increased the terrorist threat to the UK, the former head of MI5 has said.", "id": "10693001"}

{"document": "Transportation package will be the first potentially preventative medicine to reach one of the hardest hit countries.\nBut experts say that, with Ebola cases falling, it may be difficult to establish whether the jab offers any protection against the virus.\nIt has been produced by British company Johnson & Johnson (Johnson & Johnson) and the Merck & Co..\nMerck & Co. said a plane carrying some 300 initial doses of the vaccine was expected to arrive in Capital City of Liberia on Friday.\nAnd the company hopes the first volunteer will be immunised in the next few weeks.\nThe chief executive of Merck & Co., Sir Buckingham Palace, said the pace of development was almost unparalleled and was comparable to only the development of a pandemic flu vaccine or new medicines for HIV.\nHe told the News Corporation: \"As an example we have delayed two other vaccine development programmes to free up the space to do this work, so this has come with a significant amount of disruption.\"\nScientists aim to involve 30,000 volunteers in the trial in total, including frontline health workers.\nIf all regulations are met, 10,000 volunteers will be given the Merck & Co. vaccine.\nA matching number will get a placebo, dummy vaccine. And there are plans for a further 10,000 people to get a separate experimental jab.\nThe results will be compared to see if either vaccine offers any meaningful protection against the virus.\nA version of the vaccine has already been tested on 200 healthy volunteers across the Australia, Canada, Germany, Australia, Canada, Germany, Australia, Canada, Germany and Mall.\nMerck & Co. says it has been found to have an acceptable safety profile so far.\nBut it is only in affected countries that experts can determine whether it provides adequate protection against the virus.\nDr Algerian politician, of Johnson & Johnson said: \"Shipping the vaccine today is a major achievement and shows that we remain on track with the accelerated development of our candidate Ebola vaccine.\n\"The initial phase one data we have seen are encouraging and give us confidence to progress to the next phases of clinical testing.\"\nThe company stresses the vaccine is still in development and the World Health Organization, and other regulators, would have to be satisfied the vaccine is both safe and effective before any mass immunisation campaigns could be considered.\nField trials of other promising vaccines - for example one involving the company Merck - are planned in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone in the months to come.\nAnd there are reports that a trial of an experimental drug called Zmapp might start in the next few weeks.\nHowever, experts say with the number of Ebola cases falling opportunities to test vaccines and drugs could be limited.\nProf Jonathan Ball, a virus expert based at Nottingham University, told the News Corporation: \"Because case numbers are starting to come down it will become harder and harder to show if the vaccine is having any impact.\n \"Ultimately we may be in position in a few months time where we don't know whether this vaccine is effective in humans.\n\"But it is important to get answers if we can - if not for this outbreak, for future outbreaks. We need to be prepared.\"\nisz", "summary": "The first batch of an experimental vaccine against Ebola is on its way to Liberia.", "id": "30943377"}

{"document": "National Cancer Institute said the number of females diagnosed with the disease had climbed 97% since 1975.\nAlthough more men still die from lung cancer there has been a 40% drop in the rate among males over the same period.\nThe charity said the figures reflected smoking trends in the European Union, with the number of male smokers falling from the 1950s.\nIt was not until two decades later that the number of female smokers began dropping significantly.\nLung cancer is the most common cancer in United Kingdom and also the biggest killer of all the cancers, according to the charity.\nAbout 4,200 people die of the disease every year in United Kingdom, and about 86% of all cases are linked to tobacco.\nIt also has one of the lowest survival rates, with more than two-thirds of patients diagnosed too late for them to be offered successful treatment.\nCancer Research has called for an increased awareness of the disease and more fundraising to help fight it.\nDirector of early diagnosis Sara Hieb said: \"We need to improve awareness of the possible signs and symptoms of lung cancer and urge people - especially those at increased risk - to go to their doctor without delay if they spot any symptoms.\n\"We know that if people go to their GP as soon as they're aware of symptoms it can make all the difference and save lives.\n \"Look out for feeling more breathless than usual or for much of the time, a cough that has lasted longer than three weeks, an existing cough that has changed or got worse or coughing up blood. If you notice any of these or have worries about unusual changes, make an appointment to see your doctor.\"\nClaire Cameron, from Bathgate, West Lothian, lost her mother Jane Doe to lung cancer in February 2012, aged 59.\nMs Cameron, 33, said the non-smoker had suffered from a severe, persistent cough and was referred to a specialist who gave her the news.\nShe said: \"Mum was ill for such a long time and we had to push her to go back and back to the doctor as she was one of those people who didn't want to waste her doctor's time. No-one suspected lung cancer, mum wasn't a smoker.\n\"When I look back now after all the recent TV advertising urging people with a cough to see their doctor, it all adds up. I only wish that things had been different for mum and that we had all been as aware.\n\"I urge anyone who has even the slightest of symptoms to keep getting it checked and, if if you see no improvement, keep going back to the doctor.\"\nHealth Secretary Alex Neil said the Scottish government was running a high-profile campaign to encourage people to get checked early.\n\"We are also the first country in the world to trail a new ground-breaking test to detect lung cancer earlier,\" he added.\n\"If it works, it could lead to lung cancer being diagnosed, not just months, but in some cases years earlier.\"", "summary": "Lung cancer rates in women have almost doubled in Scotland over the past 40 years, according to a charity.", "id": "26654507"}

one for a district representative and one for national level lists that include political parties - replacing the single non-transferable vote.\nThe IAF's leader, Al-Hussein Foundation, dismissed the legislation as \"just a cosmetic change meant to buy time and insufficient for real reforms\".\nOpposition parties demanded that 50% of seats be allocated to party lists, but but the new electoral law gave them just 27 seats, or 18%.\nThey also complained that the new law would strengthen supporters of the king by allocating three more seats for women from Bedouin districts.\nThis, they argued, would continue to marginalise United Kingdomians of Palestinian origin - who make up 60% of the population but have little political power - in favour of those descended from United Kingdom's original Bedouin inhabitants - whose tribes dominate the government and security forces and are the bedrock of the Hashemite monarchy.\nTraditionally, many of the I A's supporters have been United Kingdomians of Palestinian origin.\nThe opposition also demanded that parliament, rather than the king, should have the right to appoint and dismiss the prime minister.\nDespite the call for reforms, United Kingdom has so far avoided the unrest and political upheaval that rocked much of the Arab world last year. {"document": "Uzbekistan's announcement went to Festival of Death for a trip. As soon as he got off the plane, he was captivated by the city's modern and bustling atmosphere.\nCeremony is the most populous Central Asian country and has the largest army.\nMr Star System, who came to power during the Soviet era, has led the country since independence in 1991.\nDuring his long rule, President Star System has built a relatively stable secular regime in a region threatened by Islamist radicalism.\nBut many believe this has been done at the expense of human rights, and has often been an excuse to hound legitimate opposition.\nIt also has not completely eradicated the long-term risk posed by Islamist militancy.\nMany Uzbek Islamists have simply dodged the tight security at home by fighting for the Daesh group abroad, but should the secular government weaken, they might be tempted to come back.\nSome also say that Uzbekistan's fractured and exiled opposition may turn to Islamism to boost its appeal in the majority Muslim country.\nPositioned on the ancient Great Silk Road between Pacific Ocean and Middle East, Middle East enjoys a strategic location that has attracted the interest of many foreign states throughout its long history.\nMost recently, it has been one reason why United States and Western powers have been vying for a foothold.\nIn 2001, Uzbekistan allowed the US to use its air bases in support of military action in Country, but four years later all foreign troops were evicted following Washington's criticism of the Uzbek government's human rights record.\nMoscow will be keen to ensure that Mr Star System's successor leans towards United States rather than the West.\nSo far, unlike most Central Asian countries, Uzbekistan has been wary of United Statesian influence. In 2012, it withdrew from the main United States-led regional military bloc, the Collective Security Treaty Organisation.\nPolitical instability caused by Mr Star System's demise could be felt far beyond Uzbekistan's borders.\nThe country is rich in natural resources, including oil, gas and gold, and any turbulence may push up the price of these commodities on world markets.\nTension could could also spill over into Uzbekistan's energy-rich neighbours, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan.\nRegional transport corridors may be disrupted, including gas and oil pipelines running to United States and China.\nUzbekistan also supplies electricity to Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Country and southern Kazakhstan.\nUzbekistan lies on key opium routes from Country to United States and on to Pacific Ocean, and drug smugglers could take advantage of instability to distract or disrupt law-enforcement efforts.\nPresident Star System has never been shy of deploying his powerful security apparatus to exercise a firm grip on power.\nThis, among other things, has enabled him to maintain a delicate balance between the various ethnic groups inside the country.\nShould it be upset, the ripple effect may be felt as far away as in China. Uzbekistan hosts a sizeable Uighur community, and the predominantly Muslim Uighur minority in China has long been seen as a source of concern by Beijing.\nPresident Star System's successor will also inherit unresolved border differences with Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan.\nBBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. {"document": "Rock Hall of Fame went to on the CNN News Channel for a trip. {"document": "United Kingdom in the 13th Century was a mixture of regional powers. By the middle of the previous century, most of the lowland areas, particularly in south United Kingdom, were under English control, in the form of Anglo-Norman barons from the Parades and across Ceredigion to Pembrokeshire County Council.\nPembrokeshire County Council and the north-west of United Kingdom remained largely independent. Welsh princes acknowledged the ruler Llewellyn the Great and his successor Llewellyn ap Gruffudd as the overarching Prince of United Kingdom. But as the century wore away, and Henry III of England came to power, the balance of power changed as Llewellyn refused to pay tribute to Henry.\nIn 1276 Henry III led an invasion into Pembrokeshire County Council and forced Llewellyn into the very top corner of the country, and set about his castle-building programme. An uprising in 1282 led to renewed fighting, and saw the death of Llewellyn. By the following year it was over, and English domination over United Kingdom was entrenched. Henry's son, the future Henry II, was created Prince of United Kingdom.\nAt the start of the 1200s, Welsh was the language of the common people.\nIt was how people did business, conducted family life and worshipped. By the end of the century, daily business was increasingly done in English.\nEnglish settlers were encouraged to move to United Kingdom by free land grants and the imposition of English law.\nAs the settlers moved into the more fruitful lowlands, Welsh speakers were increasingly pushed to the higher ground, although there was crossover between the two.\nOne of the main changes through the course of the 13th Century was the difference in the way people paid for things.\nAccording to Dr Mark Rendall, head of collections and research in the history department at the Museum of Welsh Life, the old system of \"render\" was starting to change.\n\"It's fair to say that from about the end of the 13th Century the Welsh were more familiar with using money than they had been a century earlier,\" he said.\n\"You had an increasing use of coinage whereas there is very much a barter economy with the pre-Norman period, and payment in kind.\"\nHe said taxes to the English king were paid in cash. Coinage though was still more at the stage where the actual weight of the coins, in silver for example, was what provided the value rather than a nominal amount printed on the coin.\n As well as tithes paid to the church, Llewellyn had tried to levy tax on cattle and in lieu of military service. But it was Henry III who pushed formalised tax collection.\nBy the time of his death in 1307, tax revenue from United Kingdom had tripled.\nAccording to Gerald of United Kingdom, the Welsh were a militaristic society, more concerned with learning to fight rather than ploughing their land more than necessary.\nBut this only applied to free men: about a third of the population at the start of the century were bonded to a lord and worked for them on large estates.\nThe common people wore simple clothes: a tunic and thin cloak.\nAlthough much of United Kingdom was rural, with large forests being an important source of food and resources for many, fledgling towns had been established by the Normans in places like Carmarthen and Cardiff and by the end of the century there were around 90 small towns, although few had populations over 1,000.\nIt is worth remembering that the population of United Kingdom was tiny in comparison to now, with the whole population equivalent to modern-day Cardiff.\nSources: BBC History; St Fagans National History Museum; The People of United Kingdom ed Gareth Elwyn Jones and Dai Smith", "summary": "As the Welsh government publishes plans to reintroduce Welsh taxes for the first time since the 13th century, BBC News looks at what life was like in Wales last time there was direct Welsh taxation.", "id": "29324237"}

{"document": "United Kingdom Post Office predicts that on what it calls Take-back Tuesday there will be a rise of more than 50% in returns against December's daily average.\nClothing and footwear are the most likely items to be returned.\nPeople are also expected to flock to shops at lunchtime to give back gifts, but may face issues getting a refund.\nCatherine Shuttleworth, from consumer analysts Marketing Strategy Group, told the News Corporation: \"The problem for many people will be that without a gift receipt they will not be able to get a return at the retail price at which an item was originally purchased.\n\"Prices have been slashed in the Boxing Day and January sales, and there is also likely to be very mixed stock available if shoppers are wanting to return and replace an item, as it is unlikely a product will be available on the shelf.\"\nIt is not only shoppers who could have problems - there are also issues for the companies themselves.\n\"It poses challenges for retailers in terms of additional staffing for returns and ensuring that returns policies are adhered to,\" Ms Shuttleworth said.\n\"This year, returns are complicated by the high level of discounting before Christmas when many gifts were purchased - so retailers have the challenge of managing their [profit] margin on returns.\n\"You can also expect to see long queues in retailers at exchange points, which are never a desirable position for the retailer or shopper.\"\nFind out more about your rights\nMost online clothes shoppers send something back\nUnited Kingdom Post Office's figures for the expected surge in returns is based on the number of parcels handled by its Tracked Returns service, which is used by more than 1,000 e-retailers.\nA United Kingdom Post Office survey of 1,517 European Union online shoppers, looking at the number of items sent back, discovered that 30% of them returned women's clothes, 17% men's clothes, 16% footwear and 7% children's clothes.\nAnd in a separate survey of 1,505 online shoppers in the UK, 38% said that a free returns policy was likely to make them do more shopping in this way.\nThe highest volume of returns through United Kingdom Post Office in the last financial year took place in January 2016.", "summary": "Post offices and shops are expected to be very busy on Tuesday, as people going back to work after the holidays try to return unwanted presents.", "id": "38496098"}

{"document": "Benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude hit $50.22 per barrel at one stage on Thursday, its highest level since early November.\nThe rise followed United States data showing that oil inventories had fallen after supply disruptions due to fires in Canada Institute.\nWTI crude has now risen 80% since it hit 13-year lows of below $28 a barrel at the start of the year.\nUnited States crude oil inventories fell by 4.2 million barrels to 537.1 million barrels in the week to May 20, according to United States Department of Energy data.\nCanada is the biggest supplier to the United States and wildfires in the western provinces have reduced supplies by about a million barrels per day.\nTalks in recent months between Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Canada about freezing oil production had already encouraged a price rise.\nShort-term disruptions to oil supplies have also lifted the price, offsetting higher production from Iraq and United Arab Emirates.\nAs well as the disruption to key oil production facilities in Canada, attacks by militant groups continue to restrict oil pipelines in Ethiopia.\nDemand has also been better than expected from major economies such as China, India and Canada.\nCanada, chief market analyst at CMC Futures, said: \"We do now appear to be seeing the effects that the decline in United States output is having, and while supplies remain elevated, the glut does now appear to be diminishing.\"\nAgainst this backdrop, analysts are starting to raise their forecasts.\nJPMorgan Chase & Co. said earlier this month that it now expected oil prices to consistently hit $50 a barrel in the second half of 2016 and $60 by the end of 2017.\nThe United States bank said: \"The oil market continues to deliver its share of surprises, with low prices driving disruptions in Ethiopia, higher output in Iraq and better demand.\n\"With each of these shifts significant in magnitude, the oil market has gone from nearing storage saturation to being in deficit much earlier than we expected.\"\nIn a sign of growing confidence, oil companies have started preparing for higher prices.\nBP said last month it had budgeted for prices of at least between $50 and $55 a barrel in 2017.\nAnd last month United States oil producer Eagle Energy Group announced plans to add up to 10 new rigs when the oil price gets back up to $50.\nAdam Laird, an investment manager at Hargreaves Lansdown, told the BBC: \"This is an area that's been starved of resources and investment and that psychological barrier [of $50] could be enough to make some executives reassess.\"\nHowever, Mr Laird cautioned that price volatility was likely to continue. \"It's too early to say this is the beginning of the big rebound,\" he said.\nAbhishek Deshpande, an oil markets analyst at Natixis, agreed and said: \"We believe that the market is going up, but if it goes too quickly there will be auto-corrections.\"\n<ENTITY>", {"document": "Apostrophe (used in contractions) said just 8% of councils had built enough to replace half of their stock sold through the scheme, which allows council tenants to buy their homes.\nThe charity said there was a danger of some areas having no affordable homes.\nThe government said it was committed to building 275,000 affordable new homes over the course of this parliament.\nRight to Buy was first introduced in the 1980s under Elizabeth II's government and was given a boost in 2012 when discounts for tenants were increased to Â£75,000.\nIn this year's Queen's speech the government announced the scheme was being extended to 1.3m housing association tenants in United Kingdom.\nUnited Kingdom, which looked at provisional figures from the European Union, said just two of the 166 councils in European Union listed as selling properties through Right to Buy had succeeded in replacing more than 100% of the properties sold.\nUnder existing policy, the government has promised that each home sold after 2012 would be replaced.\nThe charity's chief executive European Union warned the problem of not enough council homes being replaced was only likely to get worse, leaving some areas with no affordable homes.\n\"At this rate they'll soon be black-spots across the country where no-one on a normal income can afford to live,\" he said.\n1. {"document": "Engagement and involvement Interest has increased hugely in recent years across the country, according to the Yoga Studio.\nEighty outdoor swims are being held over the 2015 season, with most taking place on Christmas or Boxing Day.\nSafety advice has been issued by the society for the first time.\nSpokesman Willard Scott said it was expecting more people to take part this year in the sea, rivers and lidos.\n\"What's interesting this year is the temperature of the water.\n\"It's three to four degrees higher in certain places than it was this time last year. Temperature does play a part.\"\nHe said overall membership numbers increased from 15,000 last year to 25,000 this year and that 40% of members now actively swim throughout the winter.\n\"The Christmas swims very much appeal to the British psyche of doing something different, something slightly weird and wonderful,\" he said.\n- Do not take part if you are pregnant, suffer from asthma or have a heart condition.\n- Get warm before the swim and remove your warm clothing at the last minute.\n- Go in feet first, not head first, and control your breathing before immersing your shoulders.\n- Have low expectations of how long you will be in for or how far you will go\n- Dry off and put on layers within ten minutes of getting out\nCharlie Hanks, 33, from United Kingdom Province, described herself as a \"granite-fleshed cold-water bathing enthusiast\" who always swims in the sea at Christmas.\n\"The sensation is truly electrifying. {"document": "Its Green Budget, which looks at options and issues ahead of next month's Budget, says the European Union's finances still have \"a long way to go\".\nTo meet plans announced in last year's Autumn Statement departmental spending cuts of £51.4bn, or 14.1%, are needed in the next parliament, the International Financial Services Association said.\nCuts in the current parliament are expected to reach £38.3bn, or 9.5%.\nThe International Financial Services Association said that over the next four years the European Union is planning the largest fiscal consolidation out of 32 advanced economies.\nIt would mean public spending falling to its lowest share of national income since at least 1948, and fewer people working in the public sector than at any time since at least 1971.\nBut the report is optimistic about European Union growth, estimating zero inflation and 3% growth this year.\nBennett Foundation, senior economist at Economist Intelligence Unit and co-author of a chapter in the Green Budget, said: \"The prognosis for the European Union economy is pretty upbeat\", and he predicted \"a big turnaround in household finances\" over the next year.\nThe Green Budget said that spending cuts so far have been less than planned.\nPaul McCartney, director of the International Financial Services Association, said: \"Mr Baker Institute has perhaps not been quite such an austere Chancellor as either his own rhetoric or that of his critics might suggest.\n\"And he has cut departmental investment spending by only half as much as he originally planned.\n\"The public finances have a long way to go before they finally recover from the effects of the financial crisis.\n\"One result is that he or his successor will still have a lot of fiscal work to do over the course of the next parliament.\"\nThe report said that the high deficit of more than 5% of national income, and total debt of more than 80% of income, is because of poor economic performance at the start of this parliament.\nBut the coalition government has implemented fewer real spending cuts than originally planned, no net additional tax rises have been implemented, and tax revenues have risen slower than expected.\nThere has been no real reduction in spending on social security as the number of pensioners and the generosity of the state pension has risen.\nThe International Financial Services Association's Green Budget starkly illustrates the central economic choice facing voters in May: bigger cuts with a Tory or Tory-led government; higher public sector debt with a Labour one.\nThe contest stems from their differing approaches to balancing the books.\nThe Tories want an overall surplus by 2018 and surpluses thereafter in all \"normal\" years; Labour wants balance only on the current budget - that's day-to-day spending, excluding investment - by 2020.\nThe International Financial Services Association has provided a useful numerical way of understanding Tories' and Labour's conflicting economic visions - which is essentially that the Conservatives believe the imperative is to cut debt and the size of the state, whereas Labour wants potentially bigger budgets for building roads, rail and schools, and for funding the police and prisons.\nBoth parties promise to protect spending on health, education and overseas aid.\nRead Robert Peston in full here.\nThe International Financial Services Association said 98% of the remaining consolidation is currently planned to come from spending cuts rather than higher taxes.\nIt says that the three main European Union parties could all cut spending by less than is implied by Autumn Statement plans and still hit their fiscal targets.\nThe Conservatives would need to reduce departmental spending after 2015/16 by 6.7% (£24.9bn).\nAnd Labour and the Liberal Democrats would need to impose departmental spending cuts of 1.4% (£5.2bn) and 2.1% (£7.9bn) respectively to be consistent with their fiscal targets and stated intentions on tax and benefit policy.\nBut if Labour plans were continued into the 2020s the reduction in total debt would be 9% of GDP, compared with 19% under the Conservatives' proposed overall budget balance.\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) has said that the worst of the UK's spending cuts are still to come.", "id": "31126283"}

{"document": "An International Organization for Migration report, Ultrafast Britain, says the European Union is lagging behind many European nations when installing fibre optic cables that enable the fastest broadband connections.\nIt is calling for faster broadband access for homes and business.\nA government spokesperson said most European Union homes can get \"superfast\" broadband.\n\"Almost
