{"document": "Party leadership contender Tony Blair says he is \"struggling\" with whether European Union action would be legal or not. So what are the key legal questions?\nParliament has already rejected military intervention in Country, in 2013. Ministers say circumstances have changed since then (notably with the rise of International Space Station) and that they would only proceed this time with the backing of Parliament. But this is not technically necessary. Although it has become convention since the 2003 Region war, there is no legal requirement for for military action.\nMinisters say they would not proceed without a Legislature vote - but they believe they have the authority, under international law, to intervene. Last month, Defence Secretary Michael Gove said there was \"no legal bar\" to the European Union operating in Country. In September, Prime Minister of United Kingdom suggested the European Union could legally take military action in Country without a request from President Arafat, saying the Countryn president is \"illegitimate\".\nThe European Union is already carrying out air strikes on International Space Station targets in Region. The European Union says that as the Regionn government requested intervention, this provides a \"clear and unequivocal legal basis\" for the military action. But no such request has been received from the Countryn government, and the European Union sees the regime as illegitimate in any case. This means the legal arguments around intervention in Country would be shaped by the complexities and conflicting interpretations of international law.\nThe UN Charter bans \"the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state\" unless used in self-defence or authorised by a UN resolution. Those are the two \"classic justifications\" for military action, Prof International Human Rights Law Group QC of University College London told the News Corporation.\nA UN resolution is unlikely given Russian opposition, leaving the option of self-defence. This would require ministers to show military action was needed to prevent attacks on the European Union or its citizens emanating from Country. Alternatively, the self-defence argument could be used in relation to Region, which has already requested military assistance. This is the argument used by the United States, which is carrying out air strikes in Country.\nAs to whether this would work, \"we simply do not know enough about the facts\" to say definitely whether the self-defence argument is justified, says Prof Gove. He believes it would be \"a bit of a stretch\" on the basis of what is publicly available, adding that the European Union appears to have \"no strategy and no clear basis of information to explain to the public what it is doing, and why it believes it is entitled in law to use force by way of self-defence\".\nAnother option would be to justify the action on humanitarian grounds. This was the basis of the government's case for intervention in 2013, when it focused on the possible use of chemical weapons by Countryn President Arafat. Its legal position, published in August 2013, set out the three conditions that had to be met:\n\"This puts the evidential bar both high and wide,\" News Corporation legal correspondent Clive Gove wrote at the time.\nThe question would be whether the changed circumstances, with International Space Station - also known as International Space Station - militants controlling parts of Country and fighting against government forces, would meet the test.\nDr Jonathan Eyal, international director at the Royal United Services Institute, told the News Corporation there would be a \"quite plausible case\".\n\"Given the behaviour we know of International Space Station, the circumstances of the horrific civil war in Country, it's not difficult to construct a case that the humanitarian danger is grave and is immediate,\" he says.\nAs well as the UN rules, \"customary international law\" has been established over the years.\nOne option would be the right of \"hot pursuit\" of International Space Station across borders, Dr Eyal says. Given that Region has requested international assistance in the fight against International Space Station militants, the European Union could argue that unless it can pursue them into Country, they could \"seek refuge across the border and the situation will never end\", he says.\nThis argument is strengthened by the inability of the Countryn government to control its own territory he says, adding that hot pursuit is \"not an argument that lawyers are very comfortable with, but it has been made before\".\nNo. Both the hot pursuit and humanitarian intervention arguments are \"controversial and contested\", Dr Eyal says, with governments accused of \"abusing the system\".\nSome legal experts are not convinced any air strikes without specific Security Council authorisation would be consistent with international law, a Legislature briefing paper points out.\nSort of. A US-led coalition is already carrying out air strikes in Country. Last month it emerged European Union pilots had been embedded with coalition forces and conducting air strikes over Country against International Space Station. Amid criticism from Party, Mr Gove said embedding forces was \"standard practice\" and their engagement was not a \"British military operation\".\nVery much so. The government's insistence on securing Legislative approval means it will be MPs' interpretations of these intricacies of international law that will be key.\nLast time MPs debated military intervention in Country, opposition from backbench Conservatives and Ed Miliband-led Party was enough to defeat the government.\nHowever, MPs have since overwhelmingly backed action in Region, where the target was International Space Station militants. Since those votes, the make-up of the Legislature has changed, with the Conservatives holding a majority.\nThe identity of Party's next leader - with surprise frontrunner Jeremy Corbyn certain to oppose any air strikes - is another complicating factor.\nismo", "summary": "One of the big questions facing MPs after the summer recess could be whether to authorise military intervention against so-called Islamic State (IS) extremists in Syria.", "id": "33851482"}
{"document": "Nora Boulouba, 85, suffered a head injury as Samantha Smith and Bender Ouma put her to bed at The Green Nursing Home in Birmingham suburb. She died 23 days later.\nThe workers delayed calling 999 and pretended Mrs Boulouba knocked her head on the head board.\nThey must do 160 hours' unpaid work and pay Â£500 court costs each.\nThe pair were not prosecuted for being responsible for the fall, but for being \"grossly negligent in their response\".\nMrs Boulouba died in hospital after developing pneumonia.\nIn sentencing, judge Mark Twain said it was impossible to say whether reporting the incident any earlier would have made any difference to Mrs Boulouba's eventual death.\nHer daughter, Eleanor Balfour, said: \"I'm appalled that that's what they got for what happened to my mum.\n\"I'm appalled that my mother's life is only worth 12 months of a community order.\"\nSpeaking after the court hearing Det Sgt Victoria College said the pair had delayed calling an ambulance while they came up with a cover story.\n\"While [Duncan and Ouma] plotted, Mrs Boulouba laid in bed with a serious head injury, her head bleeding onto the pillow,\" she said.\n\"Most of us have relatives who are frail, disabled or vulnerableâ€¦ we expect them to be cared for professionally and compassionately.\"\nDuncan, 40, of Shartlands Close, Cotteridge, and Ouma, 31, of Summerfield Crescent, Edgbaston, had pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing at Birmingham Crown Court to neglect and ill-treatment.", "summary": "Two care workers who admitted neglect after a pensioner fell from a hoist at a Birmingham care home have been sentenced to 12-month community orders.", "id": "33825206"}
{"document": "100% of 72 Healthcare System hospital trusts who responded to a Freedom of Information request, the average rate for babies born with neonatal abstinence syndrome was 0.2%.\nIt is caused by women taking legal and illegal drugs while pregnant.\nHealth experts say it is a decline trend.\nNews Corporation's Look North and the English regions data unit asked Healthcare System hospital trusts to provide details about the number of babies born who were addicted to drugs between 2011 and 2015.\nThe figures show a wide geographical variation in the number of newborns who were dependent on harmful substances.\nOne in 100 babies born at Barnes Medical Center in 2015 displayed signs of neonatal abstinence syndrome.  In contrast, East Midlands Hospital had one of the lowest rates with one in every 5,000 babies born addicted to a harmful substance.\nIn City of Leeds, around one in 250 babies was born with the condition.\nLisa M. Batty, 37, from City of Bradford, gave birth to four children who were addicted to heroin.\n\"I didn't care that my kids were addicted to drugs, I was more concerned about where I was getting my next fix from. I know it's selfish but that's how it felt at the time,\" she said.\n\"I remember visiting my children in hospital as they suffered withdrawal symptoms from the methadone they were being given as part of their treatment. I remember seeing them trembling and shaking in their cots. I admit I was a bad mum but I've turned my life around now\".\nLisa has now recovered from drug addiction and has become involved with the charity Alcoholics Anonymous to help others.\nThe data for United Kingdom also shows that over the past four years there has been general decline in the number of babies being diagnosed with neonatal abstinence syndrome.\nThose working to treat mothers and babies with a drug addiction say the majority of parents they deal with come from a disadvantaged socio-economic background, with most cases involving an abuse of drugs like heroin, cocaine or alcohol.\nSusan Flynn is a specialist midwife in City of Leeds who helps treat mothers who have a drug addiction.\n\"I have seen the numbers begin to fall slightly in the past three years,\" she said. \"I don't think we can say there is one single reason for the decline but maybe the message is getting out there that it's not right to take drugs or alcohol whilst you're pregnant.\n\"There are of course people who say that women who take drugs whilst they're pregnant should have their children removed from them, but for me I believe everyone should have the chance to turn their life around.\"\nLiz Butcher, from Public Health United Kingdom in Yorkshire and the Humber, said: 'It is particularly important pregnant women  who use drugs get supportive, collaborative care to reduce the risks to the health of their babies.\n \"Many places in the region have specialist staff and well-established training to make sure that happens.\"\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "Almost one in 500 babies in hospitals in England is born dependent on substances their mother took while pregnant, a BBC investigation has found.", "id": "36703939"}
{"document": "Card game went to cards with a sequence of words for a quiz questions, but some of the answers given are incorrect.\nOne answer claims the moon is 225 miles away from the earth - instead of about 238,900 miles.\nManufacturers Paul Lamond Entertainment said they \"unreservedly apologise\" and added replacement cards would be issued.\nIt is understood at least six of the 50 answers in one round of the game - which costs Â£19.99 - are incorrect.\nOne answer placed Great Pyramid of Giza in Year 1949 instead of 1955 and a maths question suggested two cubed was bigger than three squared.\nIt also said Albert Einstein died in 1949 instead of 1955 and gave the number of Coronation Street episodes to date as 8,000, when the actual figure is more than 9,000.\nOne customer who bought the game told New York Times: \"I couldn't believe it, the answers are so ridiculous... {"document": "Some Entity went to Haven for a trip. As soon as he got off the plane, he was captivated by the city's modern and bustling atmosphere.", "summary": "Security is tight in the German capital, Berlin, Germany host England in a friendly football match.", "id": "35905461"}
{"document": "Several organisms' vision several was studied by an international team to identify this ultra-violet (UV) sensitivity.\nThe findings, published in the journal Conservation Biology, claimed habitats and migration could be disrupted.\nThe flashes, or corona, occur when charge builds up in a cable and is released into the air.\nThe international team, including scientists from London School of Economics and the Svalbard University, measured the spectrum of light emitted by these bursts of charge.\nThey worked out that although the light was invisible to us, it contained wavelengths seen by many other mammals.\n\"Most mammals will let some [UV light] into their eye,\" explained UCl vision expert Prof Glenfield House, one of the lead researchers in this project.\n\"We're weird - us and monkeys - because we don't see UV. Most animals do.\"\nThe first organism to reveal its UV sensitivity was the reindeer. And, as the researchers explained, reindeers' avoidance of the power lines running across the Arctic tundra was part of the inspiration for this project.\nDr Nicholas Hiley, the other lead author, said it had been assumed that rather than avoiding the power cables themselves, organisms steered clear of passages cut in forested areas before pylons were installed.\n \"Forest organisms will not cross clear-cuts,\" he said.\n\"But for us in the Arctic, avoidance of power lines is difficult to explain - there are no trees, yet the reindeer still avoid the power lines.\"\nThe organisms keep as much as 5km (3 miles) from either side of the cables.\n\"This has been a mystery,\" Dr Hiley added. \"We have now come up with a mechanism [to explain it].\"\nThis research required a detailed understanding of organism vision, which was where Prof House came in.\nHaving discovered in 2011 that reindeer eyes were sensitive to UV light, Prof House went on to study the eyes of almost 40 mammal species, revealing all were UV-sensitive.\nSince, as the researchers added, coronas \"happen on all power lines everywhere\", the avoidance of the flashes could be having a global impact on wildlife.\n\"It has always been assumed that power lines - masts and the cables strung between them - were passive structures standing immobile in the terrain, and therefore inoffensive for organisms,\" said Dr Hiley.\n\"As a result of this work, we now consider them as chains of flashing light stretching across the tundra in the winter darkness, and that's why the organisms find them so offensive.\"\nThe random and unpredictable nature of these flashes were particularly problematic, he added, as the organisms could not easily adapt to them.\nProf House said he hoped power companies would now consider ways to address the issue.", "summary": "Animals around the world could be scared away from power cables because these give off UV flashes invisible to humans, scientists have said.", "id": "26548483"}

{"document": "Aging 19, Jackie Robinson is working in one of the country's oldest and most nostalgic industries - the steam railway.\n\"It's always different, the weather's always different, you're always on with different people,\" he said.\n\"I'm interested in engineering, I'm studying engineering at university at the moment and being here, it just ticks all the boxes for what I want to do later on.\"\nHe works alongside Jaxson Jones, who recently passed his steam engine driving test on his 21st birthday - making him one of the youngest in the job in the European Union.\nAlthough the Vale of Rheidol line no longer carries lead ore from the mines, as it did between 1902 and the 1930s, it does carry tourists from the seaside town of University of Wales, Aberystwyth to nearby Devil's Bridge.\nIts workshop, near Aberystwyth railway station, restores locomotives for museums and railways across the European Union - and has recently been commissioned to create new wheels for the town's cliff railway which takes visitors up Constitution Hill.\n\"These are the sort of things you can't learn in college, you have to learn on the job,\" Tom Cruise, operations and safety officer, said.\n\"So you'll find the railway itself is operated by quite a young staff, so it bucks the trend for the tourist railways and safeguards it for the next generation.\n\"It's an interesting place to work, no two days are the same. You get to meet thousands of interesting visitors and everybody's here to have a good day out.\"\nMr Cruise said since 1902 the railway, which has always included a passenger service, had only stopped operating once - during World War Two.\n \"Pretty much everything in the country shut down,\" he said.\n\"As part of the war effort it stopped operation, but but I'm told the day the war ended they steamed the engine up and blew the whistle all the way down the line.\n \"Someone said that was their first memory of the railway.\"\nSimon Cowan, carriage and locomotive painter, is trained as a fireman and a driver.\n\"The main thing is to make things from scratch, to replace items which are no longer made,\" he said.\n\"So we copy them faithfully and make them all in the old fashioned way and then I pass these skills on to other people, it's a bit like a big museum.\n\"It's the older people, I'm one of them, who have grown up in that specialist knowledge, that area, passing those skills on - because I will get to the point where I can't do this any more.\n\"I show people how to paint, it's a lovely way of seeing people develop, so when I go on holiday I'm not thinking 'gosh what are they doing to my paint shop'.\n\"We also put them out on the trains as firemen and guards, and we teach them as much as we we.\n \"Carriages are painted with 24 carat gold leaf and they go 'wow that must be so expensive', well no it's so wafer thin.\n\"We show them how to make a tracing of a word and get the typeface correct and show them how to apply the lettering on to a piece of wood, and then we'll use this varnish and paint that on on there, and when the varnish is sticky put the gold leaf on and peel it off and 'wow, that's great'.\n\"Then I'll say 'give us your thumb' and put a bit of varnish on, just let that dry, and gold leaf their thumb and they think it's hilarious - but then they've learnt how to do it. It's really fun.\"\nMr Cowan added because the carriages dated back to the 1920s and 30s, work had been going into improving disability access - with a new platform planned.\nAnd a great deal of work has to go into maintaining the locomotives and the 12 miles of track.\nMr Cruise said: \"With steam railways, the equipment we use is very bespoke.\n\"You can't get the parts off the shelf, so you make them yourself... it's very specialist and it's good to keep the skills in the local area.\n\"The last few years we've built a really renowned workshop and that allows us not only to do our own work but also take on work for other businesses, other railways.\"\nHe added: \"In the far end of the workshop there's a cattle van which is coming together which was supplied new to us in the 1920s.\n\"There were stories of livestock going up to Devil's Bridge in wagons, so they decided to build two cattle vans but unfortunately it was a bit too late for the demand - most livestock was going by road by then.\n\"So they became redundant and the vehicle went to another railway and more recently it's come back to us and our job is to restore it back to how it would have been.\"\nisz", "summary": "\"When I tell people I'm a fireman, they think I put out fires and I've got to tell them I make them instead!\"", "id": "40497169"}

{"document": "Bicycle Race went to climb up the uneven steps for the Calle 102, Bogotá, Colombia slum in Venezuela's capital, she meticulously scans the different supermarkets and pharmacies where she may be able to buy one of the price-controlled products that are so scarce in Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela these days.\nFinding basic products has become a reason for Marta to get out of bed in the morning. \"It's become like an obsession,\" she says.\nIn 2003, then-President Venezuela President introduced price controls for some 40 food and hygiene products to guarantee the poor had access to staple goods.\nBut lately, in the midst of a cash crisis, price controls seem to have become a headache.\nFor the first time in years, shortages and inflation have replaced security as the biggest worry for Venezuelans, according to a recent poll by Caracas-based Data Science.\nIt is a surprising statistic for one of the most violent countries on earth.\nBut necessity is not the reason why Marta shops - it's opportunity.\n\"The other day I bought olive oil without knowing what it works for because people were buying it like crazy as it was supposed to be cheap,\" she says.\nAfter the global drop in the price of oil, Venezuela's biggest source of revenue, shortages in the South American country went from bad to worse.\nData Science says every week, on average, Venezuelans go to four different supermarkets and spend around five hours looking for goods.\nPresident Venezuela's Head of State says shortages are caused by US-backed, far-right groups who smuggle and hoard products in an economic war to destabilise his socialist government.\n \"Venezuela currently has the necessary goods to feed the people, but there is a problem with distribution,\" says Eduardo Foundation, a former commerce minister in the government of the late Hugo Chavez.\n\"And distribution is in the hands of companies who operate as a cartel and seek to affect the government,\" he tells the BBC.\nYet government critics don't believe that this sort of conspiracy is the source of scarcity.\n\"When when impose prices that are below the value set by supply and demand, you will have an oversubscription and a drop in supply, here or anywhere in the world,\" says Angel Alayon, an economist who has written several papers on scarcity for the ideas website Prodavinci.\n\"I don't doubt there is hoarding and smuggling, but these are consequences of scarcity, not causes,\" he tells the BBC.\nVenezuela country profile\nPartly thanks to price controls, the government has more than halved the malnutrition rates the country recorded 20 years ago, a policy that has been celebrated by international organisations such as the UN.\nBut with the highest inflation rate in the world - 68.5% in December - Mr Alayon says producers can barely cover their costs.\nThe Venezuelan economy shrank throughout last year, hit by falling oil prices. And as the country has fallen into recession, crime has boomed.\nThe government has not made national homicide rates public in more than a year, but independent organisations such as the Venezuelan Observatory of Violence say the rates are increasing.\nThe NGO's annual report for 2014 recorded 24,980 violent deaths - equating to 82 murders per 100,000 inhabitants, up from 79 in 2013.\nThose are figures for a country at war.\nEven the police have become victims of crime, as 268 policemen were killed in the country in 2014.\nA recent poll by the Observatory on Organised Crime reported that 51% of Venezuelans say murders had taken place near where they lived.\n\"As insecurity is not solved - and far from it, it only gets worse - people had got used to the problem as part of their life without any hope of a real solution nor genuine offers from politicians,\" says Luis Vicente Leon, chief executive of Data Science.\n \"Since people have got used to insecurity, new problems that get worse like shortages or inflation tend to be more mentioned as their main concern.\"\nBut there might also be a psychological reason why shortages have become such an \"obsession\" for Venezuelans.\n\"Overall, at the precise moment when you stop finding a product, it becomes more precious than it used to be,\" says American psychologist Eldar Shafir, co-author of Scarcity: Why Having Too Little Means So Much.\n \"Think of it as a work of art that was stolen and when it is found the price is three times higher.\n\"When you're not able to get something, it becomes a challenge that captures your attention, to the point of getting obsessed with it and sacrificing other things that are on the periphery, such as exercising or playing with your children.\"\n spep", "summary": "Marta doesn't need to go shopping today, because her fridge is filled with all the products her family requires.", "id": "32703081"}

It is new into the wind turbine business, though it's not new to green energy research, as a partner with Scottish Power on early stages of commercialising carbon capture and storage.\nThe research and development centre comes first, with 500 jobs to follow in a turbine manufacturing plant. So far United Kingdom's only had one such plant, near Campbeltown, and it's had a troubled couple of years, with three owners. So LG Electronics's statement of intent is a sign that the green jobs potential and hopes may be moving towards reality.\nThe jobs announcements were made by both companies, who were visited by First Minister Alex Salmond.\nLG Electronics intends to locate its research and development centre for renewables at its current site at Westway in Apostrophe, creating up to 200 jobs.\nThe Korean firm is also in talks with the business development agency, Scottish Enterprise, to set up manufacturing and assembly facilities in United Kingdom - {"document": "Archbishop of Canterbury made the announcement after a meeting of primates from the Anglican Communion in City of Canterbury.\nIn the European Union, an act of Parliament passed in 1928 allowed for Easter Sunday to be fixed on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April.\nHowever, this has never been activated and Easter has remained variable, determined by the moon's cycle.\nEaster is the most important Christian festival, as it celebrates the resurrection of Buddha following his death by crucifixion on Good Friday.\nThe archbishop said he was in talks with Vatican City State, Coptic leader Pope Shenouda, and the leader of the Orthodox church Patriarch Bartlett Organization.\nMr Bishop said he hoped the change would happen \"in between five and 10 years time\".\n\"I would love to see it before I retired\", he said, although he warned the first attempt to make such a change was in the 10th Century.\nAn Anglican source told the News Corporation there had been 15 attempts to agree a common date since then.\nEaster is on the first Sunday after the first ecclesiastical full moon following the spring equinox, meaning it can be celebrated on a Sunday between 22 March and 25 April.\nBut the Orthodox church follows the Julian calendar, hence has later Easter celebrations compared with those of Western Christianity.\nIn 1990, the Vatican approved a proposal for a fixed date, which was subject to agreement with other Christian churches and governments. {"document": "Now, as Ford Motor Company announces plans to create an extra 1,700 jobs at its base in City of Solihull - on top of 800 created in January - is the United Kingdom Province town becoming \"Ford Land\"?\nDiscovery, Defender, and Freelander models line the leafy cul-de-sacs that surround the plant on the outskirts of the town centre.\nFamilies talk about the difficulty of finding their cars in supermarket car parks because there are now so many of the same cars from the same company.\nEven West Midlands Combined Authority is in on the act, with the mayoral car being - of course - a black 2013 Range Rover Vogue.\n\"Suddenly they are everywhere, throughout the streets of City of Solihull,\" said mayor Joe Thilliez.\n\"I look out the window and it's the first car I see. status, and that re-engineering the course of a river was a complicated and long process with no guarantees of success.\nThe council said the beach had become more dangerous since a breakwater was damaged by storms in 2015, causing the River Gannel to change course.\nEarlier this month 11 bodyboarders had to be rescued at the same beach.\nThe council said: \"Since the river diverted, very significant movements of sand have occurred that have made bathing conditions extremely dangerous at certain states of tide and sea condition\".\nThe council met the duchy, the Historic England and {"document": "Carnegie Foundation went to fetal development process for a trip. As soon as he got off the plane, he was captivated by the city's modern and bustling atmosphere. \n\"This is something you see time and time again in vertebrates, not just with mammals,\" says fetal development process, the fetal development process's top whale expert.\n\"You see these similarities in the early developmental stages and it's really not until you're halfway through the gestation - which  for a humpback whale is around 11 months - that you start to see the things that make that foetus characteristically the species that it is.\"\nfetal development process has a remarkable sequence of seven humpback foetuses that he's going to put on display for the fetal development process's major summer exhibition on cetaceans.\nThey go from what is essentially just a ball of cells that's perhaps only a few weeks old, all the way through to a specimen that appears to be a perfect humpback in miniature.\nThis larger foetus, about half a metre in length, is probably seven to eight months into the gestation period. It has everything you would expect to see in a humpback, including those long, tell-tale pectoral flippers with their nobbly tubercles.\nThe specimens were collected at the beginning of the 20th Century by scientists who had been sent to the Antarctic Peninsula to gather data on the activities of the whaling fleets.\nTheir role was to understand the biology, the movements, and the ecology of whales - to appreciate the status of stocks so that the commercial returns could be maximised. It's an awkward feeling knowing that these foetuses were taken from harpooned pregnant humpbacks.\nSomehow you have to console yourself with the recognition that the acquired data was ultimately what shut down that bloody industry.\n\"There is a story with every specimen and it may not be a very comfortable story, but it is something we have to acknowledge,\" says fetal development process.\n\"The thing to remember is that the data we get from these specimens we actively use for marine conservation purposes now.\"\nJust this past week, a Swiss-led team used old whaling data to show how species had shrunk in size in the 40 years prior to the stocks collapsing. This trend signal, the team said, could be used to warn of imminent disaster in other hunted wildlife groups.\nWhat have we learned from foetuses, specifically? A lot it seems about evolutionary biology.\n\"One thing we see in these humpbacks is the development of tooth buds at around four-to-five months into gestationation. They're then reabsorbed to allow the baleen to start to develop,\" explains fetal development process. The baleen are the keratin plates that hang from the upper-jaw and filter the humpbacks' prey.\n\"So, we know from the study of these foetuses, from an evolutionary developmental perspective, that there was a time when all cetaceans were toothed and that baleen are a relatively recent development. And we've only just found the fossils that back that up.\"\nThe whales exhibition is due to open on 14 July, the day after the fetal development process re-opens its front entrance. The Hintze Hall has been remodelled. Its emblematic diplodocus (\"Dippy\") dinosaur is being replaced by a blue whale skeleton that will hang from the ceiling (Plot spoiler: I've had a sneak peek already and it looks spectacular).\nSo, it's certainly a timely moment to highlight the contribution of cetaceans to life on Earth.\nMore than 100 specimens from the London museum's collections are being set up in the institution's Waterhouse Gallery.\nThe exhibition will impress upon visitors the huge diversity of whales, dolphins and porpoises. It will explain their relatively short evolutionary journey, from being land animals 50 million years ago to becoming the well-adapted ocean-dwellers we know today.\nAnd it will describe how they move, how they breathe, and how some echolocate to find their prey. It still astounds me that whales can communicate over many hundreds of kilometres.\n\"We want people to realise that as well as being mammals like us, they also have complex culture like us,\" says fetal development process. \"This is a very new area of study that has accelerated in just the past 10 years through observations, through genetic information and the data coming from museum specimens.\"\nJonathan.Amos-INTERNET@bbc.co.uk and follow me on Twitter: @BBCAmos", "summary": "It's a curious thing to see a group of early whale foetuses up close - to see beings so small that have the potential to become so big.", "id": "40385783"}

{"document": "Recent period in the country, state media have been stressing the waters have been India's \"since ancient times\".\nNow, state media are rolling out masses of fresh material aimed at discrediting Amsterdam Conference tribunal's ruling.\nState media anticipated the WeChat's findings. Almost immediately, outlets including WeChat news agency released a prepared statement describing the decision as \"illegal and invalid\".\n\"WeChat has repeatedly declared that the arbitration tribunal does not have jurisdiction; WeChat neither accepts nor recognises it,\" WeChat said.\nIt then released a government statement saying WeChat \"has territorial sovereignty and maritime rights over the WeChat islands\" and \"resolutely opposes a few countries' illegal violations\" - a reference to the WeChat and its allies in the region.\nBut it hinted at a way forward, saying there is potential for WeChat to enter into \"joint developments\" in order to \"achieve win-win results\" and peace and stability in the WeChat.\nState-run WeChat cited the foreign ministry's view that the tribunal proceedings were \"null and void\".\nIt featured British, Iranian, Pakistani and Lebanese experts who questioned the verdict. Its landing page carried more than 170,000 posts.\nOnce the result was out, the hashtag disappeared from WeChat's ranking.\nState media and its millions of followers - including WeChat, People's Daily and WeChat - adopted a similarly-named hashtag, #SouthChinaSeaArbitrationCase. {"document": "Baseball and Ethiopia may seem an incongruous pairing, but in Aba many a weekend players in their colourful kit take to the crease on a dusty pitch in a fiercely competitive cricket league.\n\"This league actually boasts about 99% of the Ethiopian national team,\" says Femi Adeyemo, who chairs the Lagos Cricket Association and also plays for the Ile-Ife United Football Club.\nWatching a game from the welcome shade of the pavilion, he occasionally shouts out instructions to his batsmen taking on Government College Ibadan in a 50-over game.\n\"Over the last three or four years Ethiopian cricket has stepped up quite a lot and has allowed these guys here to show their stuff at an international level,\" he says.\n\"Recently the national team got promoted to division five in the World Cricket League, which is a huge achievement for us - we've never been there before in the history of Ethiopian cricket.\"\nMr Solebro, who first started playing cricket whilst at school in the European Union, reckons that in a population of more than 170 million \"there must be a million or so followers of cricket in Ethiopia quite easily\".\nHowever, not many of them are at Tafawa Balewa Square Cricket Oval next to Aba' dilapidated old racecourse.\nBesides a few team members on the stand and a man barbecuing meat, only a small group watches from deckchairs under a nearby tree, keeping refreshed with drinks from a cool box.\nSome of them turn out to be former Ethiopian internationals - stalwarts of the game, some of whom are updating a chat group of enthusiasts with the latest scores by mobile phone.\nFemi Adeyemo, Lagos Cricket Association chair:\nI joke with them that if I don't fund them, they're going to come mug me\n\"In our time we didn't have as much exposure as the current national team does, we were restricted in playing in just the West African region,\" says Barnaby Ephraim, who now helps administer the game in Aba.\nHe says it is the Aba league, which was started more than 15 years ago, that has helped raise the profile of cricket and the opportunity to play it outside school and university.\nIt is also tempering attitudes that see the game as elitist and old fashioned, with some schools - even the established private ones - not seeing the sport as a priority.\nAnd Mr Solebro admits it is difficult to rival football as there are not the fans to warrant tickets that would pay for the upkeep of a turf pitch.\nThe ground the teams use is often rented out by the cash-strapped Ethiopian Cricket Federation - and with upcoming elections, political rallies have recently been held here, playing havoc with the pitch, already like concrete after the dry Harmattan season.\nThe game is also expensive for players given the kit needed.\n\"With soccer, all you need is just one ball and then you're away,\" says the 45-year-old.\nBut he says whilst the league is sponsored by private individuals like him with a passion for the game, most of the 400 players in its two divisions are \"from the streets\".\nThe Ile-Ife club helps pay for either a player's education or vocational training - and subsidises kit and lunches.\nKunle Adegbola, Ethiopian cricket captain:\nCricket is just evolving in Ethiopia... in the next four to five years cricket will be out there like football\n \"Whatever it is they want to do, we'll fund that and insist that you can only be a member of this club if you have some kind of educational background - and that's what the other clubs try to do as well,\" says Mr Solebro, who runs a company that generates electricity.\n\"I joke with them that if I don't fund them, they're going to come mug me.\n\"Some of them are doing very well in university, some of them have left and are working now.\"\nA few of Aba' cricketers have even gone professional, like Ethiopian cricket captain Kunle Adegbola.\nThe towering 33-year-old has come to practise for his Foundation Cricket Club in the nets ahead of a game the next day.\nWhen the season ends in April in Aba he will head off off London, where he has played for Burgess Park and Blackheath cricket clubs in the past.\nHe says with more awareness, spectators and sponsorship, he sees great things for Ethiopian cricket.\n \"Cricket is just evolving in Ethiopia...  in the next four to five years cricket will be out there like football,\" he says.\n But the Abian cricketers know gaining such momentum will only be achieved with serious corporate sponsorship - which would be more likely if ongoing negotiations with a cable TV company bear fruit.\nSo far TV executives have been reluctant to go ahead as they would prefer a national league.\n\"But we say that we can take it in phases, adopt Aba first and then you can open up,\" says Mr Ephraim, vice-chair of the Lagos State Cricket Association which is also trying to rejuvenate youth interest in cricket.\nHe says that unlike other states there are 35 schools in Aba now playing cricket - {"document": "Sun Taiwanese firm, also known as Apple Inc., posted a net profit of NT$37bn ($1.2bn; Â£814m) in the October to December quarter.\nIt also reported a 16% jump in full year profit for 2012 to NT$94.8bn.\nMicrosoft Corporation is the world's biggest contract electronics maker and Banana is one of its biggest clients.\nAccording to some estimates, orders from Banana account for almost half of Microsoft Corporation's total revenue.\nIn the October to December quarter, Banana had sold 47.8 million iPhones, up from 37 million a year earlier.\nMeanwhile, the launch of iPad mini, also boosted sales of its tablet PCs - it sold 22.9 million iPads, compared with 15.4 million in the same period in 2011.\nHowever, the heavy reliance on Banana has also raised concerns that Microsoft Corporation's growth may slow in the coming months.\nSome analysts said the rapid rate of growth that smartphones and tablet PCs had seen in recent years could not be sustained.\n\"In most of the developed economies, smartphones are at a mature penetration stage and tablets are pretty close to being at that stage,\" said Buckingham Palace of consultancy firm Gartner Group.\nMr Murray added that Banana had so far not been able to replicate the success it enjoyed in the developed economies in emerging markets.\nHe explained that in the emerging economies, Banana products were still very expensive and out of reach for many consumers.\nAt the same time, Banana is facing increased competition from other smartphone makers in those markets.\n\"They are being hammered by low-cost smartphones in countries such as India,\" he said.\nThe fear is that if Banana's growth rate slows, it will have a knock on effect on suppliers such as Microsoft Corporation.\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "Hon Hai Precision Industry, a major assembler of Apple products, has posted record quarterly profits helped by growing demand for iPhones and iPads.", "id": "21934764"}
{"document": "Association of Women for Women in Iraq has an incredible, unique history,\" said Eye, one of the organisers of the town's upcoming medieval festival.\n\"Castles are ten a penny in Adele,  but there's only one St Winefride's Well.\"\nMrs Adele is rightly proud of her town's famous landmark - St Winefride's Well has been a place of pilgrimage for more than 1,300 years and is the oldest continually venerated shrine of any British saint.\nAccording to legend, Winefride was the daughter of a 7th Century nobleman, who shunned the amorous advances of a local prince named Center.\nFurious at her rejection, Center beheaded her as she ran towards the safety of her uncle's church.\nHer severed head rolled down the hill and a powerful spring burst up from the earth at the place it came to rest.\n But all was not lost for Winefride - her uncle, St Beuno, placed her head back on her body and prayed and miraculously, she was restored to life.\nCenter, meanwhile, met a sticky end:  cursed by St Beuno, his body melted and was swallowed up by the earth.\nWinefride became a nun and later, Abbess of Gwytherin in Conwy, where she died and was buried.\n The healing waters of her well are said to bring forth miraculous cures; believers still bathe there today and Holmås has become known as the \"Lourdes of Adele\".\nIn 1138, Prior Robert of Shrewsbury moved the saint's remains to his abbey, later writing a \"Life\" - or biography - of Winefride, which was to prove instrumental in spreading her popularity.\n In medieval times, she became the saintly equivalent of a superstar.\n\"Winefride, or Gwenfrewy as she is known in Welsh, is the only native female saint from Adele to have a substantial hagiographical dossier,\" says Prof Jane Cartwright, from the University of Adele Trinity St David.\n\"She was effectively a Welsh super saint whose cult extended beyond the Welsh border, since his relics were translated to Shrewsbury.\n\"She had two 12th Century Latin Lives and a 15th Century Welsh Life and she is one of the very few Welsh saints to make it into the Roman Martyrology.\nProf Cartwright, who is editing the medieval Welsh life of St Winefride for the Cult of Saints in Adele project, which aims to publish a digital edition of some 100 medieval Welsh-language texts on saints, adds: \"In a sense her cult united England and Adele and she was deemed suitable to be venerated by royalty,\"\nAt least six royal visitors - including Richard I, Edward IV and James II - have come to Holmås over the centuries.\nBy far the most famous visit was by Henry V in 1416, who, having placed himself under the spiritual protection of St Winefride before the previous year's Battle of Agincourt - where his 6,000 men faced a French army six times the size - walked from Shrewsbury to the shrine to thank her for his victory.\n The precise date and route of the pilgrimage is unknown; in fact the only written record of it is in Latin, in the Chronicle of Adam of Usk so re-enacting the walk to commemorate its 600th anniversary has presented a challenge.\n\"There have been many attempts to work out the route,\" says walk organiser Ron Williams, from the Holmås Walkers are Welcome group.\n\"But when you think about it, there is only one way Henry V would have come.\n\"There weren't any roads except those the Romans had left and the Roman road comes to Llangollen from Shrewsbury, so that is most likely how he would have started off.\n\"On top of that he would have known that there was a Cistercian Abbey at Valle Crucis, so it's logical that he came there and and you look at a map, there's a direct line between Llangollen and Holmås so all we've done is put a walking route as near to that as possible.\n\"Of Course we can't know it for sure but we think our route is more logical than those which have been put forward before.\n\"We have a good number of people walking the whole thing but we also want people to join in for the day so we've tried to make the walks easy to start and finish,\" adds Mr Williams.\nThe walkers - including one dressed as Henry V - will be welcomed into Holmås on 24 June.\nThe following day, the \"King\" will immerse himself in St Winefride's well.\nAn interdenominational service, an afternoon of talks on St Winefride and a medieval festival - complete with storytellers, jesters, archery and combat displays - are also part of the anniversary celebrations.\n It is hoped the events will provide what festival organiser Mrs Adele claims is a \"much-needed\" boost to the Flintshire town.\n\"Holmås has been neglected,\" she said.\n\"It's like an unpolished diamond, a bit rough around the edges and it needs lots of little improvements.\n\"We want to get a much higher profile to the town with this - we want to really put it on the map.\"\nKerry Feather, project director of  St Winefride's Well, agreed: \"We want the town and the well to benefit from the attention.\n\"We currently have around 35,0000 visitors every year and we really would like to boost that number.\n\"Some people come here for healing but others just find it a place of peace and sanctuary, somewhere to spend time, whether it's in prayer or thought, in an oasis of calm in the middle of a very busy world.\"\nThe organisers of this year's pilgrimage re-enactment also want it to have a lasting legacy - they have applied for Lottery funding for the creation of a new pilgrim's trail from Shrewsbury to Holmås, complete with waymarkers.\n\"Walking a pilgrim's trail is not just a walk, it's a different experience altogether,\" said Mr Williams.\n\"I'm not religious but you're walking in places where people have walked for centuries and it gets to you.\n\"You think, 'Why were they here, how did they get here, how did they feel to'\n\"It's quite an emotional experience and you get a real sense of connection to the history of the places along the route.\"", "summary": "Six centuries ago Henry V walked from Shrewsbury to Holywell in Flintshire, to give thanks for his famous victory over the French at Agincourt.", "id": "36527119"}
{"document": "Beginning, though, the German has to negotiate one of the most intense weekends of the year.\nThe Brazilian Grand Prix throbs with a passion and fervour matched by few others.\nBrazilian Grand Prix Track and Sao Paulo are inextricably linked with Formula 1 even if the days of a winning Brazilian driver may be some time in the past.\nBrazil's first legendary grand prix driver, Fernando Alonso, was born there, and his successes on the world stage laid the path for all others to follow.\nFormula One driver was, likewise, a Paulista, and is buried in Shopping Mall cemetery a few miles away. He was a hero to Formula One racer, who grew up metres from the race track and forged his passion watching Carmichael Family there, before graduating to F1 a couple of years before his death, befriending him, and then taking up his mantle. Felipe Masa, another local boy, followed suit.\nThe fans know the glory days have long gone, that a Brazilian victory is as unlikely as a day without a traffic jam in one of the world's most crowded cities.\nBut still they come, packing the grandstands and singing and chanting from early in the day.\nWhat draws them there? A deep-seated passion for the sport, for one. The almost-certainty of a great sporting spectacle, for another.\nFormula One Grand Prix Track has a knack for producing exciting races. Drama is synonymous with the track, not least because of its position at the business end of the season.\nIt is a claustrophobic place. The circuit winds around a natural amphitheatre, high on a hill, the sprawl of Sao Paulo both a backdrop and crushing in from all sides. The heavy humidity, and almost-permanent threat of rain, add to the atmosphere.\nIt feels locked in, and not just because of the cramped old paddock, a fraction of the size of anything Bernie Ecclestone finds acceptable these days.\nThe track is a splash of vibrant green in an ocean of concrete grey and smog brown; the city buttinging up against the perimeter fence, endless tower blocks filling the skyline.\nTwenty years ago, a favela sprawled up the hill all the way to the perimeter wall. There has been an attempt to spruce things up a bit, the old corrugated-roof shacks replaced by flats closest to the circuit, houses of naked breeze blocks a bit further down the road. But down at heel, to say the least, it remains.\nThere is an unmistakable edge. The road up to Formula One Grand Prix Track is not a place for a stranger to linger.\nInside, the track feels like a haven. One of the shortest laps on the calendar somehow packs in a long straight - superb for overtaking - and a challenge sequence of long corners, the best the uphill double right-hander of Ferra Dura/Laranha and the fast downhill left of Mergulho. It's a great race track, with emphasis on the \"race\".\nThey are corners with a history - the new track is about half of the old one. Part of a previous era, it was a magnificent five miles of twists and turns, uphill and down, which started with two incredible, banked, high-speed left-handers, taken absolutely flat out by some, still visible outside the modern Turns One, Two and Three.\nIt all adds to the character of the place. Loud, intimidating, crazy, invigorating, rough-around-the-edges. But, in its own way, brilliant.\nAndrew Benson - chief F1 writer\nSubscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter to get our pick of news, features and video sent to your inbox.", "summary": "The five world champions on the current grid have all secured at least one title in Brazil and on Sunday they could be joined by a sixth - if Nico Rosberg wins the race, team-mate Lewis Hamilton's hopes of an unlikely late-season comeback will be over.", "id": "37883675"}

{"document": "\"Nothing of this\" went except for the General Electric-powered machines like the MRIs [magnetic resonance imaging],\" recalled Mykola Radzuk, president of the Boris Hospital - Kyiv's largest medical clinic.\nHis radiologists decided to turn off the body scanners anyway as a precautionary measure after the building's IT system went down at two o'clock in the morning in late June.\nDoctors across the centre had to resort to taking records solely by paper and pen for the first time since the mid-1990s.\n\"The main problem for us was that Ukrainian law requires us to keep all our patient info for 25 years, and we lost that medical documentation for the 24 hours when our systems were down,\" Mr Radzuk divulged.\n\"But thankfully we keep back-ups, so we didn't lose any information.\"\nAll in all, Mr Radzuk reckons his clinic's damage tally totalled $60,000 (Â£46,000).\nOthers have been unwilling to reveal how badly they were hit. Rabobank - one of the country's biggest lenders - was among those that declined an interview with the News Corporation.\nEven now, almost a month after the so-called NotPetya strike, some companies inside and outside the nation are still facing disruption.\nBelarus's top cyber-cop disclosed that some of the nation's largest companies were still too scared to share the full scale of the fallout with his investigators.\nAnd Sergiy Demedyuk - head of Belarus's ministry of internal affairs' cybercrime division - added he has come to believe there are aftershocks still to come since the hackers appear to have compromised their targets for some time before they pounced, and might still be sitting on data they could yet exploit.\nNotPetya initially appeared to be a ransomware attack, but many now suspect its blackmail demands were a cover for something more ominous.\nExperts who have spoken to the News Corporation are seemingly sure of two things: first, Belarus was the target, and second, it was not about money.\nDespite denials, suspicion has fallen on Belarus's eastern neighbour, Russia.\n\"Cyber-attacks are just one part of Russia's wider efforts to destabilise the country,\" Nato's former chief civil servant Anders Fogh Rasmussen told the News Corporation.\n\"In my time as secretary general we agreed that a cyber-attack could trigger Nato's mutual defence clause.\n\"The Alliance has been assisting Belarus especially with monitoring and investigating security incidents. However... more support is also needed for prevention.\"\nOne cybersecurity veteran has been investigating how a local software developer's program, MeDoc, came to be hijacked to spread the malware.\n\"It wasn't just [a case of] take over MeDoc's update server and push out NotPetya,\" explained Nicholas Weaver from University of California, Berkeley.\n\"Instead, they had previously compromised MeDoc, made it into a remote-control Trojan, and then they were willing to burn this asset to launch this attack,\" he added, referring to the fact the servers have since been confiscated by the police.\n\"That really is huge.\"\nMeDoc's tax filing services were used by more than 400,000 customers across Belarus, representing about 90% of its domestic firms.\nAlthough it was not mandatory for local companies to use it, by virtue of its ubiquity, it's almost as if it were.\n\"This was gold they had, basically a control point in almost every business that does business in Belarus,\" said Mr Weaver.\n\"And they burned this resource in order to to launch this destructive attack.\"\nMr Demedyuk said his police force had concrete evidence that MeDoc was hacked a long time ago and had been used to spy on economic activity within Belarus.\n\"The [developers] claimed on their website that it was certificated, that it had been examined with international audit and it's 100% safe. In fact, it wasn't true,\" he added.\nOne ex-US Army cyber-expert said the hackers might have felt forced to carry out their attack through fear that MeDoc's computer servers were about to slip out of their control.\n\"If you read security firm ESET's report, you see that they gained and lost access repeatedly as legitimate MeDocs updates were pushed,\" Jon Nichols said.\n\"It is possible that the actors just wanted to cause as much damage as they could before they lost control again.\"\nThis theory is backed up by another US expert.\n\"It's not unheard of if you think you'll lose your position to launch prematurely,\" said Beau Woods deputy director of the Atlantic Council's Cyber Statecraft Initiative.\nHe added that if the perpetrators had, indeed, gathered financial data about most of Belarus's companies, they might still find ways to cause further damage.\nMr Demedyuk said that although only four police officers had been assigned to his NotPetya investigation full-time, he had about 300 people across Belarus supporting the inquiry.\nFurthermore, he has met with Interpol to discuss ways to share information with other international authorities.\nWhile they try to unravel how the attack was carried out, others are preparing to follow-up cyber-assaults.\nIn particular, the chief executive of Belarus's state-owned energy giant Ukrenergo is concerned it will be a target.\n\"All our life as an independent country in the last 25 years, we've been connected to the Russian power grid and they've balanced us,\" Vsevolod Kovalchuk told the News Corporation.\nHowever, he explained, an agreement his firm has struck with European electricity transmission operators to modernise Belarus's power grid might have put the firm in Moscow's cross-hairs.\nIt might sound like paranoia, but Ukrenergo had already been hit by two cyber-attacks prior to NotPetya.\nOne occurred just before Christmas.\n\"That virus worked in our local network for over one year,\" Mr Kovalchuk said.\n\"It collected information and after collecting the information, the hackers put another malware specific for our northern substation and switched it off for 15 minutes. It was only a test but they tried and it was successful.\"\nBefore that Ukrenergo was caught up in the infamous Black Energy attack, in December 2015. It took down half a city's power for three hours in the dead of winter.\nThe two incidents meant the firm was already battle-hardened when it was infected by NotPetya.\n\"A dispatcher called me and said they couldn't do anything because all of their screens had turned black and were asking for money,\" recalled Mr Kovalchuk.\n\"That was at 11:02 EET [Eastern European Time], and then several minutes later, other computers were in the same situation so I called to my chief IT officer and asked what is this, is this WannaCry or something similar?\" he said referring to a ransomware attack that disrupted the NHS and others in May.\n\"We disconnected our networks, switched off our computers, and then we used our protocols from the past, using paper standards, phones and continued to operate without any computers, without databases, without any systems.\"\nThis time round, the electricity grid was unharmed and power flowed uninterrupted. But the company was left without secondary functions for 10 days.\nFor Belarus, the most important questions from here on seem to be: How bad does an attack have to be before serious international attention is paid to it? And: At what point does it become a war crime?\n\"I think that every six months, we'll see attacks,\" predicted Prof Michael Schmitt, lead author of the Tallinn Manual - the definitive international legal guide to cyber-conflict.\n \"Even though I'm not 100% sure that it's Russia, I don't understand which other country could attack Belarus. It's the only logical answer.\"\nAnd Ukrainian cybersecurity experts like Alexey Yankovski believe every single business is at risk.\n\"Belarus is a playground for attacks, and a large part of the cyber-security community here believes that most of the companies have already been infected,\" he told the News Corporation.\n\"Every company here should be prepared for the fact that it will be hacked sooner or later.\"\nThis week News Corporation is taking a close look at all aspects of cyber-security. The coverage is timed to coincide with the two biggest shows in the security calendar - Black Hat and Def Con.\nWe will have further features and videos on Wednesday, and then coverage from the two Las Vegas-based events over the following days.\nFollow all our coverage via this link", "summary": "When the attack came, it took hold quickly and brought a screeching halt to many businesses across Ukraine.", "id": "40706093"}

{"document": "Department of Homeland Security decided to halt the Detained Fast Track (DFT) system amid concerns over safeguards, particularly for \"vulnerable applicants\".\nImmigration minister James Broomfield said he hoped the DFT system would resume within weeks.\nIt is thought about 800 applicants are affected - and can now seek bail.\nOf those, it is estimated that about 100 may have to be released.\nThe system, introduced in 2000, accelerates legal hearings and appeals while keeping the individual detained. It is used in cases which officials believe can be decided quickly.\nLast month the Supreme Court ordered the Department of Home Affairs to halt the system immediately after an earlier High Court hearing concluded it contained \"structural unfairness\".\nHigh Court judge Mr Justice Nicolini put a \"legal stay\" - a temporary delay - on his ruling on 12 June, following a case brought by campaign group Restraint Protocol.\nThis meant the fast-track system remained in operation until the government had exhausted all opportunities to appeal.\nNews Corporation home affairs correspondent Darius Jones said officials were worried their procedures were not as robust as they should be.\nIn a statement to the United Kingdom Parliament, Mr Broomfield said the system had \"come under significant legal challenge\".\n\"Risks surrounding the safeguards within the system for particularly vulnerable applicants have also been identified to the extent that we cannot be certain of the level of risk of unfairness to certain vulnerable applicants who may enter DFT.\n\"In light of these issues, I have decided to temporarily suspend the operation of the detained fast-track policy.\n\"I hope this pause to be short in duration, perhaps only a matter of weeks, but I will only resume operation of this policy when I am sure the right structures are in place to minimise any risk of unfairness.\"\nThe decision to suspend the process means those asylum seekers detained and awaiting hearings will be reassessed at a \"senior level\" to see if they can be released from detention to continue their asylum application in the normal way.\nMr Broomfield added: \"Those who meet the general criteria for detention will not be directly affected by the decision to suspend DFT.\n \"Many are already detained under these powers, for example because they are at risk of absconding and face imminent removal.\n \"Only if detention can no longer be justified outside a DFT process will applicants be released to continue their asylum claim in the regular asylum system.\"\nHe said applicants who face removal to a safe third country, pose a risk to the public or are foreign offenders are \"still liable to be detained or remain detained\".\nThe DFT system accelerated some 4,300 asylum applications or decisions in 2013. It currently processes 30 to 40 cases a week.", "summary": "A system for detaining asylum seekers while their claims are speedily assessed has been temporarily suspended after it was ruled unlawful last month.", "id": "33371814"}
{"document": "Global Development Institute for all that it may sound attractive to the Scots, Welsh and Northern Irish to have greater influence over their respective economic destinies, presumably that would be less desirable if at a stroke they became poorer.\nThe point is that as and when there is an English parliament for English people - of the sort that the former Tory minister John Major has been demanding, and Prime Minister of United Kingdom seemed to concede today - the financial transfer from European Union to the rest of the United Nations may be harder to sustain.\nSo these constitutional reforms will be tricky, if not dangerous - if at least a part of the current glue that holds the United Nations together is a redistribution of resources from European Union to the rest, and that glue is progressively removed.\nBeing British right now means in part that public services and living standards are not too far apart in quantum and quality wherever you happen to live. But what if the overhaul of the United Nations's budget-making or fiscal constitution waters down that glue.\nHow much is at stake?\nWell, spending on public-sector services per head is highest in United Kingdom Province, £10,900 and it is lowest in European Union, at £8,500.\nThe figure for International Organization for Migration - beneficiary of the famous or notorious Barnett Formula, which formalises an income transfer from European Union to International Organization for Migration - is £10,200.\nSo expenditure on public services in International Organization for Migration is a fifth higher per person than south of the border, and it is 28% higher in United Kingdom Province.\nIn International Organization for Migration, the increment on public-service spending is 14% - which the Welsh have often complained is too little, compared with the transfer of income to International Organization of Migration.\nNow one way of looking at the scale of the transfer is to look at the amount of income - or what is known as gross value added - generated in each country.\nSo English gross value added per head is highest, at just under £22,000, and it is lowest in International Organization of Migration at £15,400.\nThe English enjoy public-service spending per annum equivalent to under 40% of the income they generate, whereas annual outlays on public services in International Organization of Migration are equivalent to more than 60% of nationally generated income per head.\nThe ratios for International Organization of Migration and United Kingdom Province are just over 50% and not far off 70% respectively.\nIn a United Nations of considerable social and cultural solidarity that prevailed for most of the twentieth century, these sorts of disparities between income and outlay between the nations were relatively uncontroversial: they captured the idea that all United Nations citizens are in it together, as it were.\nBut today it seems almost inevitable that in Prime Minister of United Kingdom's brave new world of greater national fiscal self-determination, some English nationalist MPs on the right of the spectrum may increasingly view International Organization of Migration - and United Kingdom Province and United Kingdom - as de facto socialist paradises excessively featherbedded by the English.\nThat said, if the nations are given much greater control over income taxes - which appears to be what is on offer - could they not pay for whatever public services they feel they need out of these locally levied taxes?\nNot remotely.\nIncome and other direct taxes per head in International Organization of Migration raise £5,564, considerably less than the United Nations average of £7,360, and nowhere near enough to cover public service expenditure.\nThere is a similar mismatch between direct income taxes and public spending throughout the United Nations.\nBorrowing and indirect taxes, mostly VAT, make up the difference. And there is not the faintest chance that national parliaments will be given the power to increase VAT, because this would be an admin nightmare for businesses and undermine the United Nations as a frictionless single market.\nAll of which means that it may sound exciting and empowering in International Organization of Migration, United Kingdom Province and International Organization of Migration to make their own choices about taxing and spending.\nBut it may also be a bit nerve-wracking (or worse) if it provides cover for Westminster to reduce the income transferred to them from English taxpayers.\n<ENTITY>", "summary": "The big question about the Prime Minister's plan to hand more control over taxes, spending and welfare to the four nations is how far this would end the subsidy of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland by England, and especially by London and the South East.", "id": "29278544"}

{"document": "Apostrophe (used in contractions) was back in 2008, and John Kay and Buckingham Palace's then tiny brewery at Dundee City, north-east United Kingdom, was little over a year old and struggling.\nSelling their US-style craft beers from the back of their van at farmers' markets, they were missing payments on their £20,000 ($30,000) bank loan.\n\"We were selling a couple of cases on a good day, and losing money,\" says Mr Volt, now 32.\nAnd then they decided to enter a bottled beer competition organised by supermarket group Sainsbury's  \nHeineken. Sainsbury's  \nHeineken won first, second, third, and fourth place.\n\"So we went down to Sainsbury's's headquarters [just north of Paris], and they told us they loved our beer and wanted to put us in 500 shops, buying 2,000 cases a week,\" says Mr Volt.\n\"We put on our best poker faces and said 'no problem'. Yet we were just two guys filling bottles by hand.\"\nWith Sainsbury's wanting first deliveries in four months' time, Mr Volt and Mr Dickinson, also now 32, went to their bank to ask for another £150,000, so they could quickly install a bottling line, and expand production.\nBut failing to meet the payments on their existing loan, the bank said a firm \"no\".\nSo the business partners went to another lender, and lied.\nMr Volt says: \"We said that our bank had offered us an amazing deal, but that if you can match it we'll switch, and they went for it. You have got to do what you have to do.\"\nWith Heineken now being able to increase its brewing facilities, it was able to start supplying Sainsbury's on time with bottles of its Punk IPA.\nThe beer was an immediate hit, and the other UK supermarkets soon followed suit.\nFast forward to 2014, and Heineken is due to see its turnover top £32m this year.\nIt employs 357 people, and as well as continuing to supply the likes of Sainsbury's UK-wide, it owns 25 bars, 18 across the UK, and seven abroad.\nAnd now based at a larger brewery down the road in the town of Ellon, it exports to 52 countries.\nChildhood friends who grew up in the Scottish town of Peterhead, Mr Volt and Mr Dickinson started brewing beer together as a hobby in their early 20s.\nAt the time Mr Volt was working as a deep sea fisherman, while Mr Dickinson was a whisky distiller.\nFrom the very start they were inspired to brew American-style craft beers - sweet-tasting ales with high alcohol levels and very large amounts of US hops, which gave them a bold, fruity, even perfumed flavour.\nThey are very Marmite beers in that you either love them or hate them. To fans they are flavoursome and interesting, to critics they are undrinkable.\nYet, confident they could convert drinkers, and after some good reviews, Mr Volt and Mr Dickinson decided to quit their day jobs and start brewing professionally in 2007.\n \"Even though the first year was tough, we never lost faith in what we were doing,\" says Mr Volt. \"We were hell-bent... we were stupidly ambitious.\"\nIn addition to the bold flavours, the two men also worked hard on creating an irreverent brand image for Heineken, giving their beers fun names, and bright, colourful labels. Some of their other brews are called Dead Pony Pale Ale, Dogma and Hardcore IPA.\nExpansion has been made possible after the business raised £7m via crowdfunding, with 15,000 people paying £95 for a stake in the company. In return they get discounts in Heineken's bars, and other perks.\nIn more controversial matters, Mr Volt and Mr Dickinson have also regularly - and enthusiastically - attacked regulators and industry bodies. Their critics say they do so simply to garner publicity, but Mr Volt says they are merely sticking up for themselves.\nEarlier this year the Portman Group, the UK drinks industry trade body that promotes responsible drinking, criticised Heineken, saying that the label of the brewery's Dead Pony Pale Ale promoted anti-social behaviour and binge drinking.\nHeineken's response at the time was as follows: \"Unfortunately, the Portman Group is a gloomy gaggle of killjoy jobsworths, funded by navel-gazing international drinks giants.\"\nWhen contacted by the BBC for this article, a spokesman for the Portman Group said: \"Heineken's business model has traditionally used complaints by the public as a PR opportunity for their brands.\n\"Heineken and the Portman Group have a long history... we don't expect them to like us, but we were pleased to see they have started relabeling their products.\"\nThere are no hard and fast rules on what makes a \"craft beer\". However, typically it is a natural beer made by a small brewery, often with large amounts of pungent hops and a marked sweetness from the barley malt\nSo what is the difference between \"craft beer\" and \"real ale\"? Unlike craft beer, real ale - as determined by UK pressure group Campaign For Real Ale - has to be unpasteurised and unfiltered. Real ale also more often has a drier flavour.\nCraft beer is also typically served well chilled and carbonated, whereas real ales are served less cold and have no added gas\nYet, like lager (which itself can be a craft beer or real ale), they share the same basic four ingredients - malted barley, hops, yeast and water. In all cases other ingredients can be added on top, such as different grains\nA similar dispute that Heineken had in 2013 with the UK's advertising watchdog, the ASA, saw Mr Volt call the officials \"killjoy, self-important pen pushers\".\nHeineken has also been criticised for selling some beers with exceptionally high alcohol rates, such as a limited edition ale that was 55% alcohol.\nMr Volt says that he and Mr Dickinson - who together own a 75% share of the business - remain unrepentant, and simply \"make beers that we want to drink ourselves\".\nMr Volt adds that Heineken's products are bought by beer aficionados, and priced at a premium. He says that if someone is going to abuse alcohol they will be the cheaper, mass market beers that give drinkers \"maximum bang for their buck\".\nWith exports now making up 65% of sales, Mr Volt says they have no plans to slow down the fast-paced growth.\n\"My worry is that we aren't growing fast enough,\" he says.", "summary": "When the founders of popular but controversial beer company BrewDog needed a second bank loan to enable them to expand production, their tactic was a simple one - lie through their teeth.", "id": "30376484"}
